reviews.review_text: Update: It appears that Starbreeze has purchased all the rights to their game and they are doing away with paid drills. This is a step in the right direction, but in my opinion there are still a lot of wrongs that need to be righted before I can recommend the game.  Original Review:  My friend, Doctor Insano, said it better than I could...  So here's the thing. I have 2,000 hours in this game. I have a Youtube channel of me doing Death Wish heists solo without bots. I did the Tabula Rasa challenge solo without bots, unmodded weapons, before Grinder. You could say I loved this game at one point.  That time is gone. Overkill has repeatedly broken promises. They directly said before release 'We will not ever have microtransactions.' And yesterday, October 15, 2015, they added Microtransactions. This game is not Free to Play with microtransactions. This game is not cheap with microtransactions. This game has a reasonably priced base game with $100 of DLC. In order to purchase this game with all DLC, you must pay $130 outside of a sale. On top of this $130 price tag are microtransactions. Just...think about that. The price of this game alone is more than the price of two AAA games. Overkill then has the audacity to TRIPLE DIP on this by adding microtransactions.  Last year, there were a series of 'what's next' audio files hinting at something. After a *month* of daily audio files being released, it culminated in an advertisement for another game that isn't released until 2016 and an in-game baseball bat.  Last year, we had 'Crimefest,' where the top reward Overkill was to release was a mystery. This mystery ended up being John Wick. A movie tie-in they were going to make and release anyway.  Last year, some of the rewards for Crimefest were 'FBI Files' (in-game stats), and a new enemy. These weren't released until this year. The FBI files ended up being a re-implementation of a community web page, and the new enemy ended up just being a bunch of shields standing in a circle.  This year, Overkill did a 'Hype Train' event. By pre-ordering DLC, we would get 'hype-fuel' points. With enough 'hype-fuel,' rewards for the community would be unlocked. In order to boost sales, Overkill finally delivered on a promise of finishing their new prestige levels (called Infamy). The first five infamy levels provided very small gameplay benefits along with awesome in-game masks. The next 20 levels released in Infamy 2.0 provided new masks and experience point bonuses (so you can infamy....faster?). I call this 'Mask Pack 2.0.' It took Overkill 14 months to release this. In response, people started refunding their DLC pre-orders. In response to THAT, Overkill released the DLC early so no one could get refunds. The latest Hype-train reward has yet to be released. In response to this, I completely stopped buying DLC. I have no DLC at all that has been released since Mask Pack 2.0.  And most recently, Overkill added microtransactions after explicitly saying that they will NEVER do that along with intentionally breaking extremely well made community mods. Overkill does not deserve your money. They do not deserve any money. They have repeatedly broken their promises to the community. They have insulted the community. They have done absolutely nothing but show how far a company can fall.  Overkill, shame on you. I truly do not believe there are words that can describe my level of disappointment with you. Am I angry? You bet your ♥♥♥ I am. But more than that, I'm just so disappointed. You've truly shown that you are nothing but liars and cheats. I truly hope your company goes out of business.

It was an honestly fun horde shooter before the DLC power creep took hold.  Also, the requirements call for multiple CPU cores when the game can only run on one. Overkill™ quality and all that.

Payday 2 is a fantasticly fun game, which gets even more enjoyable with friends. The gunplay is nice, the skills give tons of different playstyles, the heists are enjoyable, and the music is amazing. I would completely recommend this game to anyone if it was made by a different developer. Sadly, it's made by Overkill.  See, Overkill is known for keeping in touch with their community. And that's not a bad thing; it's great, actually. If they actually ♥♥♥♥ing listened to their community, that is, instead of just pretending to give a ♥♥♥♥ about the people that play it. Overkill loves money, never forget it. They release tons of DLC, did a whole 'completely free event' back in the Spring where you had to buy DLC to unlock more rewards, and now did another 'completely free event' where on the first day microtransactions are added that give stat boosts.  Now, whether or not you consider this Pay 2 Win or not is your opinion, as it is a coop game. But it's still ♥♥♥♥ing slimy to promise your community a completely free event, have them work hard to get all the rewards, then day ♥♥♥♥ing one release a macrotransaction system which gives stat boosts.  This is a great game. It was made by a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ developer. If you want to still spend your money on it, go ahead, but be ready to feel like ♥♥♥♥ when Overkill once again manages to ♥♥♥♥ over their community for that cash.

Don't spend your money on a game that is developed by liars that are twisted and blinded by their greed. This game is 100% community driven, but Overkill seems to be fine with ♥♥♥♥ing us all in the ♥♥♥.

I've been playing this game since its beta, back then, the game used to have a lot of potential, It was a game I was excited for back in 2013. When Payday 2 was finally released, it was a broken, unpolished piece of software, the base content was alarmingly low and some of features announced before its release were nowhere to be found. However, the gunplay was a blast and the addition of skilltrees, mask/weapon customization and the card drop system kept the game interesting despite its lack of levels. At this date, the base game offers an acceptable amount of content for its price but still remain broken and unpolished.  I would actually recommend the game if it wasn't for Overkill's behavior these past years.  Of course there are the sheer amount overpriced DLCs and the microtransactions but that's only the tip of the iceberg.  Back in 2014, Overkill hosted the first community event known as the Crimefest, where the community could be awarded free stuff by joining the community group.  Reaching 3 millions members would unlock a the last reward which was a secret at the time. Unsurprisingly, the community thought that this last secret reward was going to be something awesome, so they started to gather everyone they could in order to reach that 3 Millions member mark. And then Overkill ruined everything when they revealed that the secret reward was the fact that they were going to use those 3 Millions of people to advertise a movie and later on the AlienWare Alpha and their own VR Googles and if you leave the group to avoid that kind of advertisement, you can kiss all the the free content released after the event goodbye. Not to mention some of the rewards unlocked were post-poned and released roughly one year later during the second Crimefest.  A couple of month after that event, Overkill released 2 DLCs on the same day which started the trend of putting 2 DLCs on the storefront instead of regrouping all the extra content they made for Payday 2 into one single DLC in an attempt to squeeze as much money as they can from their playerbase.   Then we got the second community event : The Hypetrain which is a Crimefest where the 'free' rewards are unlocked with a set amount of hypefuel that can only be obtained by buying DLCs on the store. Two DLCs were introduced : The Overkill Pack and the Completely Overkill pack which were not related in any way as their name would suggest (The first being a simple weapon pack and the later being a 25$ 'support' with 4 masks and a weapon skin 'crafted with love and care [...] A true Payday collectible'). I suppose Overkill thought it would be hilarious to confuse everyone.  But this wasn't enough for Overkill, all the money they were already making wasn't even close to enough. Fast foward to the Road to Crimefest ; the third community event, Overkill came up with the neat idea of giving the community actual in-game challenges that would unlock the rewards upon completion. Once again, the community worked hard to overcome all the challenges and managed to unlock the final reward. And then Overkill once again ruined everything when they revealed that the final reward was in fact a microtransactions system à la CS:GO. 'But it is not that bad because CS:GO and TF2 does the same thing and get away with it... Right?' Well, not really, TF2 is a Free-to-play where that kind of business model is expected while CS:GO may be a pay-to-play game but is updated on a regular basis and all the content added to the game beside weapon skins is free of charge.  Meanwhile Payday 2 is not free-to-play, has those kind of microtransactions, is updated on a regular basis but the content added to the game may be paid DLCs. The microtransactions are there just to, again, squeeze as much money from the playerbase rather than support the developement of the game itself.  I cannot think about this game without having a bitter taste in my mouth, Payday 2 could have been something much greater than a money extracting billboard meme-shooter if it wasn't for Overkill greed.  The game is still great but Overkill is ruining it. Since all the money they are already making through microtransactions and DLC sales will never be enough, they will probably come up with something even more disgusting than the introduction of microtransactions in the future.

Crimefest is close. Free rewards for the community since they finished challenges given by overkill during the last few weeks.  Now Crimefest is here. The first reward is revealed and it is....a treasure/chest/crate system with Skins ala Team Fortress 2 and Counterstrike: Global Offensive.  I liked Payday 1, i liked Payday 2. I might not have alot of hours put into the games, but it was a nice game to get back on once in a while and Crimefest was the perfect opportunity to get back in now.  After seeing the First Day Update of skins that BOOST stats of the weapons and the gambling mechanic, which costs as much as a key in TF2 or CS:GO, i deinstalled and im never going to look back. Overkill lied to us when they promised 'free' rewards and they lied to us when they said a few years ago: 'PD2 will never have micro-transactions'. It's a damn shame what is happening right now

-----Updated review:  With the broken promise of introducing microtransactions, I can no longer recommend Payday 2, nor will I support or laud Overkill as I have done in the past.  - Skinny from the Fat B*stard  (curator link)   -----Previous (positive) review:  One of the best FPS experiences available. Fun solo; even better in co-op with friends.  Payday 2 picks up where  Payday 1  left off - improving on almost every facet of the first game.  Several heists have been designed specifically with the option to use stealth tactics as opposed to going loud (aka 'Plan B'), with a revamped skill system to help facilitate the players' preferences.  With a tonne of post-release content, both free and paid (but none of it essential), the developers continue to foster a healthy relationship with the community, listening to and working with the playerbase to improve an already superb game.

Let me just quickly list off the things that ruined this game for me personally, and that anyone who might be interested in purchasing this game should know before buying. I do not make this review lightly, and I myself have played the game thoroughly. I however cannot forgive some of this game's faults. They are the following:  -Terrible money-grab DLC's. The gage shotgun pack is perhaps the worst here, and in my opinion the courier pack is perhaps the best (simply due to the fact that you now have some slight control over what gun attachments you are getting). But to pay $5+ to recieve a few specific guns only to have all of the modifications locked behind impossible to get achievements is ridiculous. For example, 'Unusual Suspects' in the Watchdogs job, you have to complete the mission with four different friends all wearing different DLC masks. This is an obvious ploy to convince your friends to waste their money on the DLC as well so you can get the mods the achievement unlocks. While you are not necessarily forced to buy the dlc content, the game does get dull after a while, and the presence of all the DLC makes it all the more obvious that if you want a few more hours of gameplay out of this game the devs are going to milk you for all it's worth and then some.  -Mob spam. What's that? You crave more difficulty? Instead of perhaps, improving the AI, allow us to instead drown you in a sea of tasers and shields to create the illusion of difficulty!  -Specials are ridiculous. Shields are perhaps the most annoying considering they trace your exact movement to the point that they will clip the shield through their body to block you. Don't expect to be able to shoot their hands or feet either. Tasers have a tendency to hit you through cars, and they have almost no cooldown from what I can tell. Cloakers, clearly equiped in light armor, can take up to 3 shotgun shells to the face before finally dying. I'd say the only thing done right are the bulldozers.  -There are no real tactics once you've gone loud. Expect to everyone to just run around the map. You honestly can't completely hold a position or a room due to the AI's instict of simply walking right up to you (or THROUGH you). Your team full of random people will most likely just be wandering the map doing their own thing unless it's strictly stealth. AI can hardly use cover. The game will basically zerg you to death.  -This game uses card draw at the end of every heist to determine if you get a mask, a mod, a pattern (for mask), instant cash, or a colorscheme (for pattern). Cards tend to get very repetitive very fast. This alone would be fine, but the game has a way of punishing you for trying to farm these cards by debuffing your experience points (The largest exp reduction I have recieved was -15%, which is quite significant on Overkill). You will undoubtedly reach a point in the game where you have more money than actual stuff to buy.  -AI teammates are the definition of useless. They cannot grab bags, they will not restart drills, and hell-- they can't even shoot straight. Basically the only thing you'll be doing by having AI teammates is giving yourself a couple of bullet sponges while you do all the actual work. They also have really bad judgement over weather to shoot the enemy or revive you, so expect the AI to do neither effectively.  -No system for migrating hosts. Doesn't matter how long you've spent on a heist, if the player who started the lobby disconnects, all of your time has essentially just been wasted. This is a giant problem.  -Game will randomly go out of sync. AI can be random places compared to other people's game. It gets especially confusing when AI flip a switch when in your view they are on the other side of a wall.  - Finally, pay and experience don't really seem to correlate with mission difficulty. Some missions just aren't worth doing unless you're going for either variety or a skull mask.  All-in-all, the game is definitely bearable, but having steam friends who play the game aswell was pretty much the only reason for the amount of hours I've poured into this game. These things I have listed are simply what finally drove me away from the game.   (Also, anyone who feels so inclined as to try to give me tips on how to play the game, don't bother. I've logged over 200 hours into this game. I've figured everything out, there is really nothing you could possibly inform me of that I don't already know. If you have any objections as to the things I have stated I will revise this review accordingly.)

I have 300 hours in this game, I've done every mission. I've completed almost every mission on the hardest difficulty, the only ones remaining being the most recent paid-DLC missions that they added when I stopped playing this game. I've got to V-100 (Max level, max prestige) legitimately. This game is decent but it has far too many problems.   Firstly, playing with friends is a blast. Get together with 3 other people and rob a bank, diamond store, etc. Go in stealthily, silently take out guards in an empty corridor or just swagger in while putting a mask over your face and holding a shotgun. That stuff is great at first. If you're an experienced player and friends are new to the game -- Let them host the game and pick the missions. I see too many people catapulting their friends through the levels by doing max difficulty multi-day heists. A natural progression is much more enjoyable for everyone.  On to the problems:  1) Stealth is broken.   A core gameplay mechanic outright doesn't work. In order to stealth consistently you need to use light armour (or a suit) and low profile weapons. If the alarm gets raised, stealth is gone and you need to complete the mission 'loud'. Good luck taking out juggernauts in bomb disposal suits, and 100 assorted law enforcement personnel with your silenced handgun and a suit. It's not realisitically going to happen unless you're already ready to escape.  Secondly, stealth is actually broken. Without talking about desync issues in MP (yet): guards will walk through walls, spot you through walls, spot a broken window through 4 walls whilst being at the other side of a building, etc. This breaks stealth and you need to complete the mission loud (as described above). There is no reason for it, it just happens. There is no counterplay or skill-based way of avoiding it, the game will decide at random intervals whether you fail the mission right then for no reason whatsoever.  Thirdly, for balance reasons you get a limited number of cable ties to take hostages. This stops them calling the cops, running away (alerting other civilians, etc). You can also use an ECM jammer, a temporary device that stops people calling police and/or jams cameras. It gives you time to destroy cameras, take hostages, etc. It would be great if it worked consistently: Civilians are randomly able to trigger the alarm while it's up (it's not intended). Yet another feature of the game that will instantly fail a mission because of a bug.  Lastly, certain stealthable missions ('Big oil' being the main example) have broken hivemind AI. If one NPC sees you, every NPC in the map immediately becomes alerted and knows your exact position, will raise the alarm, etc. Stealth is a puzzle game with a little bit of RNG. Once you figure out how to stealth a mission, it's solved.  2) MP is broken  Multiplayer is broken in many, many ways. It's P2P (which I'm fine with for this format of game). There are random connection problems, sometimes a certain friend can't join you but you can join them; then another friend is able to join you but not them. Other times it will work just fine.  Privacy settings are broken. If you make a public lobby it's usually public, but not always. If you make a private lobby, it's sometimes public. 'Friend-only' is Friends and friends-of-friends to the infinite degree (but only one at once). A friend can join you and while they are in the game, their friend 'X' can join your games; the original friend is free to leave then. Then any friend of 'X' can also join, and so on.  Bottom line: They are visibility settings, not restrictions . There are big problems with doing it that way.  Hackers are abundant. There are some very basic anti-cheat methods in the game. They don't actually stop people cheating, instead it marks that player as a cheater for everyone in the game. The cheating isn't so much of an issue -- you can host your own lobby if your connection is stable enough or you can just leave an find another lobby (or play with friends!). The bigger issue is 3rd party services (pd2stats) that will check your profile to see if you're cheating. No problem, apart from if you have a private profile on steam you'll be kicked from every public lobby. This is indirectly the fault of the game, the community has been driven to inaccurate methods of detecting people cheating because the game offers basically nothing. Not to mention that those sites will randomly mark you as a hacker for a variety of reasons. If you're max level, prepare to be kicked from every game too: people would rather just kick you than risk playing with a hacker.  Sync is broken. Physicals aren't synced, they're all client-side. This is espeically a problem with ragdolls. So enemy positions aren't synced but detection is done on the host. It leads to many things like getting spotted through a wall (NB: This can happen in SP because of a bug anyway). If you shoot a guard, he'll die where he actually is -- not for you though. So that guard who's in a corridor, but actually in the middle of room: Don't shoot him. He'll die in a room full of people and you'll fail. Of course you'll see the corpse in the corridor with no way for anyone to see them, but 3 other people in the game will shout at you for it. So you decide to wait an extra second or two to counteract it (taking into account you may got spotted too!) and you may think you've worked around the issue (nope!). Ragdolls are client-side: The body can ragdoll anywhere on the host and get the alarm triggered. Sometimes the physics can break and you can't answer the guard's pager (required!) and so you fail. That's a fourth distinct way of just failing a mission that's completely out of your control.  3) Items are RNG, missions are a grind, difficulty increases  So you can buy guns, great! Oh, you need an RNG drop to unlock the silencer. When it comes to stealth or max difficulty missions, you need the right loadout from RNG drops. By max level (without prestige) you'll have almost everything you'll need for a lot of missions (But not the perfect gear).  Unlocking skills costs money. You get money by doing missions (hurrah!) but you'll quickly find at lower levels that you level up faster than accumulating the required money to actually utilize your level. Don't think about unlocking guns at the same time either.  There aren't many different missions. There's quite a few at first, but many of them are pointless after a while. The 'lower level' missions give very little EXP or money regardless of difficulty. They aren't much easier on the hardest difficulties compared to other missions and in some cases can take longer. It forces you into grinding the same missions over and over. The devs have done a decent job recently in balancing the amounts of EXP and cash earned but it's just not enough.  Newer (DLC, free or paid) missions are more difficult than the previous missions. That's cool since it gives a new challenge. Oh? They improved the AI too! Cool. Wow, this is hard and I'm going to enjoy it when I finall-- wait, why is that guy mowing through everything it takes a whole clip to the face for me to kill it. 'lol these new weapons are great' -- Weapons from paid DLC.  4) Free content is 'community DLC'  It's not 'free DLC', it's 'community DLC' which is free. All you need to do is to join the steam group for the game and you unlock it. New weapons, missions. It's cool until you disagree with a dev and they can decide to ban you from the group. GUIZE WE BAN HACKERZ ND DEY CNT GET FREE STUFFZ! (except of course, they can).  Closing: I'm out of characters (there's a limit!). Edit- Well, Crimefest 2015 is over. While almost every day seemed like it was part of an elaborate joke, there was no punchline. Almir, the head of the company, did an AMA on Reddit, and has outright said that the microtransactions will not be removed, that the stat bonuses from skins will not be removed, and that everything is going great on their end. He says that the only people upset are a very vocal minority.  I've already bought this game. I've already bought a lot of the DLC (most of it). But I won't be buying any more games from Overkill. Almir wants to present Overkill as a tiny independent dev company, and this is not the case. Almir wants to pretend that the community was happy to have the safes, the crappy skins, and the stat bonuses, and we are not. Almir wants to pretend like Overkill is struggling, and needs the funds from microtransactions to stay afloat, while their parent company's own financial reports (publicly visible, since they are a publicly traded company) prove otherwise. In fact, they show that Payday 2 has been raking in the money.  The blatant lies and disregard for the community shown by Almir, who is apparently acting as their community spokesperson as well, since nobody else has said a word, are rather disappointing. Even more disappointing, since this is, in fact, a great game.  Original: This is a great game, and right now, you should not buy it. Perhaps if the microtransactions are removed, the safes no longer possible to receive instead of a payout for finishing a mission, some way to earn keys without actually spending money, the stat boosts removed, perhaps then it might be worth picking up again. This game has more to it than just the average fps, or strategy game. I got no clue where to start, but let's discuss the games -  Graphics: If your computer can hadnle everything on max, it looks really good, they have chosen the right colour palette for each map, but if you run it on minimum, it can be quite annoying to look at from time to time, for example distance animation (turn it down and you get less animation on the police, and civilians in the distance) They tend to have sorta laggy look, which can be really distracting. But overall, if you're 50%+ (It's a bar where you adjust it) then you're going to be fine.  Gameplay: Well it's quite obvious what the game has to offer, 4 masked men with weapons and money, and it's called Payday (2). But it's an awesome game which let you and your team decide wether you want to go loud or stealth. You get an exp bonus for doing stealth (which is not to let anyone inform the police you're there), there's a great varierity on customization for your weaponry, alot of different silencers, and other powerful muzzles, scopes, stocks, sights, everything your heart desires :)   Further interests: You also have a leveling system and 2 money accounts ingame, One being your Spending cash, cash you spend on mask weapons and customizations and more, where you then got your Offshore account, which mainly is being used to buy Infamous (If you reach level 100 you can choose to pay 200M for an infamous level and unlock unique items. I'm level 99 as I write this)   About the leveling system: You got 4 tech trees, or talent trees: Mastermind, Enforcer, Technician, Ghost. Mastermind, is kinda the leader, the one who can buy cheaper assets, drop medic bags, and revive you from distance. Enforcer, Brutal shotgun service, with the help and assist of deploying ammo bags for his team. Technician, C4 master, can blast through any common safe or door, which saves 2-8 mins. He also have a disposeable sentry, which however in my opinion isn't worth it. Ghost, the stealther, the one person with ECM (which is a jammer of phone signals and more) He's the invisible one running around and stealing without being seen once.  The Music: Fabulous, flawless, interesting and really well fitting under the assaults! The music tends to change from whenever there's assault or not (which is the intense wave attack of the enforcement if you have alerted them)  I bet there's something I have forgotten to mention, but this is my honest opinion about it so far :) Hope you enjoyed this review.  10/10

So, I'm seldom inclined to write reviews for games. Often, I feel like people are more inclined to write about a game when it's negative rather than when it's positive. However, I felt pretty inclined after the last few weeks events between Overkill and the Payday community to write a review for Payday 2 once the drama had died down and I could view everything from a level perspective. Now that I have, I will say that Payday 2 is a good game, if incredibly grindy. It's a good game to play with friends, not unlike L4D2 or Vermintide. The progression is there and it's relatively solid. However, I can't recommend the game in good faith given the recent drama. The introduction of microtransactions was originally promised by the developers as something that would never happen. Indeed, I also believed this and this is why I wholeheartedly supported Overkill by purchasing DLC and by extension, supporting their product. Unfortunately, this turned out to be a lie. Now, microtransactions allow an individual to get skins on their weapons which, unlike CS:GO (which has a sensible model for this), these skins actually give stat boosts. Thus, we now have a game that's pay-to-win in some sense, as well as the introduction of microtransactions and costly DLC. I have nothing against DLC personally, but I am against a developer lying to their playerbase, especially one that has been loyal over the life of Payday 2.  For that reason, I would encourage folks to avoid Payday 2. If you're looking for a good horde-like game with progression, I wholeheartedly recommend Warhammer End Times: Vermintide. Other good games similar to the genre would be Left 4 Dead 2 and Killing Floor. Support developers that don't lie to their playerbase.

I used to be an avid payday fan. I played a lot of Payday 1 and was very hyped for Payday 2. It was an instant pre-order for me. As soon as I got into the beta, I was amazed at how it felt. It was great. For the first half year I was having loads of fun. Then slowly I started realising that were only were a meager ammount of heists. And that the mechanics were not all that great at times.  But then the DLCs came. At first the DLCs were decent money. You payed €6,- for 6 heists, 4 masks with patterns and materials and 3 guns.  Then came the weapon pack. Which was €5,- but contained 3 guns, 4 masks + mats and frag grenades. Not bad in itself, even though I thought frag grenades did not really make sense for a bank-robber in the first place.  Then came another weapon pack. And then a courier pack. And a sniper pack.  And then arrived Big Bank. €7,- for 1 gun, 4 masks + mats and 1 heist. Oh and a pre-planning feature.  So lets recap. Where we payed €6 for 6 heists(5 Armored Transport heists and 1 bonus mission), 4 Masks+mats, 3 guns, we are now paying €7,- for 1 heist, 1 gun and 4 masks+mats.  And then we got even more weapon packs. Then afterwards came the shameless cross-promotion with John Wick, which did not make sense in any way. Then a female heister, and then another heister. All of which cost money to even get. The total cost for all DLCs is €114,81.  Does that sound like a normal game? Not to me. Payday 2 has become the cash-milking cow for Overkill studios. Even now with the 'hype-train' where they encourage us to buy DLC so we can get even more (payed-)DLC.   The heists are still repetitive. The dynamic and high-speed feel of the first game is gone. It's still a bag-throwing simulator. As someone who enjoyed the feeling of completing heists, I now no longer feel joy in this when I have to shell out increasingly more money for increasingly less content.  All I can say is that the spirit of Payday to be, is dead.

The first one was more of a L4D experience that was about holding a place and surviving. But then the DLCs started coming out. (You must know the first game had just one DLC pack that gave you a character, a weapon, some masks, 2 heists and some skills so real bang for buck there) At first the DLCs were not great but added some fun features and even some free stuff like the Diamond store and the infamous update. But then they decided that that was not enough and Started dropping 1 char, 1 mask and some skin packs sure not great but you don't really needed that character to get anything you could get a new Heist for the same Price. But then they decided that the best weapons were going to be in the new DLC packs, and to add injury they started 'rebalacing' the base and old DLC weapons, that meant that unless you wanted to be severely underpowered you had to get the DLC packs. I want to preface this by stating that this review is meant to be for the game as a whole - not just pathetic whining about the recent inclusion of the microtransaction business model. It's not a top-tier game, but you could tell that the producers used to try very hard to make their game something to be proud of. Yet, despite all their preparation, the quality of the contents released were sub-par, full of bugs (e.g. teleporting the player's location out of map and turning them invincible), and simply disappointing. All communications with the community ceased, and the bugged and broken content still remains in the game. Some of these bugs are completely game-breaking, making the gaming experience unenjoyable, and completely unplayable, at worst.  I would have recommended it in the past, but now the devs appear to have given up on their game. Expect the quality this game to go downhill even faster than it currently is. We are already witnessing pathetic and desperate cash-grabs - not just from the addition of microtransactions in the game, but also from these frequent discounts of their products in an attempt to trick people to buy their game - and it is highly unlikely that it will get any better. If you purchase this game, expect to be treated as a revenue stream and not as a consumer by the developers. I have 20 hours and several more on top of that on friends' accounts, and while the game is fairly enjoyable to an extent, the business practices are not.  The reason I'm bringing the developers into my review is that this is a constantly expanding game: the developers are directly involved in ALL of your future enjoyment of the product. I can frankly say that my personal future enjoyment of this product was ruined thanks to the cash cow strategies that Overkill decided to employ after their first couple DLC.  To talk a bit about the game: Payday 2 improves upon the biggest flaw of the first: it feels much less repetitive with its branching missions and offering multiple means to an end during gameplay. The leveling up, while honestly a chore and more time consuming than anything, does add a bit of incentive towards playing the game. The perks offered through the leveling system, however, does make your heist life much easier. At launch, Payday 2 was a major improvement over Payday in every aspect, and it was an extremely enjoyable co-op game.  At some point in time, DLC became a requirement to get the full experience of Payday 2. Slowly, overpowered weapons trickled in. DLC-locked missions are understandable, especially considering how only the host needs to own them, so it would be unfair to complain about those. As overpowered weapons and similar DLC trickled in, I suppose something went off in the managements' eyes, and they decided that their revenue was more important than their game. Despite promising that no microtransactions would make it into the game, they made it into the game in high amounts. The developers' response to the (highly dedicated) community of the product was an arrogant 'the system, economically, is working as intended' or something along those lines. On a platform where consumer and developer communicate directly, they decided to treat customers by ignoring their concerns and when forced to reply, replying in 'PR speak' which wasn't well thought-out.

I've had great times with this game. Particularly with friends. A short while ago I would have recommended a purchase, but as you will probably have noticed by the other negative reviews out there, things have changed, and the game and the developers are not what they once were.   The Short Story   Payday 2 was uniquely profitable even before release, which lead to multiple updates and paid DLCs to flesh out and expand the content. Over time however things got worse, and now it's profusely obvious that this no longer a game, but rather an experiment in how much money a company can make from one product.   The Long Story   8 months ago Overkill announced the 'Hype Train Event', a community event where content for the game would be released, such as a new character and weapon mods, as long as certain 'goals' were met. Unlike previous 'Crimefest' events, these goals were directly tied to DLC sales. To expedite accumulation of 'hype fuel', Overkill released two fresh DLC packs, the 'Overkill' pack, and the 'Completely Overkill' pack. The Completely Overkill Pack was £15/$20, and 'limited', which meant that only 50,000 could be bought. The actual content of this pack was kept secret, apart from a skin for the escape van, and 4 in-game masks with particle effects.  We were told this secret would be cosmetic only, and lead to believe that it would be released in 'Spring Break', with the rest of the hype train content. Neither of these things were true.  The secret was 1 weapon skin, out of a possible 25. All 25 were ranked in terms of 'quality' and 'condition'. Meaning that there were common skins, and more rare (read: better), and even super rare 'legendary' skins. These had unique modifications unobtainable any other way. Which skin you got was determined by random chance. So yeah, some people will have got a super rare skin that looked great, with stat boosts, and 'team boosts', worth at least the initial cost of the Completely Overkill Pack on the steam market, whereas the majority got something worth approximately £1.  Not only that, it was random chance what 'condition' your skin would be in. This meant that the skin would appear worn and scratched. These textures for the most part made the skin look absolutely terrible.   I'm digressing a little here. What matters more than any of this disappointment, or misleading marketing, is the reaction to the feedback from the community concerning the fiasco. Almir, an executive producer and the general 'face' of Overkill, did an AMA on reddit. In it he basically said that according to their figures (i.e the money they're making from the steam market), the majority of the Payday 2 playerbase liked the update which added weapon skins.  I've seen comments from the Starbreeze shareholders concerning the new direciton Payday 2 is taking, and in summary, they believe that the players don't know what they want, and that ultimately whatever Overkill want to do to squeeze profits out of Payday is good with them.  Basically, the game is quite good, really fun actually. It has a few lingering bugs even after all these years and the engine is hella wonky, but it's enjoyable. There is way too much drama involved with it from here on out though. They will take and take and take, until everybody playing Payday 2 tells them that enough is enough. That won't happen though.

I'll preface this with saying that it's with bitter sadness and disappointment that I write this review. Payday 2 was a game I used to really enjoy but alas - no more. I'll explain for the uninitiated (briefly).  I bought Payday 2 on steam a year and a half to two years ago just after buying my first gaming PC. I'd come straight from Xbox 360 console land and was keen to try out one of my favourite games on that platform (despite the god awful graphics, glitches and atrocious performance) again except with all the up to date content, better graphics etc etc. Things were great at first, the game was a blast to play and Overkill seemed like good developers who were always 'down' with the gamers who enjoyed their game. Then things started to sour slightly.  The DLC. Ohhh the DLC. DLC if implemented correctly both content wise and pricepoint wise can be great and a welcome addition to the game. Unfortuately for us - the consumer - Payday 2's DLC was rarely ever those two things and in fact continues that shoddy trend to this day. Endless weapon packs, with progressively more ludicrous weaponary and dodgy masks - nearly all of which are locked behind silly achievement walls. That is only the start though. I won't bother going into much detail regarding the various (and many) faux-pas Overkill has made (there are thousands more reviews on steam with the details plus google is your friend but to put it simply - Overkill basically milks its user base for every penny all the while grinning the whole time.  Which has lead us to this point - microtransactions. the thing they said they'd never do. They did it. Unashamedly. No going back, here forever, like it or lump it microtransactions. Now, one of the reasons I used to love this game even back with the muddy visuals of the xbox 360 version was the atmosphere the game and its gunfights had. The ambience. Clearly the game takes (or rather took) a lot of inspiration from 'Heat' (great film by the way - check it out). However the seriousness of the vanilla game has basically been slowly erroded by terrible comedy DLC and now these weapon skin microtransactions. Because they have stat boosts linked to then I would HAVE to use them. I don't glean any enjoyment from pew-pewing with rainbow pink guns but that's what i'd have to do were I to continue with this mess of a game. So basically i'm not - i'm done. Forever.  Anyway i'm rambling so I will end it here. In closing I seriously can't recommend this game to anyone. Steer clear, your wallet will thank you.

The most upsetting part of Payday 2 is the direction Overkill decided to take during the later years of Payday 2's constantly updating development. The first set of Paid DLC practices weren't so bad- new heists, sick! New weapons, I suppose that's worth money, maybe! New characters? I never asked for this. But then at some point DLC became outrageous- too much money for too little content, and then the same formula just kept multiplying as time passed, with less content being added each time for the same price. When the microtransactions were implemented, it served as the last straw that even the veteran community of Payday 2 had with the game.   At it's core, it's a pretty fun game. Coop shooters are always fun, and Payday 2 had solid gunplay and gameplay mechanics. At launch, though, it was still quite fault and only had so few heists with little scope- level design of Payday 2 was to me it's weakest point. Coming from the Hollywood-style, grand, and massive heists the original Payday: The Heist had to offer, Payday 2 was very lacking in the level design department- with most of the maps being confined to a small area and having EXTREMELY repetitive objectives (Drill, Drill, DRILL! Pick up bag, throw back, pick up bag, throw bag!). For a game about heisting- each level did not feel grand at all, which is something you'd expect from a heist. Future DLC slightly remedied the Level Design issue by offering larger levels with more objectives and situations, thank goodness for that.  However, oversaturation of DLC lead to an imbalance of weapons and meta- with some playstyles being completely locked to DLC and some weapon-types like Sniper Rifles and Light Machine Guns being completely locked behind a playwall- not something you really want in any game. When the extremely unnecessarily addition of microtransactions occured, the game took a hit from the community. Indeed- it was an unwelcome change that only served to disrespect customers. Further business and community practices Overkill had partaken in had completely driven me and many others away from the game. I pick the game up every now and then to play with friends- but I always have a sour taste in my mouth when I play because of Overkill's recent practices. I have yet to play the new Point Break heists which I think look fun and Hollywood-inspired, however the greedy actions taken have just driven me away.

Payday two is a story of a game that, during the span of its popularity, squandered countless opportunities on its way to becoming an excellent game. More often than not, the devs would constantly choose to ignore problems with the game in favor of releasing more DLC and running ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ized 'community events' which were generally speaking player-driven ad campaigns. This was ok for a time, but in light of the most recent one of these community events, I've decided it's finally time to put the game down. TL;DR below, but if you plan on buying this game, I encourage you to read this first.  Flash back a few years. The game had good core gameplay and an interesting meta and slowly rose from a personal score of a passable C to an A that I would recommend to friends time and time again as the game evolved. I've even purchased the game at least once for a friend so we could enjoy it together.  Unfortunately, eventually the developer, Overkill, either misunderstood completely why their game was a success, or decided it was time to cash in once people were hooked. Enter nearly $100 dollars worth of DLC over the course of two years or so. Again, this was ok for a while. It was at least a matter of interest to follow how the DLC changed the meta for better or for worse. The playerbase rolled with the punches and kept hoping that eventually the developers would catch on to what an amazing chance they had to make a great experience for their players. This came to a head during the 2015 crimefest, or one of the many thinly veiled attempts to utilize player driven 'hype' to market the game.  Crimefest 2015 was supposed to be a free event for the players, rewarding them for their 'hard work' making the last crimefest a colossal success. What players got instead was a total weapon 'rebalance', devoid of any semblance of actual balance, some minor features labeled 'rewards' that were passable as minor patches, and the cherry on top: The ability to pay real-world money to gamble for weapon skins. Weapon skins which supplied stats. Stats on weapons that were significantly reworked to accommodate these skins.  Unsurprisingly, the vocal members of the community were upset.  The remainder of the week during crimefest, the playerbase remained vocal about this. They asked questions about why they had to pay microtransactions to receive benefit from their 'free' community update when it was claimed on multiple occasions that the game would never have microtransactions, and asked if any of their concerns would be addressed, all without hearing a single comment on the matter. Finally, at the end of crimefest, after each update had rolled out, the community got their answer.  Simply put, it was a resounding 'no'.  For future developers, please look back at this event and use this as an example of a complete and total failure to understand your playerbase and why they play your game. Either that or it was a total success if it was intended to cycle out their old meta-driven playerbase for a new, more lucrative gambling playerbase. It was shortly clear that Overkill was changing nothing.  TL;DR: my goal here is to say that this company and developer is no longer worth supporting. It is increasingly clear that this developer has been constantly exploiting its playerbase in the name of putting out a quality game, which on multiple occasions has proven to be a false claim. Goodbye overkill, it was fun while it lasted.

As someone with almost 400 hours in this game, and having played it for two years now, I know a bit about it.  The game started off very well. It was engaging and entertaining, the staff actually seemed to care about the playerbase (As it was smaller at the time) and the game was a fun way to spend an evening with friends. However over time OverKill has taken all the popularity to their heads, and is currently dragging what was once an enjoyable experience and pushing it to a lower level than the Mariana Trench.  The game, whilst being semi-enjoyable now, provides little to no challenge whatsoever. I can easily clear just about every mission without any problems on the harder difficulties. Rather than add new jobs, characters or other ways to enjoy the game, Overkill as started to smother what was once a burning flame in the gaming world, with microtransactions and buyable items that break the experience for everyone who doesn't have them.  When I purchased this game, I was very thrilled to have it. I got the DLC for it immediately, and spent countless hours completing heists either online or on my own. As time passed, DLC was added more and more frequently, and even though the purchases got slightly redundant after a while, I was still happy to give my money to a company who had shown to care for their playerbase. However I had noticed over time that, in fact, Overkill does not care about anyone or anything that may or may not play their title.  How have they done this? First of all is one of the most blatant of things, ignoring those with serious complaints or ideas, and listening only to those with praise and worship towards themselves. Boosting your ego is fine on occasion, but ignoring others with legitimate complaints isn't the way to go about things. The players in the community had done nothing but help and provide insight to the developers about things occuring, and what was enjoyed or not. Game developers who care for their buyers would typically listen to the masses and try to compromise, however Overkill leans towards those who would rather just throw money at them blindly. That's fine and all, abuse your buyers and take the money they give you, it's their fault I suppose.  From DLC once every so often, to boxes of microtransactions and rapid DLC being shoved down the throats of the playerbase, Overkill has let what was once a very enjoyable game slip down to a worthless piece of software with nothing redeemable about it anymore.  As a long time supporter of the game, until very recently, I am both shocked and appalled at the way Overkill has shifted their views and their ideas. It's not about the players anymore, it's not about the experience or the game, it's just the money to them. So, they will continue to flood us with mindless microtransactions and packs of useless cosmetics that break the game for the players who can't afford them. As they move forward with the game, missions will be made incredibly difficult, too compensate for the one shot one kill, full automatic assault rifle people can buy. Meanwhile people without said item will struggle to make any progress at all.  I am very dissapointed, and if I could demand a refund I would. But they'll ignore me, as they will anyone else with a concern about the game they've ruined, or anyone hoping to get even a bit of their wasted time back.  TL:DR Don't buy this game, please for the love of god. These developers don't deserve your money.  - KnyghtFalcon

The most upsetting part of Payday 2 is the direction Overkill decided to take during the later years of Payday 2's constantly updating development. The first set of Paid DLC practices weren't so bad- new heists, sick! New weapons, I suppose that's worth money, maybe! New characters? I never asked for this. But then at some point DLC became outrageous- too much money for too little content, and then the same formula just kept multiplying as time passed, with less content being added each time for the same price. When the microtransactions were implemented, it served as the last straw that even the veteran community of Payday 2 had with the game.   At it's core, it's a pretty fun game. Coop shooters are always fun, and Payday 2 had solid gunplay and gameplay mechanics. At launch, though, it was still quite fault and only had so few heists with little scope- level design of Payday 2 was to me it's weakest point. Coming from the Hollywood-style, grand, and massive heists the original Payday: The Heist had to offer, Payday 2 was very lacking in the level design department- with most of the maps being confined to a small area and having EXTREMELY repetitive objectives (Drill, Drill, DRILL! Pick up bag, throw back, pick up bag, throw bag!). For a game about heisting- each level did not feel grand at all, which is something you'd expect from a heist. Future DLC slightly remedied the Level Design issue by offering larger levels with more objectives and situations, thank goodness for that.  However, oversaturation of DLC lead to an imbalance of weapons and meta- with some playstyles being completely locked to DLC and some weapon-types like Sniper Rifles and Light Machine Guns being completely locked behind a playwall- not something you really want in any game. When the extremely unnecessarily addition of microtransactions occured, the game took a hit from the community. Indeed- it was an unwelcome change that only served to disrespect customers. Further business and community practices Overkill had partaken in had completely driven me and many others away from the game. I pick the game up every now and then to play with friends- but I always have a sour taste in my mouth when I play because of Overkill's recent practices. I have yet to play the new Point Break heists which I think look fun and Hollywood-inspired, however the greedy actions taken have just driven me away.

The problem isn't the game. The game is great.  The problem isn't the DLC. The DLC is fair.  But now that Overkill have reaped the benefits of a faithful community, and their help in turning Payday 2 into a huge succes, they've chosen to leverage all that trust and hard work, into selling people lottery tickets for imaginary products with no obvious value. Random boxes, which by design are intended to make people pay for a product, that isn't worth 10% of the asking price.  The premise of a crate lottery is this: 'Give us your money and you MIGHT get a product of the same value'. Mostly you won't. It's designed to make you pay 2.5 bucks for skins that cost 18 cents. That is the very definition of a scam.   Even if the vast majority of people are too smart to play, you're still golden.  It's an old trick, selling people an 'exciting' product they're not allowed to see before they pay, but sadly it's not a first for videogames - Valve does it too. CS:GO isn't offered for free either, and it obviously caters to a lot of kids, who probably don't realize they're being tricked.   It's really pretty amazing that Valve has succeeded in marketing a gambling product to kids, without any authorities taking note.  It's even more disgusting for the fact that those kids never have the chance to win any actual money. The best you can get is store credit, and you're never even afforded the agency offered to a poker player at an online casino. In this one, the house has already claimed your money the moment you buy in, and I don't know any casino for which that is actually true.  Most people would be quite ♥♥♥♥♥♥ if the croupier just ran away laughing. I guess gamers are just nice enough to look the other way.  Clearly though, Overkill couldn't give less of a ♥♥♥♥. They know all of this, that's why they're doing it. Just as you know that no one with half a conscience would ever want to earn a single buck this way.   Not even a Vegas casino, where kids aren't allowed, and you're at least afforded some chance to leave with actual money in your pocket.  Payday 2 may be a great game, it's certainly been one of my all time greats, but it's tainted both by this scam, and by the fact that the developers obviously don't care more about their baby, than to abuse it for the sake of such a scummy, low down trick.  To Amir and his fellow conmen - I wish you all the worst with your business. You've really earned it.

A mediocre followup to an unpolished diamond.  Payday 1 was good game, almost a great game. It had heart. It was a bit rough around the edges, but somehow you never got tired of playing the same levels over and over. Each level was distinct. Each weapon was different, fufilling a different role on the team. The action was tight, the mechanics good. Notably, Payday allowed the players to carry three guns instead of the usual two. There was a little DLC that was a welcome addition at a reasonable cost.  Payday 2 was a fundamental step backwards in design and stability. A random drop system was implemented that removed control from the player in upgrading the guns they liked. Glitches abounded, ruining stealth runs and in some cases by not synchronizing which way guards face, and punishing people with weaker computers by not generating the textures required to finish levels without brute guesswork. The game is stunningly poorly optimized, I am able to run Killing floor 2 at higher settings that this. Pages were taken from the middle COD series: Guns were added, seemingly for the sake of having them in the game, which contributed little but spreading out the time it took you to get attachments for the ones you like, and taking away the distinctness of each. Weapon catagories got blended together, and players are now only able to carry two at a time. There is now several times the cost of the game in DLC, most of it gratituious. The level design team from the first game presumeably is somewhere in the DC river, wearing size 10.5 concrete. Gone are the multiple city blocks of heat street, the variety of sizes and types of objectives found originally and instead the majority of the levels involve running into a building, setting up a drill and waiting. The Stat system is insane, and poorly explained. One of the popular mods simply added explanations, one would expect that if there was that much confusion the devs would add in an explaintion.  If you told me this was a cash grab by an unrelated company that bought the IP, I wouldn't be surprised.

TL;DR I got a bit of cleared vision, and looking back on the various things this game has done really highlighted some glaring issues that existed long before I gave up on the game.  This is my second most played game, next to Terraria. That right there should say a lot about what I thought. When I was actually playing and enjoying the game (and it is fun if you 'play along') I never really noticed the issues. When a new events started, I got more excited about reaching all the goals than stepping back and looking at some of the logic. Half of the event awards were bugfixes, and eveything that was not achieved would be sold as DLC. Weird, right? It's pretty bad business practice, but everyone also knew that the goals would be reached (in the end, mostly by bots and hackers). The events were mostly good, but looking back now they did a really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ thing with the Hypetrain event where it was literally fueled by money, preordering a DLC that probably wasn't even made yet. I actually didn't really notice how stupid this was until after I stopped playing and got a bit of clairovoyence on the subject. Like most people, I got really jarred by the addition of microtransactions (which are fine on their own but were horribly executed), partly because I payed so much money form getting every DLC they released. It didn't feel like it, but over time I had spent over $200 supporting them by buying their content, and I felt a bit betrayed.  This is where I get back to the 'playing along' bit. The game was okay on release, and was well balanced but with little content. The DLC fixed that, but the game has also been massively transformed. None of the base guns and mods are good by comparison to what you can get, and additions to the game assume that you already bought everything they ♥♥♥♥ out. My feelings for Payday are so mixed. I really enjoyed Payday: the Heist, and minus loving how the game played, was mostly disappointed with Payday 2 when it was first released (pre-ordered it). There wasn't that much content. They promised that they'd be updating the game for years to come so I wasn't worried about it, but the amount of PAY updates is insane for how base this game was when it came out. I paid like $40 for it at the beginning (I was a sucker, cause later it went on sale for nothing), but how much do I gotta put into this thing?  A lot apparently.  I have almost all (if not all?) the DLCs (granted, most of them were gifted to me -- but I feel bad that someone out there paid for them). Most of the DLCs are complete ♥♥♥♥. If you're going to come out with such a puny game, Overkill, why make it so expensive to play? From the getgo I feel like I was cheated out of the game I originally paid for.  Then they announced that there was going to be a female hesiter, and I lost my ♥♥♥♥. As a chick, yeah, I enjoy playing ladies in games. This is after they came out with the Hoxton character pack (for free). When the Hoxton Breakout heist and character came back, my faith in Overkill was (somewhat) restored. Great heist, free content, good EXP -- thank you so much Overkill this is what I was expected! And pretty soon I was going to get to play a lass, and that was exciting for me. But then it was announced that my ability to play as a girl was going to be a $5 DLC. WHAT. ♥♥♥♥. And I paid for it too, just for the novelty of getting to be a girl in the game. This is when I lost aaaaall faith that they'd redeem themselves for me. The issue of making a character pay2play is -- only 1 of each character is allowed in a game. The amount of times I've joined a game and Clover was already taken, meaning the whole reason I bought the DLC was unusable to me, was so frustrating. I'm a very particular gamer -- I don't like change, be it a flaw in my makeup or whatnot...but if I pay money because I want to be a specific character, and if I can't, that's really bothersome for me.  Fast forward to me picking this game up sporadically because I have friends who really love it. My love can't be that great because at this point, I don't feel comfortable supporting Overkill and their money-grubby DLC decisions. I will stress -- this game CAN be really fun and challenging. I've played in heists that I felt were really rewarding when I finished them, and I've enjoyed improving over how many hundreds of hours of gameplay I've accumulated. But is it worth it? Not really.  The fun doesn't last, in my opinion. This game gets so repetitive so fast, I feel like I've played each heist 10x more than I'd ever want to. The locations get old. I have friends with thousands of hours of play in this game and I don't know how that's possible -- for me, even after going on hiatus after hiatus, coming back to the game I still feel the 'ugh, not this one again' fatigue of the game.   But fast forward again to this microtransactions fiasco... and hooooo  I called it.  I've been ♥♥♥♥♥ing about Overkill being a greedy company for so long, and it just proves it. Even my friends who have defended them when I've complained about the number of $5 DLCs have agreed -- that this is just crap. It makes me happy to see the community turn on them, because unless they get the message then I only see it escalating. I thought Crimefest was supposed to be about rewarding their players, and they give us microtransactions like 'there you go, I hope you're proud of what you've unlocked'?  Nah. Overkill... you need to stop. Seriously. Your game isn't great enough to crap on your entire community like this.  Even before the microtransactions, I'd find it really hard to recommend this game, despite the fun I've had playing it (just because the base game is so weak, and I can't in good conscience recommend someone buy a game and then 5+ DLCs to make it playable). But the microtransactions is the nail in the coffin.  Don't buy this game. Overkill doesn't respect you, and will do anything to bleed as much money out of you. Give your money to someone else.

This was my most-played game on Steam, by far. It was a wonderful co-op FPS game with RPG elements that has been utterly ruined by greed, bad communication and worse management.   Up until October 15th, 2015, Overkill had stuck to their word that there would never be microtransactions in the game. Sure, they released a lot of DLC, especially for a buy-to-play game, but I bought it, because I wanted to support the company and I felt they had earned my money. I certainly got a lot of enjoyment out of it.   But requiring the playerbase to complete challenges to unlock supposedly 'free' content, only to turn around and have the leading features of the Crimefest event be microtransactions to gamble for skins that add stats, the same day they add a 'weapon rebalance' that gutted half the weapons in the game and made them nigh-unusable was a horrible move.   The fact that people have been clamoring for a weapon rebalance for literal years now with complete radio silence only made that worse.   The playerbase should NOT have to pay real money to gamble for a chance at a skin that might restore some of the stats they lost from their weapons with the weapon 'rebalance'. Period. End of story.   Especially not in a buy to pay game that, over the past year, has gotten less and less free content (something they pride themselves on) and more and more monthly DLC packs. DLC Packs with weapons and mods that were all hit incredibly hard by the weapon rebalance.   The addition of the Vault/Drill microtransactions as part of the 'free content' in Crimefest 2015 is the last straw for me. They will no longer be getting my business, I will no longer be recommending the game to my friends, and I sincerely hope that anyone that reads this review will not contribute player numbers to a game that Overkill seems determined to drive into the ground.

If you ever want to know how NOT to treat the people who play your game, take some notes from Overkill and PAYDAY 2.   For quite awhile PAYDAY 2 was my go-to game. Whether I could only play for an hour or I had all day, I almost always found myself playing it. However, over the past few months that has changed. Yes, PAYDAY 2 has had a ton of DLC over the years. Most of which have all been very well made and well worth the prices they ask for, especially when they are almost always on sale during the big Steam sales for 50% off. I was more than happy to support the developers that I felt had the community's best interests in mind. That all changed almost overnight.   From a business standpoint, it makes sense to add micro-transactions. They're completely optional, and if done right they do not change gameplay in any way besides cosmetically. They can also bring you a ton of income if you have a big community. Counter-Strike Global Offensive, for example, handles micro-transactions perfectly. When they're handled right, they're good in both a business and consumer standpoint.   This, unfortunately, is not the case with PAYDAY 2. They decided it'd be a good idea to add a similar system of micro-transactions that CS:GO has, but the weapons obtained from the crates would have stat boosts for either the weapon or your team. While Overkill has admittedly switched up and made the system better, they still felt it would be nice to add them despite them saying in the past they would never add such things to their game. Adding them to the game is one thing, making them so obviously pay-to-win is another.   To add insult to injury, they released a 'Goat Simulator' DLC which is not only a major cash grab which lacks much of any content, but further progresses PAYDAY's deep descent to being nothing more than a 'meme game'.   Is PAYDAY 2 a good game overall? Absolutely. I'd also recommend it to you if you can get it when it's on sale along with a few DLC. However I have lost all faith in the developers to pump out quality content in the future after their recent actions. Based on that, I cannot leave a good review.

Please, don't buy Payday 2. I should say before I get into this that I genuinely think Payday 2 is a fun, enjoyable game. Which, I suppose, makes writing this all the more difficult.   Watching the game go down this path is painful, to say the least. Imagine a grandparent, slowly succumbing to dementia. You know it's not going to stop, that it'll ultimately get worse and worse until its inevitable death. That is the feeling i get from this game.  Payday 2, as a game, is a very solid co-op fps. Guns feel nice, and it doesn't look like last week's mexican take-out come back to haunt me. The maps vary in quality (There are more than a few maps that are essentially clones), but they are relatively enjoyable.  But here is where the true ♥♥♥♥ness lies. Two words. Or one word? Or a compound word? Whatever it is, it's Microtransactions. Now, to say the microtransactions are the only glaring issue wouldn't be right. But it's the biggest issue. A while back, i forget when exactly, the devs said that there'd be no microtransactions. Even going so far as to say 'shame on you' to those who thought otherwise.   And what do you know? Here they be. And ♥♥♥♥ they be. They took a page from the book of CS:GO. Lo and behold, weapon skins, which themselves I don't care about. But they did something vile: stat boosts. The weapon skins have stat boosts. To be fair, they can now be obtained for free,  but good ♥♥♥♥in luck with that.    And you know what's just great? Even if you pay for the key, you may still need to pay more! That's right, not only would you need to spend $2.50, but if you get a weapon skin for a DLC weapon, you get to pay for the relevant DLC pack if you ever intend on using it!   And whjat would a Payday 2 review be without mentioning that DLC! Sure, you can play any of the DLC heists provided somebody invites you, but if you want to access the sniper rifle, rocket launcher, or grenade launcher weapons, you'll be shelling out a bit of cash. And they pump those suckers out every other month it seems, so you'll have quite the choice in what you'll be spending your hard-earned cash on. Of course, this was an issue long before the weapon skins, but the weapons add the moldy cherry on top of this rotten fish and coffee ground sundae.  I'm honestly more disappointed in this than I have been for any other game. I loved this game. I had so much fun, but now? I can't say I could ever recommend it. Let's say they remove the skins, the stat boosts, I couldn't ever trust the developers again. The lying, the moneygrubbing, it's left a bad taste I feel can never be washed out.

I wanted to love this game, I really did. Ever since Payday: The Heist came out, I said that this was a fantastic idea... Sadly, both the developers and the community are in such a toxic state right now that this is unplayable.  I got this game during the free week, played it amongst a myriad of other new players and I loved it. After that, I decided to buy it. I had to buy the GOTY edition since the sheer amount of DLC meant that I was missing on 70% of the content otherwise (which should never happen ever. Developers, this is a good way to tell if your business model is appropriate). I made a few friends during the free week and couldn't wait to play with them.  Upon firing the game, after going through the basic tutorial (and after being shoved in your face how awesome the new DLC pack is, through a cutscene) you'll be greeted with the possibility of customizing your gear. 70% of the weapons will be behind paid DLC walls and some other guns will become available once you join the Payday 2 community... This is the equivalent of a clickbait title on a Youtube video, to put it some way. You can still play the game without DLC, but you won't be able to even do some heists. Plus, any new weapon customization you want must be acquired through random drops after every heist.  Let's skip all of that and say that you join a game. Even as a Lv. 1 player, assuming that you don't get kicked instantly, you are expected to know to perfection the most efficient way of doing the heist and the most efficient gear to bring. If you don't, you'll be subject to being cursed, insulted and kicked. Possible death treats are also a thing.  'Well, surely that's something that happens everywhere when you play with randoms' well, no... This community has gone so down that even playing with some of the guys that joined during said free week, those 'friends' of mine, has gotten me a barrage of insults after I brought one piece of kit that wasn't adequate for the heist in question.  On top of that, now you can pay microtransactions to get some new stuff.  I really wanted to love this game, I wanted to have some fun time heisting, killing cops, taking civilians, succeding and failing at it. Sadly, it looks like failing isn't an option, or underperforming at all. (And before I forget, I had to tweak the game's configuration through the NVidia Configuration Tool to get it to run smoothly).

Alright, I deleted my previous review, to type out a new one in place of it for the ♥♥♥♥♥torm that is the Hoxton's Housewarming Party event. So everyone knows they added new difficulties, Mayhem (which comes after Overkill and before Death Wish), and One Down (the most difficult of all the difficulties). Now, I like that they are still adding more to the game after all this time. Overkill listens to their fanbase for the game. What makes me not recommend this is how it seems like NOTHING is ever playtested. The new difficulties are difficult as hell, but not because of smart A.I. or advanced tactics, but because of enemies gaining a HUGE increase in health and damage. This mainly affects Mayhem, Death Wish, and One Down (especially One Down). Mayhem is like a mini Death Wish, not as difficult as Death Wish, but harder than Overkill. HOWEVER, it is extremely difficult to kill even the basic assault wave enemies without going for the overpowered skills, which right now are the converting skills such as Joker Aced and Partner in Crime Aced, which make converted cops extremely difficult to kill, allowing them to act as bullet shields for you. Converted cops can take around 500 shots from enemy cops for some damn reason. Another overpowered skill is Body Expertise, which allows for a percentage of headshot damage to be applied to bodyshots. This is another part that pisses me off. Body Expertise's formula is utterly broken, allowing you to do 4x damage on bodyshots compared to 2x headshot damage on One Down. I know I was just talking about Mayhem, but for a good comparison, I had to go to One Down. One Down, the toughest difficulty in the game right now, is... unbalanced as all hell. Cops take quite a few shots to kill even with Body Expertise. Zeal Team, the new units used against you, have INSANE damage. A single Zeal Team enemy, a basic rifleman, is able to down you in around 3-5 shots from their assault rifle. Combine this with approximately 20 Zeal Team enemies at once, and you won't even get to blink before you are downed. The Zeal Dozers are especially well known for doing this, as 2 shots from them can down you no problem. I found this out AFTER I played Boiling Point on One Down, which was for the most part unchanged in difficulty from the original Death Wish difficulty for some reason. Russian mercenaries did very little damage compared to Zeal Team, even the Russian Dozers were pushovers compared to Zeal Team riflemen, and I completed Boiling Point with no issue, which caused me to be surprised by the other heists. And now, I shall state what I think is a sin. As of now, we have yet to get the new Safehouse, which was supposed to be released as an update today. It has NOT come out yet, and there is already a stream goin on waiting for the Day 3 update. It makes me somewhat livid, but as long as the Day 2 update does not come out on Day 3, then I am willing to forgive this.  Long story short, game is a mess right now, give Overkill some time to iron out the wrinkles and balance the scales. The new difficulties will be rebalanced as Overkill said at some point later, hopefully either during the Housewarming Party event, or shortly after it.
