The Sims of shooters.  The game builds on a simple set of well-designed fundamentals. And even though this is what makes the game so fun, it's also what limits it from being something better. The content that comes out has little diversity, and you can be pretty sure that in any DLC that comes out, the content in it is limited to two sets of things: guns and masks, or a heist, guns and masks. This means that even if Overkill makes new content for months to come, you'll eventually run tired of the repetitve gameplay.  It would seem that Overkill's solution to the above problem is to redefine the PAYDAY 2 formula every now and then. Monthly core gameplay overhauls aren't unusual, and while they do contribute in keeping things fresh, they eventually become extremely tiring. Having to learn the game you've already spent hundreds of hours on all over isn't fun.  The only redeeming quality of the game in its current state is its incredible sound design. PAYDAY 2 set a new standard for sound design when it released, and I'd say it still rocks the throne. The gun sounds are amazing and really help with the immersion, and the voice acting is great. The absolutely best part, however, is the soundtrack. It is easily one of the best I've heard in a very, very long time. Sadly, Simon Viklund, who was responsible for the soundtrack, left Overkill a while back.  The DLC is what makes this game truly disappointing, though. Thumbs up to Overkill for providing tons of free content, but that simply doesn't change the fact that a massive part (probably even up to half) of the game is behind a paywall. I won't comment on the recently included microtransactions beyond how I believe it to be another step in the wrong direction. Overkill's business practices are becoming increasingly dirtier, and the incredible contact with the community they had while they were still working on the original PAYDAY game is long gone. PAYDAY 2 has turned into The Sims of shooters.  While Overkill did a good job making a fun, enjoyable game, they've run the game into the ground. Several times. The core gameplay is constantly being altered, making it tiring to play. The countless updates have provided this game with an incredible amount of content, and although some is free, a massive part of the game's content is behind the paywall. PAYDAY 2 could be something incredible, but it turned into a sad story.
Unfortunately the company behind this game (Overkill) decided to turn a perfectly good and high quality game into a pay-to-win microtransaction crates, keys and skins (with stats)-copy of CS:GO.

On release, a fun game with a few issues and some wonky balance, but also some great, challenging co-op.  Years later, you have a game with a relentless onslaught of lower and lower DLC quality, constant balance creep, and still no fixes for gameplay problems that have existed since day one.  And finally now, after asking the community to complete challenges for free content, after advertising the 'completely free' nature of this for literally months, after promising several times never to add microtransactions in any way (even going so far as to MOCK the person who asked the question), the first 'free' content released for the big, heavily-advertised event was a CS:GO/TF2 style case/crate system that costs $2.49 per crate to open. And inside the crates: weapon skins that improve the statistics of the guns they go on. And they 'rebalanced' the guns at the same time. And they added Steam Workshop support so they don't even have to do their own art for the skins.  There was literally not a single free thing about it.  Microtransactions are fine. Especially for a coop game, small stat-altering bonuses shouldn't have been a big deal. But the constant, blatant, unrelenting dishonesty makes clear that the developers have long since stopped caring about the game or the community, and care only about how much money they can extract from you.  There is admittedly a pretty fun game buried in this pile of increasingly poor DLC, increasingly bad grind, unfixed bugs, and increasingly poor balance, but it isn't worth supporting a company like this.  Give this one a pass at any price, with any sale. The game in its current state isn't worth letting companies like this think they will be rewarded for acting so unscrupulously.  Not recommended.

Payday 2 has a lot of problems  The game is a well disguised grind-a-thon under the guise of a heist game. In reality, there isn't much heisting to do. The game plays unlike anything else I've ever played. It's your average FPS with skill trees changing how you tackle waves of police and SWAT as almost all of the 'heists' are 'loud' and the stealth ones that do exist can go sour very easily with a single slip up, which you WILL be experiencing if you play pubs.  Unlocking anything and eveything is a confusing nightmare. The game is 50% grinding the same missions and 50% RNG for getting the drops you want, like mods or masks. The heists get old very quickly and the empty 'Infamy' Mechanic pads out the boring gameplay for many more hours to come.  Despite all this, I would reccomend Payday 2, it's a game everyone should experience at least once because despite being a very cookie cutter FPS it does so many things differently and has many many layers of depth in terms of customisation. The DLC, while aggressive, is fun and usually non-neccesary. I've played up to about level 100 and I've enjoyed pretty much most of my time. Do you like games like League of Legends where rounds can last up to 40 minutes? This is the FPS equivalent. Teamwork is key, and honestly most people you will find are competent at this game enough for everyone to have a good time and make some good money doing what heisters do best: Stealing.  Don't buy all the DLC, you don't need it. Overkill are a shady company with dodgy practices and it's clear how green their horns are, they have a long way to go. Much like Gearbox, they're milking their winning series for everything they can get. But hey, at least they're trying. Few games on PC have support as good as this, come and join the fun.  The community may be a little on the young side and sometimes can be toxic, but you will make some good memories in this game.

Overkill got a little too into it and became robbers themselves, charging for stat - boosting weapon skins and essentially turning Payday 2 into a pay2win microtransaction-fest.    Edit: A Eulogy for PAYDAY 2    Overkill have gone on record stating that the stat - boosted weapon skins are here to stay. And with that, I am never playing this game again.   It's been a long time coming, what with the weekly DLC releases. 80% of the game's content is already behind a paywall. Microtransaction weapon skins are just the final nail in the coffin.   I loved OVK and PD:TH so much that I supported PAYDAY 2 before its release, pre - ordering and playing the beta. I spent countless hours with my friends throwing coke into the ocean, getting plowed by bulldozer-senpai, setting the dance floor ablaze, getting Vlad his sparkly tiara, adding HCl at the wrong time and blowing up the meth lab, and getting into all sorts of other laughable, fun situations.   At first, the updates were good and meaningful. Weapons were rebalanced, heists were fixed and added, and adjustments were made.  After a while, however, I began to feel apprehensive about the updates. OVK seemed to be putting out more and more DLC, while certain promised features went unfulfilled (safehouse customization, anyone?).  I continued to play the game, though. It was just so damn fun. I even bought some of the DLC packs, here and there. I wanted to help support a game I enjoyed so much.  Eventually, though, it got to a point where I couldn't enjoy the game anymore. OVK's already questionable business practices had devolved into some 'hype train' circlejerk which, as the name implies, involved building massive amounts of hype within the community for more hollow features while selling  special limited edition  shít overpriced DLC.  If you're going to play PAYDAY 2 in 2015, you should expect: -Microtransactions -DLC -Pay2Win game format -Lies from OVK -A community that eats all of the above out of OVK's hands -Disappointment  To be fair, OVK does provide a fair amount of free content to its players. This comes with the massive downside of joining the official PD2 group on steam, however. You'll get some admittedly nice free content in your game, but in exchange you'll have your steam activity feed spammed literally every day with NEW DLC COMING SOON or CRIMEFEST DAY 763 or BUY THIS ALIENWARE MACHINE AND GET A GLOWY MASK!!!11  I used to enjoy Payday 2 so much. I want to still like it, but I can't.   It feels hollow. Empty. Dead.  R.I.P. PAYDAY 2 goodnight sweet prince  Here's where I'd say something about OVK losing a customer, but they don't care. Well then, this'll be my first review so take it with a grain of salt if it lacks quality. Before you buy this game, you must make sure that you are a PATIENT person, this game CAN ♥♥♥♥ you off with the amount of weird deaths, cheaters, DLC.   DLC: This game has a lot of DLC , like, two Steam pages. This game is fun with it's DLC and the DLC are mostly worth it. If you lack money, you might want to wait for a Steam sale like the one going on right now. Anything that gets you a new weapon or a map is worth it in this game. But it will be expensive without the steam sale, that's for sure. It's a never-ending cycle of you heisting in banks and other missions and Overkill heisting in your pocket.   Combat: This is where the game gets fun, the combat is fun as you mow through the cops with your arsenal of weapons. BUT... The A.I. is not that bright, the cops will outnumber you to overwhelm you instead of outwitting you. Same goes for your friendly A.I. , they are not smart at all. Want an explosive shotgun to stun the cops and get out of a tight situation while also sniping with a shotgun or mowing everything down with a minigun (or LMG) ? That can happen with the very low price of ... Nevermind, not going for a DLCDAY joke here. Plus, according to this game, America's population is 98% SWAT units,1% civillians and 1% heisters.  Stealth: It is very rewarding but it will destroy you from the inside. Seriously, the frustration in stealth is outstanding! Detection Risk of 3 which is the lowest (best) in the game? Well, too ******* bad, everyone has eyes behind them, except you. Hell, even on top of their heads. You will be spotted for very silly reasons such as: Broken glass? CALL THE ENTIRE ARMY Heard some random drill? Oh god, they are robbing the bank even though it can be any random drill! Heard a SAW? RUUUN , SCREAM AND SHOUT, LET IT ALL OUT. (lel) Put a beard on? Shoot him/her. Call the damn Swat force. All of it. Now. Put a mask on? Shoot him/her. Call the damn Swat force. All of it. Again. Put glasses on? You got the idea. Same with hats and anything else. Saw a random gym bag? Help, they killed someone/they are robbing us! Et  cetera.  Economy/Grinding: Well, I've never had issues with money in the game and I am Infamy IV which is a high level (not that high after Infamy 2.0 came out) . Leveling is a grind indeed. But the real grinding is finding weapon parts, masks, colours, materials. So much grinding for those. If you don't play with mods, that is.  Customisation: Weapons: Lots of customisation options for every weapon. (Well, nearly every weapon, looking at you, Mosconi.) You'll need to find every damn part though, hard to get, again, grindy game is grindy. Masks: TF2 is the hat simulator. Payday 2 is the mask simulator. Masks are like Pokemon, you ''Gotta Wear Em' All!''. Some members of the community even get ideas about your skill level by looking at your mask. Silly. You can further customise your masks with patterns,materials, colours. Which requires RNG drops, which requires grinding. Yaay, grinding. No, just no.  Modding: Even though people seem to dislike modders/modding in this game, modding is what makes it better. Hud mods will help you a lot while playing on public matches where people don't communicate much most of the time. For example, Hoxhud, one of the most popular mods in the game, lets you track the amount of bags,pagers,guards,civillians, collectables that are on the current map. Plus, you get ''PushToInteract'' . Goonmod aka Goonhud , it is customisable so you can disable things in it if you want. I don't want to advertise but people mistake these mods for ''cheats''. Goonhud lets you do things like making the game harder (for fun), increase corpse count, rainbow lasers for your weapon,a trading system and it can also completely wipe-out depending on RNG. Yes, you canget mods that you want without depending on RNG. It adds a special currency in the game and stuff. Yeah, enough talking about modding.  Security... ? : Peer to peer connection, the only thing the game does against cheaters is putting a CHEATER tag on them and making them unable to play with players that don't want cheaters in their lobbies. You can play with whoever you want, cheating is okay in Payday 2 unless you use it to ruin people's experience, kill them, or brag about masks/weapons/achievements that you did not earn. Don't play with cheaters if you don't want to, play if you want, keep it fair, don't be an ******* .   Community:  Great if you find people to play with. Other than that, full of people who whine about everything in the game. Failed mission because of you? OMG YOU SUCK SO MUCH. Deathwish mask? HACKER. Overkill mask? Hacker? Came to the end of a heist? Cya, our friend is coming. *kicked before getting the rewards* You'll end up seeing lots of foreign language speakers as well.   Legend: +=good -=bad /=medium Final Verdict: COMBAT + STEALTH + ECONOMY/ COMMUNITY / SECURITY + DLC + MODDING + CUSTOMISATON + A.I. - FUN +  8/10 because of the A.I.  I highly recommend this game, you'll have lots of fun AND frustration at the same time. Message me + add me as friend if you need help with the game.   PS: Sorry for the extra long review of DLCDAY.. *cough* Payday 2. But it's a fun game worth your money and you'll get the bang for your buck. You guys remember the golden days of payday? OVERKILL takes a chance on a mob shooter with interesting characters, proffesional standards from said characters, and absolutely INSANE ides and escapes on heists? Well, that payday is gone.  When this game first came out it was a beautiful update to an amazing game. The money became real and spendable (even though you lose most of it to an offshore account), the masks became art pieces, the guns became modular, and everything felt new and exciting. You went through your first run of every heist loving the uniqueness of the missions and hopefully enjoying it with your friends. Then you started to notice a few things were pretty similar to one another...most missions are throw bag in van then hop in van, where as opposed to the original where you had to attach a chinese guy to a plane flying by, then scuba dive away or gather blood samples from some dude in a hospital who slowly transforms into a zombie then escape in one of a few different ways while military jets shot at said hospital. But you let it fly because some are really interesting. Then you start seeing little packages pop up everywhere and think 'Wow! These are cool I wonder what they do!' So you get a dlc pack thats relatively cheap and start getting Gage upgrades. Fast forward through your first playthrough and you get infamy and just think 'Wow.....these are getting old and I'm amazing at every heist.' You've done every heist on its hardest difficulty, Bulldozers dont even make you flinch anymore when it used to make you cower in fear when someone called it out in the original. Fast forward about 2 years after the release, the game becomes a bloated dlc monster with over 40 dlcs and becomes a money maker rather than a good game. You look back at all the greatness that was the original with its fun heists, tough enemies, and unique experience that made you (hopefully) cry in laughter and fear as a great heist goes completely out the window because a bulldozer runs in and knocks down your friend and you think on your feet to get him back as bullets fly around you. Every heist made you feel like a professional robber, wearing a suit a tie and taking out cops with deadeye precision right until a shield ran in first and made you panic and run. Even though there were no more than 10 heists, every heist came at you differently and made you feel amazing. Then you come back and see whats its become...

Movies tell us the life of a successful criminal needs to be free from attachment. Unless you want to end up doing a dime in last season’s orange jumpsuit, don’t cozy up to anything you can’t drop in thirty seconds when you smell those handcuffs coming around the corner. Being a crook in Payday 2, however, requires some social ties: three friends, or a couple of acquaintances with solid internet connections, at the very least. If you can muster up a motley crew with a few mics, you’ll have a thoroughly enjoyable avenue for pulling off intricate, replayable heists and amass all the riches and weapons that bank-robbing, art-thieving, drug-running, and meth-making can net you.  Just like the original Payday, this sequel pits four career criminals against a vault or a stash, and most certainly an absurd number of well armed but dim-witted boys in blue. You and your fellow co-conspirators begin most levels casing the joint, walking around sans masks, trying to pick out scores and potential liabilities.

Overkill has repeatedly broken promises. They directly said before release 'We will not ever have microtransactions.' And last month, October 15, 2015, they added Microtransactions. This game is not Free to Play with microtransactions. This game is not cheap at all actually. This game has a reasonably priced base game with 100€ of DLC. In order to purchase this game with all DLC, you must pay 130€ outside of a sale. On top of this 130€ price tag are microtransactions. Just think about that.  Some years ago, there were a series of 'what's next' audio files hinting at something. After a *month* of daily audio files being released, it culminated in an advertisement for another game that isn't released until 2016 and an in-game baseball bat.  Next year, we had 'Crimefest,' where the top reward Overkill was to release was a mystery. This mystery ended up being John Wick. A movie tie-in they were going to make and release anyway.  Next year, some of the rewards for Crimefest were 'FBI Files' (in-game stats), and a new enemy. These weren't released until this year. The FBI files ended up being a re-implementation of a community web page, and the new enemy ended up just being a bunch of shields standing in a circle.  This year, Overkill did a 'Hype Train' event. By pre-ordering DLC, we would get 'hype-fuel' points. With enough 'hype-fuel,' rewards for the community would be unlocked. In order to boost sales, Overkill finally delivered on a promise of finishing their new prestige levels (called Infamy). The first five infamy levels provided very small gameplay benefits along with awesome in-game masks. The next 20 levels released in Infamy 2.0 provided new masks and experience point bonuses (so you can infamy....faster?). Well I'm rude, there are achievements...  I call this 'Mask Pack 2.0.' It took Overkill *14 months* to release this. In response, people started refunding their DLC pre-orders. In response to THAT, Overkill released the DLC early so no one could get refunds. The latest Hype-train reward has yet to be released. In response to this, I completely stopped buying DLC and I told all my friendlist to stop gifting me new DLC, I don't wanna support this anymore.  And most recently, Overkill added microtransactions after explicitly saying that they will NEVER do that along with intentionally breaking extremely well made community mods. Overkill does not deserve your money. They have repeatedly broken their promises and insulted the community.  Overkill, shame on you. You've truly shown that you are nothing but liars and cheats.

Note: I did not play this game at all before the big 100th update so I was not exposed to whatever problems the game had before then.    Overall, Payday 2 is a really fun experience, especially with friends. There is a lot to do and the game is full of content even though people like to argue that. The base game will give you way more than 20 hours of enjoyment if you like team-oriented FPS games. So, in my opinion, this game is worth the asking price but it goes on sale a lot which is even better.   In case you're still on the wall over buying this I'll give you a breakdown of my experience so far.   Pros:    Amazing gameplay. Very fun especially with friends you can chat with. Everything feels pretty solid and there are MANY approaches to each of the heists. It's a little complicated at first but it's easy to get used to. If you're looking for many hours of fun for your dollar, this is an excellent place to put it.    Lots of levels. There is a lot of variety in the base game and pro versions of most heists which keep me interested so far. You can always play the DLC heists with your friends if they have it which is a plus.    Pretty good customization. When I do get colors and masks I have a lot of fun customizing them and it's awesome. It's even possible to get weapon skins and such but they are a bit more rare.    Randomized parts of certain heists. Even though most heists are replayed a bunch, lots of stuff changes so you can still strive to beat a heist perfectly with a hint of randomly placed objects and people.    Balanced equipment. Most of the weapons and items in the game seem like they can hold you in most situations so you never really feel underpowered unless you bring the complete wrong equipment. The game gets easier as you learn what you are doing in each heist but I never really feel overwhelmed anymore. Later stage weapons and perks make you much better and makes the game more enjoyable.    Cons:   Expensive in game items. Not like micro transactions but many in game items cost too much in my opinion. Later on its pretty easy to acquire cash so I guess it's not such a big deal but you have to pay for pretty much everything. Coloring your mask, applying patterns, adding attachments, stuff like that. And it doesn't stay usually. As in, if I buy an attachment for my gun, I have to pay to attach it every time if I ever take it off. Kinda silly in my opinion. Same with mask colors and masks but if you take a mask out of your equip, you basically have to sell it unless it's a special mask.   Dumb A.I. sometimes. Your partners are crappy at doing their job if you're playing with less than 4 people and you can't really command them to do anything useful. Not a big deal since this seems to be a team game anyways.    Poor solo experience. I am mostly a solo player but this game isn't too fun solo for me. I now play with my friends only because solo is very hard. Not all the time but most of the time. Solo is usually only fun if you know exactly what you're doing and have it all planned out. It's also better to be stealthy when doing solo.    DLC. There's too much DLC obviously. I mean, some of them are cool and you can always just join someone else who has the heists but there's just a lot to look at when it comes to the extra paid stuff. I hate seeing that I can't unlock something because it's DLC so I'll probably eventually get it all but very slowly and only when it's on sale. There's only about 3 or 4 DLC you probably really want anyways and they go on sale for about $1 pretty often. Just pick up that stuff on sale. I mostly just do it for the customization unlocks anyways. For the most part though, I don't see myself spending much on extra stuff anyways because the main game is so fun.     All in all, this is really a great game. It had a downfall at one point but it seems to be making up for it in a great way. I really love this game so far and can't wait to play even more with my friends.   9/10

When people say 'crime in a videogame', the first game that pops up in someone's head is likely 'Grand Theft Auto'. But just behind GTA is PAYDAY 2, a cooperative first person shooter with packed with both flaws and hours of fun.  Story: There actually isn't much story to PAYDAY 2, but I'll cover some of the plot at least. The game takes place in Washington D.C., and players take on the role of one of multiple heisters, from the former Chicago mobster Dallas, to the crooked Interpol agent Dragan and even to cinematic hitman John Wick, who cameos in the game as a playable character. (Although, he isn't voiced by Keanu Reeves.)  Gameplay: Gameplay is somewhat similar to most first person shooters with notable differences. The game is less about killing everything in sight and more about working together to complete objectives, weither it's sticking up a jewellry store or looting the deposit boxes from various banks across the city. In these heists, you use various moddable weapons ranging from assault rifles to shotguns and droppables from ammo bags to sentry guns. The game also discourages killing civillians, as when you kill one of them, weither on purpose or by accident, a small amount is taken out of the final cut as a penalty. After completing a heist, each member is issued experience points, money and a PAYDAY, where you choose from 1 of 3 cards to obtain either more money or unlockable safes containing skins for your weapons. The game also adds in a healthy dose of RPG elements, Inbetween heists, you use skill points to upgrade your skill tress and give new abilities like increased weapon accuracy with certain weapons and increased charges on your droppables. You also don't need to go in guns blazing all the time. Some heists actually require you to do things quietly with silenced weapons and hiding the bodies.  Downsides: As mentioned before, PAYDAY 2 has both flaws and fun. For one thing, the AI on both your friends and enemies is extremely stupid, with enemies relying more on superior numbers as opposed to tactics. Another problem is the players. If the host disconnects, the heist automatically fails, no matter how far you got. Also, most of the good weapons and characters are locked behind somewhat overpriced DLC, so I reccommend buying the GOTY edition on sale to make decent progress.  Verdict: I'd reccommend PAYDAY 2 if you buy the GOTY edition when on sale and you play with friends, otherwise you'll need to team up with random players and hope they know what they're doing.

I don't normally write reviews for games, however I feel compelled to review this game for anyone who is considering buying it and is looking for info before they do. If you want in-depth analysis of the gameplay/graphics/sound/etc, this is not the review for you. This is a BUYER BEWARE warning about the state this game has come to be in since most of the positive reviews were written. It is also a careful analysis of the direction the development team have taken the game in the last year and change and what that means for the future of the game. This is not going to be short. If you don't feel like spending several minutes reading a whole lot of detail about the history of a video game, keep scrolling. Otherwise, buckle in. I'll try to be as succinct as possible and assume no prior knowledge of the history of the game.  I have played Payday 2 for nearly 700 hours. If I had reviewed this game a year ago, I wouldn't have been able to recommend it enough. It has been a ton of fun, especially with friends. The difficulty levels provide adequate degrees of challenge depending on the competency of the crew from ridiculously easy to ridiculously hard. The achievements provided an added layer of meta-challenge for those times when I got bored with normal play. Progression was satisfying - a veteran player was a huge asset to the team, while new players required extra help from the team to make it through. The game rewarded players for learning the nuances and finding the 'best' way to complete objectives. New content was added at fairly regular intervals. Some was free, some was paid. All of it was quality content that enhanced the game, and I happily bought all of it.  Something changed.  I'm not sure when the change began. Maybe it was right around the first anniversary of the game's launch (Crimefest 2014). A whole bunch of free content was added to commemorate 2 million players joining the official Steam group. This new content was fairly well received, but I think the way the community came together to support the game set a bad precedent with the developers.  Future content became less and less about enhancing the game and more about adding content for its own sake (or for the sake of revenue. Power creep with new DLC weapons and items made the game easier for people who bought the DLCs, making the progression faster and less meaningful. The prestige system was overhauled to provide more grinding for the sake of grinding. Meanwhile fewer and fewer new heists were added, with the developers focusing more and more on weapon packs and character packs instead of heists.  The there was the 'Hype Train' event. This was similar to Crimefest 2014, except that instead of just joining a group, players had to buy exclusive DLC packages to 'fund' the event and unlock rewards for the whole community.  Hype Train left a bad taste in my mouth for several reasons.  1: Some of the free content that was promised during Crimefest had not been released yet. It was kind of weird that the developers were having another community event so soon without following through on the things that were promised during the last event.  2: The event advertised that the new content that was unlocked would be 'free' for the whole community, but the purchase of paid DLC was required in order to unlock the content. The exclusive content was extremely overpriced, with the justification being that it was exclusive (it wouldn't be sold again after the event), and it was overpriced on purpose because buyers would be supporting the event. Kind of weird to make the most loyal fans of the game support free content for less loyal fans... Luckily I saw through the bullcrap and didn't buy it.  3: Some of the images used to tease the 'free' content were actually images for upcoming paid content, with the free content being different stuff released much, much later. It was essentially a bait and switch to get people hyped and buy DLC.  So hopefully you can see why the Hype Train event really set the community on edge. Fans felt like their support and goodwill was a commodity that could be cashed in by the developers.  Future DLCs were much less interesting. Things were added that were completely game-breaking (such as the RPG, which has ludicrous griefing potential and is also completely OP) or just straight upgrades from existing DLC packs or core content.   I began to play the game a lot less. I still enjoyed it but it was really discouraging to see how easy it had become with the overpowered new content. The game was much less satisfying.  We are now in the midst of Crimefest 2015. I haven't played the game since May, but I learned from the Crimefest website that a new feature has been added that is similar to the skins and inventory systems in CS:GO and TF2, respectively. This is a huge disappointment, even to someone who hasn't played the game in months. This game does not need microtransactions. TF2 is free to play, so it makes sense that it has microtransactions. CS:GO's microtransactions do not affect gameplay at all, and CS:GO has zero paid DLC - all the gameplay content is unlocked by buying the core game.  Payday 2 now has: The upfront cost of the game - $5-$20 depending on the sales The cost of any desired DLCs - Anywhere between $0 and $111 Microtransactions - who the fuq knows?  As if this weren't bad enough, the pre-existing content has been nerfed to make room for the new microtransaction-based content. That's right. The weapon skins you get from the slot-machine DLC affect the gameplay. They're not just cosmetic. As if that weren't bad enough, many of the weapon skins are for DLC weapons.  In essense, the developers are triple-dipping on this game. They charge for the core game, they charge extra for what is now the vast majority of the content (there's more DLC content than free content now), and the paid content is MUCH better than what comes with the core game. On top of that, they charge for random weapon skins that DO affect gameplay that might be for a DLC that you don't have. SO basically unless you're willing to buy all $131 of existing content AND all future content regardless of the price, there's no point in even participating in the slot-machine microtransactions because you might get something you have no use for. ***EDIT: Wow... looking back on this, I originally posted just one year ago this week about how I thought this was the best game ever. It was one of the first games I finally started reviewing. It's terrifying to see how much changed in that one year.***  Wow... I don't even know what to say about this game anymore. If someone told me three or so years ago that I would leave a negative review for Payday 2, I'd think they were crazy. There was one time when this game was all I could look forward to every day after high school. My friends and I would talk about it at least 3 times a week, plan new strategies and new ways to play, go home and try it all weekend, and start over again on Monday with new ideas. This game has to be one of the greatest games on Steam, but it's ruined. It's kind of like seeing an old friend willingly walk out of your life for good. Buckle up, this'll be a long one... for an old friend.    TL;DR: Listen to P!nk's 'Who Knew'   I've played Payday since a few months after the first one came out, and I really looked forward to the 2nd one. When it came out, I loved everything about it. Everything felt better. Just better. The dlc that was introduced in Payday the Heist (Wolfpack, included the technician branch) was already in this game. When the first few dlc packs came out, I was happy to buy them. They all felt like they added so much more to the game. Grenades, machine guns, transport heists (although some people hated them, I really enjoyed them), they were all amazing.   After a while, it was obvious that they were running out of ideas for dlc, but they still made new packs which I bought right away as well. Adding new characters was a stretch for me, and so were single day + single mission map packs, but what the heck. People started to call the game 'Pay2Win' and whatnot, like they normally do as soon as a game has more than 3 dlc packs. I ignored them. They were, afterall wrong... at that point.  Later Overkill started pumping out weirder and less immersive packs that I just couldn't convince myself to enjoy. The Alesso Hesit, Golden Grin, Wild West, Medieval, & Ninja packs, to name a few, just felt wrong to me. I slowed down my pace and eventually stopped playing the game for weeks at a time. Yesterday, Overkill announced Microtransactions to the game. I'm not going to go into too much detail, since the community is already beyond angry, but that was just a slap to the face. After playing the game seemingly endlessly and standing by the developers for  years , they keep trying to suck our money. Recently the website  pd2stats.com  announced their death. Go to that website by the way, and read the reason. Overkill lost touch with its community due to their own greed, and they pushed their community to pieces.  I'll say this again, since it deserves to be said,  Payday 2 is the best game on Steam . I honestly do believe so. Overkill though... you guys ruined it. I wish we could all go back to when there were just 3-4 dlc packs and only 4 heisters. The game was so fun and innocent back in those days. Even if you try to go back, it's impossible to play with the original 4. You can try to play the old missions by yourself, using old guns, and relive those days. You can try. But the mandatory addition of the newer enemies & heisters will only remind you that those days will never happen again. Sometimes change is good, but when Overkill twists and bends this game the way they did, you just want that change to go away... but it can't.  Payday 2, you were a great friend. Looking back, I can't believe this all happened. I miss my old friend, but this friend willingly left me for greed. I'll never forget all of the fun I've had with this game, and I'll never forget why I could no longer bring myself to play it again. I'm sure I'll play it again. I'll wrack up maybe a hundred more hours on this game. I know I will... but it'll never be the same. It'll still be fun when I play it with my friends, but it'll never again be as fun as it once was.  Farewell old friend.

I don't normally write reviews for games, however I feel compelled to review this game for anyone who is considering buying it and is looking for info before they do. If you want in-depth analysis of the gameplay/graphics/sound/etc, this is not the review for you. This is a BUYER BEWARE warning about the state this game has come to be in since most of the positive reviews were written. It is also a careful analysis of the direction the development team have taken the game in the last year and change and what that means for the future of the game. This is not going to be short. If you don't feel like spending several minutes reading a whole lot of detail about the history of a video game, keep scrolling. Otherwise, buckle in. I'll try to be as succinct as possible and assume no prior knowledge of the history of the game.  I have played Payday 2 for nearly 700 hours. If I had reviewed this game a year ago, I wouldn't have been able to recommend it enough. It has been a ton of fun, especially with friends. The difficulty levels provide adequate degrees of challenge depending on the competency of the crew from ridiculously easy to ridiculously hard. The achievements provided an added layer of meta-challenge for those times when I got bored with normal play. Progression was satisfying - a veteran player was a huge asset to the team, while new players required extra help from the team to make it through. The game rewarded players for learning the nuances and finding the 'best' way to complete objectives. New content was added at fairly regular intervals. Some was free, some was paid. All of it was quality content that enhanced the game, and I happily bought all of it.  Something changed.  I'm not sure when the change began. Maybe it was right around the first anniversary of the game's launch (Crimefest 2014). A whole bunch of free content was added to commemorate 2 million players joining the official Steam group. This new content was fairly well received, but I think the way the community came together to support the game set a bad precedent with the developers.  Future content became less and less about enhancing the game and more about adding content for its own sake (or for the sake of revenue. Power creep with new DLC weapons and items made the game easier for people who bought the DLCs, making the progression faster and less meaningful. The prestige system was overhauled to provide more grinding for the sake of grinding. Meanwhile fewer and fewer new heists were added, with the developers focusing more and more on weapon packs and character packs instead of heists.  The there was the 'Hype Train' event. This was similar to Crimefest 2014, except that instead of just joining a group, players had to buy exclusive DLC packages to 'fund' the event and unlock rewards for the whole community.  Hype Train left a bad taste in my mouth for several reasons.  1: Some of the free content that was promised during Crimefest had not been released yet. It was kind of weird that the developers were having another community event so soon without following through on the things that were promised during the last event.  2: The event advertised that the new content that was unlocked would be 'free' for the whole community, but the purchase of paid DLC was required in order to unlock the content. The exclusive content was extremely overpriced, with the justification being that it was exclusive (it wouldn't be sold again after the event), and it was overpriced on purpose because buyers would be supporting the event. Kind of weird to make the most loyal fans of the game support free content for less loyal fans... Luckily I saw through the bullcrap and didn't buy it.  3: Some of the images used to tease the 'free' content were actually images for upcoming paid content, with the free content being different stuff released much, much later. It was essentially a bait and switch to get people hyped and buy DLC.  So hopefully you can see why the Hype Train event really set the community on edge. Fans felt like their support and goodwill was a commodity that could be cashed in by the developers.  Future DLCs were much less interesting. Things were added that were completely game-breaking (such as the RPG, which has ludicrous griefing potential and is also completely OP) or just straight upgrades from existing DLC packs or core content.   I began to play the game a lot less. I still enjoyed it but it was really discouraging to see how easy it had become with the overpowered new content. The game was much less satisfying.  We are now in the midst of Crimefest 2015. I haven't played the game since May, but I learned from the Crimefest website that a new feature has been added that is similar to the skins and inventory systems in CS:GO and TF2, respectively. This is a huge disappointment, even to someone who hasn't played the game in months. This game does not need microtransactions. TF2 is free to play, so it makes sense that it has microtransactions. CS:GO's microtransactions do not affect gameplay at all, and CS:GO has zero paid DLC - all the gameplay content is unlocked by buying the core game.  Payday 2 now has: The upfront cost of the game - $5-$20 depending on the sales The cost of any desired DLCs - Anywhere between $0 and $111 Microtransactions - who the fuq knows?  As if this weren't bad enough, the pre-existing content has been nerfed to make room for the new microtransaction-based content. That's right. The weapon skins you get from the slot-machine DLC affect the gameplay. They're not just cosmetic. As if that weren't bad enough, many of the weapon skins are for DLC weapons.  In essense, the developers are triple-dipping on this game. They charge for the core game, they charge extra for what is now the vast majority of the content (there's more DLC content than free content now), and the paid content is MUCH better than what comes with the core game. On top of that, they charge for random weapon skins that DO affect gameplay that might be for a DLC that you don't have. SO basically unless you're willing to buy all $131 of existing content AND all future content regardless of the price, there's no point in even participating in the slot-machine microtransactions because you might get something you have no use for.  At the time of writing this review, the game is already so bloated that I have zero desire to play it anymore. When I log in I get to look at what seems like dozens of items that are locked behind DLC paywalls. Not only that, but players who have purchased this content can join my games and make it so easy for us to win that I don't even feel like it was an accomplishment anymore. This game used to be fun. The developers took advantage of the positive reviews to ♥♥♥♥ the game so they could keep the revenue flowing. The game is not fun anymore. The developers cannot be trusted to follow through with the things they promise to do. Save yourself the headache and buy something less bloated.

To my surprise, the missions that have the same objective as others are not repetitive. I thought to myself: 'I'm stealing an artifact? You can put nearly any modification on any gun, so you can make a very effective weapon or a really stupid, but fun to play, weapon. I once put a sniper scope on a Deagle and it was loads of fun to play with, even though it's really dumb to do. The mask customization doesn't fall short either. Having an epic mask is the definition of being a heister. You won't be notorious if you have that default mask that everybody doesn't like. You ca make really silly to downright intimidating masks.  Thirdly, the sweet, sweet soundtrack. You CANNOT get enough of it. I can safely say that this soundtrack is better than Hotline Miami's. In my opinion, every song is worth listening at least three times. Not only are they great to listen to, they provide mood in-game. While fighting off those damned Cloakers, the adrenaline-pumping music makes it even more intense. I strongly recommend buying the DLCs that have songs included in them.  Finally, the actual co-op gameplay. It's absolutely wonderful. Every heister has to work together to complete their task. When I'm heisting with four of my mates, we sound very strategic even though we're only robbing a diamond store. I feel like we could be the next Ocean's Eleven while we meticulously plan our heists.  Something that I should mention is the absurd amount of DLCs. Personally, I don't mind the DLCs because I know that by buying them, I'm supporting the developers. Only one person in your group of heisters needs to own that certain bit of DLC so all of you can play the mission. The DLCs are small things, such as a new skillset, weapons and masks. Not having the DLC weapons may make the game difficult, but they're not necessities. The devs have also said that after Update 100, they'll stop making new content as DLC.  Overall, Payday 2 is an absolutely wonderful game. I would give it a 10/10 if it weren't for the paywall, so it's currently at a 9/10. Get this game if you and your mates want to have a fun time doing illegal things.

Payday 2 is a vast improvement over its predecessor, with a fairly broad variety of missions and options galore in every mission. This isn't to say that it's anything close to open-world - but the feeling of agency in how you and your friends play lets you ignore the fact that the missions themselves can be be fairly linear.  The real joy comes from how you invest in your particular character, in the form of the skill tree. As you progress, you're able to mix and match your skills from four different classes, investing entirely in one path or becoming something of a jack of all trades and master of none. Even the weapons have a depth to them, with a great deal of customization available to them, allowing you to tweak them to suit your particular approach.  That being said, I would love to see some more novelty in the missions or yet more options. Some missions are clearly easier when you approach them one particular way, and with no real difference in reward in many of them despite your approach, it's easy to fall into habits. I understand that complete freedom isn't a formula for fun - but the illusion of it can be.   What would bring the game to another level would be an option to plan the hiest - with a map of the area (if it makes sense to have a map, or if you can buy that intel if you're a Mastermind) and have each player be able to draw on it, or make notes, going over the plan before the actual hiest begins. I think that there's potential for magic if this game is expanded upon to make a true hiest game, but for now, the tension of stealth and the chaos of police assaults is satisfying as hell.

Teamwork is key when playing on the highest difficulties and some of the heist completly relies on it. one person screw up and and everyone ends up in custody. Completing heist give you cash that you can spend on weapons and tree skill to specialise your playstyle. maxing out the four tree being imposible, choosing wisely is important. while respecing is an option, it cost more money to reset rather than trying to put your skill pts in the right skills as soon as you can. Weapons mod and most of the mask and their customization are randomly dropped after every succeded mission, which makes it kind of hard to unlock some of the better mods and mask as they are rare and require hundreds of missions to drop.   Heist can sometimes be done quietly which will result in a exp % increase depending of the difficulty. And there is of course the loud way of doing it which will result in the cops arriving and making you life a living hell. The loud part mostly feel like a horde mode in which you do objectives that mostly involve a lot of waiting and shooting, With the usual special enemies from times to times.   While this game being a lot of fun, it sure suffer from some issues from time to time. The Single Player option is mostly a play solo option, cause the ai is brain dead and will not help with any of the objective, turning them into meat shield that will sometimes revive you if needed. Even if the game is mostly around Co-op, an option to give orders to bot would sure come handy in situation where you are short on human players. Connecting to the games online can be a nightmare and will sometimes keep disconnecting multiples times even required me to reboot steam in order to get into a lobby. And even if in game you will sometime get randomly disconnected from server for no reasons, and since the game lacks a decent matchmaking lobby, it sometimes makes rejoining imposible unless if you are playing with your friends which is the most recommended thing if you can. Also the dlc whoring is getting a bit out of control with multiple weapons and heist packs coming at 5$ each. with very rarely free expansions with few content from time to time. At least none of them are required to play the game and you can even play with people owning any of the dlc. You can also join dlc heist if they are available, you just cant host them.   But overall this game is a lot of fun if you can get past the few problems mentioned above and for 30$ its worth it in my book.

To begin with, lets talk DLC. As mentioned there is a quite a bit of DLC for Payday 2. Initially I didn't mind this but as time went on the quality of the DLC steadily decreased. It became apparent sometime in the last few months that DLC was being churned out without any decent regard for quality. Characters that don't fit at all and have veritably no story, content packs that are basically an advertisement for a DJ...that you pay for! DLC has increasingly been more and more worthless over time.   But that's just the beginning of the slide. DLC going down the tubes is one thing. DLC wasn't enough, now we have microtransactions! Several studio officiates are on record having stated a number of times that microtransactions would absoutely never be added to the game. I do not appreciate the system of how I pay for content changing drastically after I have invested into a franchise for years. More over, I DESPISE BEING LIED TO!  Being lied to is bad. Being lied to about microtransactions AFTER shelling out probably around a grand and investing hundreds of hours in a franchise....well, that's being robbed by an old friend (that you helped put through college). Wether you paid for just the original game and never bought DLC, or if you're like me and bought enought copies and content to equal a used car, it's completely unacceptable for a game studio to lie to and attempt to exploit the player base in this way.   I encourage anyone looking at getting this game to stay away. Payday was a great game but you missed the boat, all that remains now is rampant profit mongering from morally bankrupt suits.

I prefer the latter, but there are XP benefits to going stealthy and it does require a lot more focus and skill. The customisation options are expansive and remind me of Modern Warfare 2; skill trees for specific group roles based on stealth, support and brute force are a bit like a 'perk' system and you can paint your masks and guns to your heart's content. The multiplayer aspects I like are that your actions only effect your own cash and XP score (i.e. if you kill a civilian or get gunned down) and that you must finish the entire length of the mission in order to receive your rewards - this means that if random idiots ditch the game at crucial points they get squat. Bear in mind that a lot of these customisation options are DLC locked, and so far I haven't seen the benefit of having bought lots of the DLC packs. If it comes out on sale in a whole package + all DLC again buy it then but otherwise the game itself will provide you with many hours of adrenaline-pumping criminal capers. Definitely more mature than games like Call of Duty... Military vs military is one thing, but bringing cops and robbers alive like this really twists with the mind and your sense of ethics, hoping for the bad guys (you) to win.  Being a mature, violent game doesn't make it bad though! In fact, those are what make it so good. On top of an RPG system to level your character and spec into four tactics trees (leader/medic, tank, damage, and stealth), the game offers the options to play stealthily, by suppression and control, or guns blazing and everyone around you dying. There are levels of difficulty in the police that responds, with it increasing over time (or difficulty of the heist), if you show you're a big enough threat for the police to call in snipers and the SWAT teams, riot shields, the FBI and helicopters, and your new best friend Sam Fisher (not to mention some nasty bruisers in bomb suits with portable machine guns or shotguns that make you wish you stayed home with mommy).  As far as story goes, there isn't much of a rigid storyline, although there are a few major clients that contract you to their heists, with some lasting a couple days, and their motives become pretty clear - the characters are less of common bank robbers and more of mercenary vigilantes, working for others to steal money owed, and pocketing some cash for themselves along the way. Getting that extra cash usually isn't easy either, at least not nearly as easy as it is to get the main money or other precious items intended for the contractor.  Still, good communication and teamwork make the heists very possible. That's something the game is good at, too. Clearly built around multiplayer, even giving you two (very crappy) AI companions so you can play alone, the game works wonderfully with four players. Meeting most of the classes' roles between the four, there are a lot more options for how to perform the heist, and give players a specific job to focus on. Someone may be watching out for guards or dispatching them and moving bodies, while another is working on shutting down security, while another is drilling into a vault, while the last is controlling the crowds and tying up civilians to use as hostages. Mastermind class is good with people-skills, like being more intimidating and convincing people to assist (including under-trained guards, etc), as well as healing allies. Enforcer has tougher armor and can resist enemy fire more, as well as being more efficient in combat in general, and can drop an ammo stash. Technician can use sentries and trip mines, and is great with using drills and modifying weapons. Ghost gains bonuses to silenced weapons and armor piercing, an electrical device to disable cameras and other electronic security, faster and more efficient lockpicking, and the ability to bag (and move) bodies. When they all play together, the game runs with so much more fluidity, and can adjust to whatever they come across.  And what they come across does matter, as the levels all have random details in them. Doorways in walls, counters, placement of jewels, safes, guards, the civilians walking along the street (or a hotdog vendor that attracts cops), random money or gems laying around, camera placement (if at all - sometimes there aren't any), or where your getaway vehicle shows up. Locks may require a drill to get through, or a keycard, or can be picked open, or even blown up with C4; spending 5 minutes managing a drill as you try to get in a safe and think you're done and can run out of there can be stopped by a door inside the safe that needs another drill, explosives, or can be picked. Wasting time with another drill may get you killed, just as using up your explosives on another secure door may leave you with little option to get through this next door, but with multiple players, you still have choices and can handle the random that shows up.  If you can't tell by this rant, I do really like the game. It brings together my favorite elements of Hitman, Left 4 Dead, and Borderlands, in a way that makes me want to keep playing, ESPECIALLY with other people. Some thanks to others who have it and sharing what's great about it with me, without which I wouldn't be playing it now at all... and that's a sad world.

I felt like Overkill was a humble team of people but - as of the second annual Crimefest - things went beyond event horizon.  The game suffers from glitches and bugs that I saw back when I first started playing Payday 2. They've never been fixed. Optimization is still garbage after massive overhaul of my rig.  The game has been receiving DLC's. A lot of them. Too many of them. Most are just pricey character packs. Characters that we really didn't need. New heists are rare and most of the time, they are mediocre or just bad.  And with second Crimefest arrived the pay to unlock crates with weapon skins. These weapon skins aren't purely cosmetic. They are NOT PURELY cosmetic. They have stat improvements. Think CS:GO crates but the skins have benefits that affect the gameplay.  I'm not sure why the mindless community supports this money-grabbing but I wash my hands from this mess. I loved this game. I even wanted my own Wolf mask. Today I say goodbye to this franchise. Unless we can go back to the old times, I won't be seen in this game anymore. Everyone sighs in relief and I sigh in relief. The game is nothing short of one of the best sequel examples in the game industry. The game evolved so much and at the same time it feels so familiar that you gonna love it right from the first minute of play, especially if you played Payday: The Heist previously. If you ever thought of playing FPS Co-op - this should be your first option to be considered.  Taking away those bugs and issues, a bit less than expected heists quantity (the game is still at least twice as big as first installment) and other issues, the game is marvelous. The game got several times bigger the original, it now has stealthy way of completing nearly every mission along with run'n'gun style. It has tons of customization options (I wonder why people were talking about high prices for mods / paint jobs etc - after several overkills walkthroughs you always have more than enough money for everyting). I have tried to like this game, I have tried to like it very very hard. I paid $50 for this game after loving the first Payday, and playing the beta I thought this had so much potential, that Payday 2 could really be something great, but it isn't. Payday 2 is pure frustration and trolling in digital form.  I don't say this because the game is hard, I am fine with hard games, but because Payday 2 is designed to troll you. This game features stealth heavily in many of its missions, yet also features randomly pathing AI, and restricts the number of bodies you can move to 2 ontop of allowing you to only kill 4 guards before automatically raising the alarm. The most recent heist added also enforces stealth, and if the alarm raises it gives you 50 seconds to make your escape, and if you do not have an arbitrary amount of loot acquired you will recieve no rewards, even if you did manage to obtain some loot before escaping.  With so many random elements to this game, even when you DO manage to complete a heist perfectly, the victory feels shallow. There is no feeling of 'I did this, I rock!' only the feeling of 'Well, I got lucky'. Because you know that you only won because the game didn't have a randomly pathing guard go down the alley way where you were forced to leave a body. Or because you know you only won because the vault spawned in a location where no civilians would hear the drill. You won because you managed to get lucky this time, not because you were good at the game.  If you like a game that will do everything in its power to screw you over, by randomly pathing AI finding the body you aren't allowed to move, or four cops with shields in a corner, or a cloaker hiding right next to the escape van that instantly kills you one nano second before victory, then this is a game for you. But if that doesn't sound like fun, I suggest you pass on this game, no matter how awesome you think it might be to get to rob a bank with your friends, because ultimately, you will only feel like you paid money to get screwed, and not to have a good time.

PROS: + Game looks very nice. + Fun gameplay for the first handful of hours. + Inventive levelling system, inspired by online shooters and translated to a co-op environment. + Decent array of weaponry, content and customization in the base game.  CONS: - Semi-broken. Very buggy with lots of lazy errors. - Stealth is very poor. Enemies seemingly have the hearing and eyesight of an omniscient being, regardless, it is made pointless by poor design choices. - Becomes EXTREMELY tedious, boring, dry and repetitive after you complete all the heists once, or even before then. (5-10 hrs). - ABSURD amounts of DLC. While it started as simple aesthetics and silly skins, it eventually grew to the point of excluding people who are not willing to drop nearly 200$ on all the expansion packs. - No real creative difficulty. Rather than limiting you in certain ways, the only way they seem to make the game any harder is by throwing more and bigger enemies your way. When it boils down to it, the toughest enemy and the easiest are only separated by their health.   While this game was very, very fun for a brief period of time, that's about all I can say about it. It's okay looking, but doesn't run particularly well, with resolution issues (Can anyone say 'letterbox'?) at anything higher than 480p. While that can easily be fixed by editing some .ini files, that's not something a player should be left to do. The missions are fun and inventive for a litte bit, but always boil down to a fetch quest gone wrong, in which you have to hold out in whichever location for X amount of time until you have a brief window to transport contraband, rinse and repeat for the umpteenth time. Any 'stealth' one might attempt is futile, because once you endure the painful process of dodging every enemy and civilian within a 10 mile radius, it all goes to ♥♥♥♥ once you star attempting to open a door. As much as it breaks my heart, I simply cannot recommend anyone to buy this game at a price higher than next to free.

One small problem I have with the game that probably doesn't correspond to everyone is the difficulty of hte game-lack of difficulty that is. I’ll be honest, I don’t know where it went wrong.  When I first bought PAYDAY2 just over 2 years ago, it was fantastic. It was just released and it had a lot going for it, I still remember my first heist down to each bullet fired – it made a really good memory I still think back to. There was a great selection of frequent and upcoming features and the developers really had their heads screwed on right, I finally found a substitute for killing floor 1. Everything was great.  Then my graphics card broke which forced me to take a year’s break. I got a new graphics card a year later, reinstalled PAYDAY2 and…well. I didn’t recognize it at all. It went from an award winning game to a development company saying “maybe later” and constantly lying to its community, even insulting them in community posts as “noise on the other side of the rails”, starting in-fights in the community itself.  Any criticism it took was either ignored or suppressed, which just made people angrier at them and their “yeah whatever” ethos. They even said 'driving will never be in the game'. Then they went and added a driving mechanic a few months later.  Better yet, a year ago they announced a completely different game they would be doing. And then pinned it on the Steam PAYDAY2 forums. It’s clear they are using PAYDAY2 as a launching pad for their next game because they sunk PD2 so badly a while ago.  The game itself had devolved greatly as well. The engine had seemed to have gotten worse at holding solid frame rates and the maps given to us only had a tiny bit of random chance such as 1 wall being in a different place or two optional places an item can spawn.  The issues of desync also still plagued the game, making it impossible to play on stealth missions because guards could see you through walls. Something that could be cured with dedicated servers, but the developers just met the community with a wall of silence or changed the subject each time.  The AI is basically slightly less smart than a sack of bricks. They will enter the area, stand around idle for several seconds and then run to cover (which doesn’t cover them at all).  At which point two things happen. A) They will stare at a wall and go idle, doing nothing B) They will track you through a wall and maybe move to run at you blindly  I have caught the AI several times (as I turned a corner) starting at the ceiling doing nothing, only to engage me a whole 8 seconds later by snap-locking to me and shooting me point blank. This happens very frequently  Balance doesn’t exist in PD2 either, there are a handful of weapons that are actually useful and the rest you surpass far too quickly and just serve to bulk out the inventory screens. Out of my hundreds of hours, I have only used a total of 6 weapons - because the rest had no incentive to be used and were never given any adjustment.  All the skills are driven towards a handful of weapon types (mainly shotguns and pistols), so SMGs and “special” weapons such as grenade launchers get no love at all. I have had many times where a fully modded and upgraded shotgun can just 1v1 literally anything on the hardest difficulty. Which makes gameplay very linear.  Additional content is the main thing that killed this game. The price of the content isn’t an issue, but the quality and perks they give you are completely out of line. Much content was either horribly broken on release or didn’t work at all. Many issues such as characters having no voice lines could be noticed and fixed within seconds of testing. But it’s clear they just don’t test anything they make anymore.   Like they don’t even care.  Much of the paid content gives you a massive advantage and game changing ability to survive the harder difficulty scenarios. And all the free content gives is boring cosmetics and items that make little or no impact in the game whatsoever. It’s clear they make the free content just to hope people shut up about it.  All the content and features from the past year are unimaginative and very much the same Weapon packs Character packs Skills  Nothing really new or inventive at all. Which is why I recently lost interest, I played for hours to find a reason to keep playing.  But after the petty insults, poor PR and terrible updates, I have just had enough.  Now Payday2 boasts microtransactions, which is another thing the developers said would never be in the game and lied about.  If you are ever doing a research project on how poor PR and development can destroy a product, this is a goldmine.

In the present day 4 people set out to steal from banks, Run from the F.B.I, transport coke, fight off the swat and much more. You follow 4 people in PAYDAY 2 called Dallas (The thinker), Chains (The muscle), Wolf (The technician) and Hoxton (The ghost). As the player we get to select which character we wish to play as but it doesnt stop there. You can pick the skills you want your character to learn, The mask he wears, The guns he uses and the way he enters. Payday 2 Is brilliant with its coustomization of masks and guns making your character 1 of a kind and the guns can effect the results of the robery, Hold off or escape. The game missions will always change by either changung the postions of the vaults to adding more guards to adding more cameras and other possiblities. It would be near impossible to explain all of the changes this game can do with just a click of the restart mission button. To be honest at first i thought this may be like Payday:The heist so i was kind of put off but i watched some videos and read about it and now playing it it feels like the creators have listend to the fans and have improved the game. From missions to your safe house everything feels like it never gets old. Lastly, one feature that caught my eye is the card choice. If any of you reading this have played with me you will know that i love this bit. It allows you to get items which cant be obtained through normal assestes e.g kill 100 SWAT, Rob 50 banks ect. You get given 3 cards and you have to choose one and the results vary. From new gun attachments to new masks this method never gets old. And the best bit is it usually happens when you complete a heist so you get money and other things yay. Oh and money is more usefull, You can now buy alot of equipment now so insted of just getting it for looking purposes you can spend it on paint for your masks or weapon mods. From characters to gameplay the game never lacks to impress me. Only problem i had was a bit of lag but if you do have that there is an option to turn the graphics down so it runs nicer and smoother. If your thinking of getting PAYDAY 2 go ahead it is brilliant and you wont regret it! Thanks for reading!

This is a pretty good co-op oriented game. Notice how I said co-op? That's key. Play this with friends if you can, if not, do it online with randoms, and try to use a mic. Communication can be key, especially in stealth missions. There are quite a few guns, four skill trees, and 100 levels. The level of customization you can have in your character is great, and this is the same when it comes to guns. Your four skills trees are as follows; a tank type tree, a rogue type tree, a healer type tree(also acts like some sort of controller), and a generalist(?) type tree. Graphically it's nothing to write home about, but it's not bad either. The sound is cool, and if you've ever watched Heat (1995), the gun sounds may remind you of that. The music is cool if you play with it, but can get annoying after a while (I've since turned it off). In the later levels it gets to a standard RPG style grindfest, and god it can move slow. Perhaps they will add some huge heist that that really level you up high in the later levels, but at this point some of the ranks can take 3+ of the most XP giving heist. I would recommend playing it with a dedicated group of friends, don't count on random, teammates to always have the best coordination/communiation skills.

(Most random onlineplayers can't do the last part. Multiplayer was a maximum rustle when taken too serious on harder difficulties). Bought it during crimefest 2014 when I saw huge updates and a lot of promise. Game was reasonable for a while, I would say until after the diamond heist, then started to roll downhill with ever dumber characters, missions, revamps and features. When the hypetrain event started I thought it was the bottom of the pit, but nope. Microtransactions followed. Attention was shifted away from actual content to pleasing kids who wanted better looking waterguns to sprinkle their balls with AND had the money to waste on them. Finally Overkill acquired the rights to the game, they made the biker heist, which was actually good I felt hope for the game for the first time in a long while. Then skills got revamped. Then difficulties got revamped because the skills were too op. Then weapon stats got revamped because the difficulty was too op... The game started out as a thoughtful heist sim, even the GO bank heist was reasonable for a christmas themed mission (later event maps became terribly silly) then the DLCs and the updates became more and more of a farce until the whole game became a parody of itself and it's fans who put a lot love and more importantly, MONEY into it. If I could, I would get that money back, because this is NOT the game I've bought in 2014. I have to say, if I'd look at it now, I definitely wouldn't buy it. And I don't recommend it to anyone.

Worthy sequel for one of my favorite games. It's bit different, but has more content than first one. I have enjoyed both games, and still do enjoy this. Going back to first game seems to be hard, as it feels different.  This game is co-op game, so have some friends to play it with, or try to find someone to play it with you; there are loads of trolls in-game, and they keep kicking randoms out, so host your own games, or play with friends.  Maps/Levels whatever you want to call them, are smaller than in first game, but there are loads of them unlike in Payday: The heist, which i still played over 200 hours. This is balanced with so called 'multi-day' jobs/missions. You proceed days on mission, and get your money on last day. There are contracts that are one days, two days or three days.   Also, if you don't stealth, (which is possible in many maps),there are escape missions between days, where your objective is to survive for like 3-5 minutes so that new escape vehicle can arrive to pick you up. These tend to annoy me sometimes, as there are about 7 of them, but i always get either Overpass, or garage escape.  Also, sequel introduces you bags. Loot bags. You have to actually carry stuff you steal, and it's big part of the game. Maybe little bit too much, but there are missions which aren't just about carrying bags from the bank to your van.  As in first game, soundtrack is superior. Awesome work by Simon Viklund, again. It fits game perfectly, and they have added many songs prior to release. They have also had 25 updates so far, fixing and adding stuff. If there a update people don't like, overkill has done something about it. If you want the game, get it on PC, as console patching is slow...  One of best co-op which you can have, if you allow 'some' grinding and it being bag throwing simulator.  Btw; you can move hostages these days ;)

Payday 2 is both a good and a bad game. It's hard to lean on one side of the game and not the other.  Is the game repetitive? Yes, very. You will find yourself doing the same mission a lot.  Is it still fun to do these heists? Yes!  Is the game fun to play even without friends? That's a mixed bag. Don't expect to be able to solo most missions on high difficulties. For the most part though, public games, from my experience, aren't that bad.  Would you recommend playing this games with friends? Yes, I can't recommend that enough. Friends that you know are reliable, and are willing to listen, will make great teammates in this.  Now, all you really need to do to enjoy the game is buy the base game itself. The DLC heists can be played if the host owns it. However, if you want to get more weapons, masks and patterns, as well as achievements, you will need to purchase the DLC. Are the DLCs worth it for the heists? Yes. Weapons, masks and patterns? Not really in my eyes. Most of the DLCs only have one weapon worth taking. Probably the best DLC would be the Sniper Pack, but then again that's my own opinion.  The game is still being actively worked on, and we're getting a lot of free stuff through CrimeFest.  The game offers a lot of gameplay and I still am enjoying this game. And while, yes, sometimes it isn't so fun to play, I still have to recommend picking up this game.

Pros:   Damn fun game with solid stealth and gunplay with unique settings and scenarios. Highly replayable missions and an interesting lottery drop system Amazingly fun to play with friends - especially while drinking heavily  Cons:   Very buggy NPCs - even this long after release dont be suprised to see lots of pathing issues including oddities such as random strolls through solid objects and ruined Stealth missions when a body part clips through a wall/floor  The NPCs make higher difficulties a major burden. The Special Police forces are barely a challenge; The real danger is the horde of regular SWAT units who shoot fully automatic weapons with pinpoint accuracy - sometimes from locations that make them impossible to see or hit in return (See the clipping issues above). This turns many 'Action' levels into a frusterating game of ressurection spam since cover is only marginally helpful  While the game is fun with friends, random parties often lack the co-ordination to complete some of the more complex missions efficiently. While this is true of many online games it really shows in Payday where teamwork and situational awareness are mandatory. Sticking to easier missions online is also a non option as well since the game heavily penalizes you for completing the same mission too often  Payday is very much Pay to win. While the vanilla game has an 'ok' selection, many of the best missions, weapons, upgrades, and coveted achievements are hidden in the 5-7 dollar content packs (Grenades being one of the most noticeable). Payday has turned the expanded content game into a full time gig with new pay walls being raised every 2-3 months with an initial investment that by this point costs more than the base game itself  tl:dr  Payday 2 is an amazing game to play if you have a fairly regular group of friends to heist with as good online groups are uncommon and offline play is inefficient at best and nearly impossible otherwise. I would also only ever recommend buying the game during one of the steam sales when you can catch up on the content packs without paying AAA prices for the combined package
