Decided I'll give this game a long and somewhat detailed review, mostly for friends who are on the fence on purchasing.  I have enjoyed this game for over a month now and continue to enjoy it. TL;DR? I recommend buying this if you liked playing difficult coop campaigns with friends on Left 4 Dead.  At first it's a game about discovering how to simply complete various heists and trying to earn skill points and money to be better at completing the maps. You'll have a sense of accomplishment from just finishing levels and may have your hand held by more experienced friends or players. Skill trees and money will seem daunting, but you'll look forward to the skills at the end and see figuring out missions as a way to get closer to those goals.  After you get used to the game you'll find it's rather easy to earn needed money, skills will become less important as your own player skills will become more important. You'll feel less challenged on some maps (bank heist :V), but others on more appropriate difficulties for your in game level will make for a lot of tense combat moments for you and 3 other friends. Especially when trying to pass maps on the highest difficulty, Deathwish. Essentially Deathwish will see even maxed out players having to make quick and very critical decisions with your 3 teammates in order to pass. Or... you'll find cheesy ways to win, but those are boring and will exist in any game like this.  The game includes a 'prestige' system where you can start over leveling for some bonuses, but it's by no means necessary to do.   The developers are constantly supporting this game and releasing new content. Some DLC, some free! DLC can get pricey as a total, but feel free to be picky about what weapon packs you buy (don't buy the shotgun pack if you aren't using shotguns :V), and keep in mind that if a friend hosts a session and has a DLC mission, they can include you even without you owning it. You just can't host and pick the mission yourself or play it yourself.  Some downsides: The game has glitches. Some are quite annoying too. I've experienced being stuck on loading screens, not being able to connect to friends who I was just playing with for seemingly no reason, and guards attacking (even worse in stealth, detecting me!) in really glitchy ways. Maps have also loaded with weird errors around which had effected the ability for friends and I to complete maps. Funniest example? Drilled open a safe, there was a safe inside. I was not happy. Also when you stealth missions, the actual execution of the heist can be fast, but on some missions there's a lot of standing around waiting for drills to finish drilling locks/safes open for extended periods of time. These are points where you've essentially already won the map, so there's nothing left to do and you just run in circles letting time pass. That can be kind of boring. Have a book nearby or Alt+Tab out, you'll be fine... sadly that's not good game play.  Conclusion: Excellent 4 Player Coop Experience that continues to reward and challenge you as you learn how to play, but may seem very daunting at first. Tons of content and continued dev support ensures the game will continue to be something you're coming back to. Just be prepared for some glitchiness and to have some game play time that is essentially waiting around. Also be prepared to spend more than the base price on DLC.

Probably the best team PvE FPS game ever made.  It has little quirks and lack of features other games have (like picking guns up off the ground when out of ammo), but this enhances the game experience and makes it even more unique. There are many mods too, like the official mod HOXHUD, which fill the gaps in extra player needs for making the game more user friendly. The bot pathing can be bad, especially with civilian hostages, but this too kinda of makes for more realism as I doubt hostages are ever easy to control all the time. The maps Hotline Miami map in basement and Big Oil engine clues require high graphics settings to read, which is annoying, but someone usually has specs or knows the answers by heart from so many replays of levels, so not a big deal most of the time.  The worst part of the game is actually the community, which is some what surprising as the best people of the community are absolutely fantastic, the bad ones being the extreme other end of the spectrum. I smashed out at least 160 hours in 2 weeks once to get to V-100 (the current xp cap, which will be raised to XIV-100 in time), this rapid gain of levels which in the end took me over 315 hours to achieve earnt many kicking from games as people accused me of hacking my much fought for leveling (you can go 2 hours without gaining any xp due to noobs, trolls, and incompetent players). There is sadly a large hacking element which pull the game down some, and make for inexperienced players who may have a high level but are clueless as to what needs to be done to finish a level; which also has an extreme other end of the scale of people who play solo or just with one mate, and have played less difficult maps more often and leveled slower, but can win games constantly at their low level with a good team. There are difficulty skull masks for Hard, Very Hard, Overkill, and Deathwish, the Overkill and Deathwish masks used to be seen rarely, but now they are quite common due to both hackers cheating for them and there being an ever growing number of good players.  Being a lover of Tenchu, who would love to see them all relaunched on Steam (hint hint Steam, do eet!), the stealth game is something I really enjoy, this is way up there in that category and the leveling system gives many good skills to enhance stealth and how to approach stealth in Payday 2. They have patched the balance many times and stealth was getting pushed out, but the Clover DLC adds the Burglar Perk Deck which gives back much of what was lost, but some say not enough, the challenge and risk makes for more adrenaline so I am happy with it for now. There are so many gun mods I have at least 2 of every gun, typically 3 or 4 of the guns I like in different configurations for different missions and skill sets. As such the Cage Courier Pack is the first DLC anyone should get as it greatly expands options and works well with the all the weapons including the Community items, join the Payday 2 Steam Community as soon as you get this game then relaunch it to update it!. This is my first review so I am bit all over the place, but this game is so worth it, especially if you can get the GOTY edition for $40 or less. On a bad day of playing (or a bad couple of days) due to the bad people in the community, with the level you'll rage at the bullcrap, this game is almost a thumbs down. When the game first came out all the players seemed to hav a pro attitude which I miss, since then I have now built up a a good group of people I play this with so can always find some good action for scoring paydays, if you have a group of gamer mates you can get in to this with, you should all get in to it now!

One of the best co-op experiences. Ever. Its mechanics while brutal are for the most part refined and it's a blast to play with friends. Couple problems:  1) Graphically, this game's pretty mediocre. Lot of low res textures and what not.  2) If you don't have friends to play with, the game isn't really fun.  3) There's latency issues. Nothing major, but weird and a bit annoying.  4) The company's name perfectly encapsulates their approach to DLC. There are over 30 pieces and counting. The game isn't free to play and they're working on a sequel. Sort of BS right? And the DLC is sort of required to really enjoy this game. It's good on its own but the DLC is what makes it a lot better. Your arsenal is a lot more varied, you get more perk decks, new characters with fun voicing, etc. And the heists. You probably are going to really want these. Golden Grin, Goat Sim, Point Break, and Wolf Pack heists are all pretty good. My recommendation, have one member of your group buy all the heists and have him as the designated contract host. Still shouldn't be this way. Should've clumped DLC together and only released a couple packs a year.  This game is really fun and is held back by some poor decisions and poor support on Overkill's part. They have supported it, but it's costly support and it'll rack up quite the tab. Wait until a sale to get any DLC and if you're not sure if you want Payday 2, there's events where the game goes free to play temporarily. The game is tons of fun with friends and has a beautiful combination of action and strategy. One of the best games I own.

I suppose the developers have done it this way to keep people in the game, but the grind takes the enjoyment out of the game, you either grind a mission for cash, or another one for XP, or another for cards (unlocks come with cards). Your not actually playing and enjoying the game.  With the smaller selection of maps to play on, all with roughly the same style/gameplay you get bored quick, and once you can solo the hardest mission on the hardest difficulty you cave in, the game is boring, empty and a useless grind.

If you have burned down games like left 4 dead already (very likely by the way) and you are still looking for another coop game to put your hands on, you came to the right place.  This 4 player cooperation shooter has a similar formula than the previosly mentioned l4d using common guys and special units, such as the shield, the tazer, the bulldozer and the last one added but not the least important, the cloaker. This especial enemies can easily take down the players if they do not coop to outsmart them. But dont get me wrong this isn´t a mindless shooting game, cause in some missions where stealth is an option you may choose that sneaky way, wich is usually hard but most rewarding.  The game also features an inventory and skill based system, thanks to the first one you will be able to buy weapons with the money earned on previous heists, and also attach mods to them like increased magazines, silencers, flashlights, and many others. The skill system offers 4 different skill trees (Master mind, enforcer, tech, and ghost), and the player can invest the points he earns with each level on one of these 4, creating a unique character depending on the player playstyle.  Some free heists and weapons have already been added to the game, making the paid dlcs (mainly weapons) entirely optional.

Others have already said basically all that needs to be said about the microtransaction hell that Overkill has introduced.  What I want to talk about is Overkill's attitude towards the community, and their complete inability to keep promises.  Let's talk about a site called  pd2stats.com . pd2stats was a website made by a fan of the game, with no official support, that provided a wealth of information about the players. It was such a useful tool that HoxHud, one of the most widely-used (and I would argue essential) mods, provided direct links to pd2stats from within the game.  As of today, pd2stats is dead. Why? Because Overkill fell through on their promises. All that's left on pd2stats right now is a letter to the community. You can read the whole letter for yourself, but some key points:   'A few weeks ago, Overkill has promised Last Bullet [A payday modding site] to work together on making a new, much better, mod format for Payday 2. We discussed this once, then arranged another meeting. A day before this meeting, Overkill has cancelled it, indefinitely. Nothing happened on this matter since. A year ago we were promised that one of Last Bullet would be a moderator if at any point they would ever do a workshop. We were not informed of the recent workshop addition, nor were we offered a position in this recent workshop addition of any kind.'  'Another week passed, no replies, seemingly no one cares. And it turned out that Overkill does respond to other people about various matters. So this implies that they are on purpose ignoring this.'  Overkill repeats the same pattern over and over. Promise, ignore, go back on promise. Hell, we're still waiting on safehouse customization, and they promised that before the game even launched.  Anyway, the TL;DR is this: Payday 2 was tons of fun, and had a great community. Sadly, the developers' attitude towards the community and their inability to follow through or keep their promises means that there's no longer any trust, and I can't honestly promote a game that could be turned into a cash grab at any moment.  It only took two days to turn an amazingly fun game into a cash grab more blatant than Candy Crush.

This game is an interesting one, definitely different from most co-operative games in that your teammates actually have to co-operate with you in order to get things done, and the adrenaline really does start surging when your buddies have to help you fend off swarms of SWAT cops and FBI agents. The missions, while somewhat repetitive, keep themselves at least a little bit fresh by switching up where the objectives for certain parts of the mission so no two heists ever go down exactly the same.  However, there are a couple glaringly obvious problems with the game, such as the safehouse not actually being upgradable yet, despite Bain's reassurement that you'll be able to fix it up 'soon.' When is this? Half-Life 3 soon? Blizzard soon? Who knows. Also, the AI teammates are pretty much useless for anything except a bullet sponge or (a big)maybe occasionally a revival. They can't set a drill, fix said drill, carry a bag, or be told to do anything except 'HEALZ PLS!' or 'FOLLOW ME!' And finally, the enemy AI only wins with extremely overwhelming force, and glitches into/onto walls and apparently can shoot through said walls half the time. Lastly, some of the things that are DLC-exclusive really don't seem like they are worth paying even $1 for.  This all being said, this is a decent game if you have 2 or 3 friends to play it with that can actually co-operate and not just YOLO into every mission, and it's on sale when you buy it. I wish there was a sideways 'kinda' thumb for recommendations, because this game is deserving of it.

This is my first review so I'll try to keep it short.  If you like guns, co-op shooters, robbing banks with friends and killing the entire police population of Washington DC tenfold, this is the game for you. I've been playing this game since a little bit after release and I still keep coming back to it near daily.  A very good time (and money) sink with lots of base content, though many of the 'Meta' gear is locked behind DLC though OVERKILL has been working with the community to address these issue by adding free community content, grabbing everything on sale (50-75% off) is the best way to go about it though you don't need ALL the DLC, any missions can be played as long as your host owns it.  Most of the gripe comes from people not willing to pay money for DLC, though I own every piece of it, it's still possible to play on the highest difficulties with a vanilla game build. Micro transactions were also added which alienated a large portion of the community but I feel that OVERKILL has addressed this as well by changing up the system to remove the micro transactions part (other than the steam marketplace trading).  The amount of crossovers (John Wick, Point Break) and celebrity cameos seems to be drawing flak but I do like the addition of characters they are bringing to the game to mix things up, the Point Break DLC still is one of my favorites.  Overall I have to say Payday 2 is a great game and definitely worth the price tag, but if you would like to extend the amount of content and time you will be putting into this game, make sure to grab some DLC while it's on sale!

After the microtransaction crusade and the highly dissapointing Crimefest of 2015, I think it's time to redirect this review toward the game and not actually against the devs. So here I re-write my review for perhaps the fourth time.  Payday 2. The Bank Robbing Game That Robs You.  Before I can even properly review this game, I have to talk about it's DLCs, that which you probably heard that it has an astonishly (too) high amount of them. I'd like to say that this game (That you have to buy to play) is not pay to win, but that would be too easy.   If you want to have fun and experience a more convenient gameplay, you WILL HAVE to buy some DLCs, and I have to remind you that each usually cost about a 5th to a 4th of the game (4.99$ to 7.99$) Weapons such as most sniper rifles and ballistic weapons like grenade/rocket launcher (yes, this is still a ''Bank robbing'' game) or basically making the shotgun-weapons type usefull by unlocking a selection of various ammunition types (Looking at you, HE Rounds and Flechettes). Same with some Perk Decks that have totally unbalanced the way of this game, like Burglar for Stealth, Grinder for Run-n-Gunners, or even get a freaking game that not everyone may like just for one character pack (I'm sorry Jacket, you're just no that that appealing to me.)  -Luckily- Overkill let most of the DLCs with a decent price during sales of any kinds, making them sometimes less than 2$, so if you are going to buy this game and the DLC's, do the smart move, and buy them during a sale. Our wallets have already bled enough, we do not need to drown in the financial blood of the new arrivals of heisters.  For the game now.  Payday 2: Drill Fixing Simulator - Steam Edition This game takes an interesting spin at RPG-FPS games by allowing you to modify how you play with skills of different varieties, such as carrying an ammo bag or medic bag like in the first game, but also specializing yourself in different types of weapons. For more ''Technical'' skills, you can get the ability to carry C4 charges to open doors and safes faster than a drill would (Otherwise, use a faster drill) . If you like the stealthy approach; you can lockpick faster and use more ''quiet'' ways to open doors faster, like an ECM jammer for electronic security doors or master lockpicking if you want to open a safe (otherwise, use a drill.) or doors faster.  Tailor your own gameplay. Play in a team of four (Preferrably with friends.)  Now grab your guns, and realise that your guns are utterly awful. That's right, when you start, you have the lowest of the low in term of firearms. You look at your friend who introduced you to the game, killing cops without even taking a second to aim, while you need three headshots to take down one guy. Well, do not worry. As you level up, you unlock the right to buy and use new firearms, and as you play, you can unlock modifications for these to make them even more efficient.  Payday 2: Crook Simulator  That's right. Everyone in this game is a crook. Either in a good way as they will do everything they can for the job to go according to plan, or as they will be the most devilish ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, and pull a Joker on you, and by that I mean... kicked at the end of the job.   Overall? an okay game. I like it, ignoring all th elatest controversies.

Payday 2 is a Co-op shooter where you try and stealthily rob a bank, but end up running round fighting off waves of Police with itsy bitsy silenced pistols in a kevlar waistcoat.  Except what makes this game great is that once you succeed a mission, you can use the money you robbed to buy new weapons, modifications, masks and skills. It uses the perfectly fitting mechanics of slightly open ended heist missions and RPG elements like skill trees and levels to create an experience like no other.   The graphical fidelity is quite good; the animations and texture quality are above average, but nothing mind blowing. The sound quality isn't bad and the police AI, whilst on their own fairly easy and slightly stupid are formiddable enemies and can easily overwhelm a robber in numbers if he is not cautious.   A criticism I can make is that you will be playing missions multiple times, because making loads of them is hard however I never found myself getting bored by them. The game uses a clever system where certain things are randomized i.e vault locations, safe locations, keycard location, guard numbers and patrol routes, etc. So you can play a mission twice and be surprised by something there that is subtlely different.   On the actual gameplay, a hell of alot of what you're doing is guarding drills as they open safes. The safes have timers and occaisionally have to be unjammed so that you don't go running off to a small room to hide in. Once you open the safes or whatever, you will be moving bags of miscellanious loot to an escape location, this gets very tense as it is usually done under heavy enemy fire. Alot of people die during this and it becomes a choice of escaping or going back for that last bag of loot. This decision can make or break a heist.   And then there's running out of ammo, taking hostages, the stealth aspect and much more. Such as mask customization.   I have made lots of friend playing this game, and I highly reccomend you use a mic for communication between fellow players because teamwork is key to winning this game.   - Pyro

A very fun co-op shooter with leveling and a massive amount of customisation available. When I first started, closer to when it was released, I enjoyed the game - but there were many, many issues that took fun out of it. It took a long time to level up without repeating a few specific heists over and over again (Rats, anybody?), there was a lack of variety in the heists, and buying new gear was unforgiving with the way cash was split back then.  Now, most of my issues with the game are solved: it is much less grindy, with many more jobs available, and the amount of content overall has been increased hugely, to the point where I am nearing the maximum level currently available and I'm still nowhere near bored of it. The variety in difficulties available (both in the heists themselves and the difficulty settings) means there is always a new way to challenge yourself (for the vast majority of people).  There are still some problems  - I think it is now   too   easy to level, as many people level 100+ have no idea what they are doing  - there are quite a few hackers that can really ruin the fun of beating the harder jobs  - some weapons are just not as viable as others, and this only gets worse with deathwish difficulty where most people only use a few different guns  - pirchasing all the dlc is expensive unless it's on sale - the game still suffers from some instability issues.  Overall though, I think the pros outweigh the cons by a mile.  If you have any friends that like coop games, get this, and have them get it too, as playing with friends is what makes it really great (as opposed to just pretty good). Also, remember to start small with your heists - I know you may think your crack team of 4 buddies can do an overkill bank heist loud, but until you have actual experience (and decent gear/skills) you will find it not worth the effort, as low level (<20) players get much less exp from harder jobs, and you may fail multiple times. One of the best co-op experiences. Ever. Its mechanics while brutal are for the most part refined and it's a blast to play with friends. Couple problems:  1) Graphically, this game's pretty mediocre. Lot of low res textures and what not.  2) If you don't have friends to play with, the game isn't really fun.  3) There's latency issues. Nothing major, but weird and a bit annoying.  4) The company's name perfectly encapsulates their approach to DLC. There are over 30 pieces and counting. The game isn't free to play and they're working on a sequel. Sort of BS right? And the DLC is sort of required to really enjoy this game. It's good on its own but the DLC is what makes it a lot better. Your arsenal is a lot more varied, you get more perk decks, new characters with fun voicing, etc. And the heists. You probably are going to really want these. Golden Grin, Goat Sim, Point Break, and Wolf Pack heists are all pretty good. My recommendation, have one member of your group buy all the heists and have him as the designated contract host. Still shouldn't be this way. Should've clumped DLC together and only released a couple packs a year.  This game is really fun and is held back by some poor decisions and poor support on Overkill's part. They have supported it, but it's costly support and it'll rack up quite the tab. Wait until a sale to get any DLC and if you're not sure if you want Payday 2, there's events where the game goes free to play temporarily. The game is tons of fun with friends and has a beautiful combination of action and strategy. One of the best games I own.

Okay Ramblers, let's get Ramblin'!  Payday 2 is probably the best thing since the evolution of FPS gaming or since Betty Flintstone had a Bird Tablet typewriter.  Backing it up a bit, Payday 2 plays on a few gaming elements: randomization, risk vs reward and crisis management. This is pretty much a co-op heist game with a twist. There are so many elements to cover, I won't even scratch the surface here. However, if you are a solo kinda player, you can also enjoy Payday 2 with stealth. In fact, stealth is encouraged on some maps where its possible. There is a bit of a learning curve to start with other than knowing where the enemies are at any given time but, once you have that under your belt, fortune favors the brave and you will need to bring your balls of steel to pull of big heists successfully. And then, you need to survive. There are 5 levels of difficulty to start with: Normal, Hard, Very Hard, Overkill and Deathwish. They are aptly and correctly labelled for your levelling pleasure, as you gain XP and money for weapons, mods, etc. The hardest part on ANY game mode is not being too greedy and knowing when to bail. Then, once you get to level 100, you can gain an infamy level. Think Prestiege for you Call of Duty types and you have an idea. However, Infamy brings better rewards and much better paydays. Does a $24M payday sound awesome? Well, you have to work for it.  If you play the Demo and you keep hungering for more once you have mastered that, then get the game and DLC ASAP!  Payday 2 has me hooked and is very addictive. Can be frustrating if you rush it. Patience is a virtue here. Also, trying to remember where things are: cameras, civilians, enemies to aviod, locked doors, etc.  The community is VERY active, alive and passionate about this game and rightly so. Overkill has done a great job here and keeps listening to the community. One of the VERY FEW devs that still pay attention to their fanbase.  I have absolutely NO hesitation in recommending this game to anyone and if you have friends on steam, up to 4 players can play at a time. Or you can PUG it, whichever.  I haven't even begun to scratch the surface here (70+ hours in < 2 weeks as of this review) and it still draws me in. Get some Payday 2 action today!

However, after the recent relase of stat-changing lootdrop weapons, i am the most dissapointed.  CSGO was MADE around the concept of having crates and weapon skins. And i was NOT happy when TF2 did it, since the hat economy was fine and i really liked the way weapons worked. Their lastest update only made it seem like they REALLY wanted to capitalize on the money from CSGO skins that there already is, wich i really disagree on.  But this? Not only this seems like a cashgrab, but if you honestly put a lot of money into buying crates and 'drills' (keys) You can actually find stats upgrades for your guns. Not related to skills, upgrades, or anything. Just cards that you get for paying. This, while not EXACTLY a 'Pay 2 Win' service, is scratching the surface of it, even after the devs claimed at game relase that they would never even dare to make the game P2W.  Even i acknowledge that this idea would hurt more on games like TF2 or CSGO since they are PvP, but the idea that the game just makes the game easier depending on how much money you throw at the devs (and this was true just with the DLC) is a statement to how Overkill has gone to ♥♥♥♥ with DLC. Adding light machineguns meant making sure that players cannot use drum magazines for their rifles again, so that they are forced to buy their DLC. This has been going on with the game for 2 years, from weapon packs like the medieval and western ones providing with cool but unnecesary guns that you didn't had to get, but you could if you wanted interesting challenges and to look great, to providing DLC that would make the game far easier (like the sniper pack, wich would bring a sniper weapon that could kill skulldozers in less than 3 shots) and it would make the job harder for those who dont have the DLC. The relase of Grenades, Molotovs, Dynamite, and so on as DLC is only more concrete evidence that Overkill is just unaware of what makes a good DLC. This has lead to seeing how DLC melee weapons are over 3/4 of the weapons of that category, and having 1/2 of the primary weapons (usually the best) behind, also, DLC.   I didn't think Overkill was trying to do this just for the sake of being money grabbers, but i think they just dont know how to make DLC, and instead of trying to figure out what makes a good DLC, they just keep making more. These Stat-changing cards for weapons are the cherry on top of the cake. Actually selling items that upgrade your weapon.   Its a shame to see how bad the game has gotten ever since it got relased, back when your biggest complaints was your unavailability to move hostages and the fact that customizable safe houses was a relase-date promised feature (AND HOLY ♥♥♥♥! THEY STILL HAVEN'T ADDED THAT!) If you've ever wanted to feel like a master criminal with three of your friends, Payday 2 is the game for you. Keeping the four player heist action from the first game, it improves on some of the features from the first game, like talent trees to customize your play style and stealth missions, while bringing in some new aspects, like weapon and mask customization. However, the game has been lacking on 'grand' heists like the ones from the first game until the recent release of the Big Bank DLC. But anyone can play the DLC missions without buying them as long as someone in the game lobby has bought it, which is one of the fairest DLC policies I've seen. On top of that, there are also a few heists, like Shadow Raid and Election Day, which are completely free! This game is definitely worth picking up if you have a few friends to play with, especially when it goes on sale.

Payday 2. Payday. 2. Where to start, eh?   I love this game, as anyone who knows me can tell you. I play it quite often, and have worked hard to make sure friends have it as well, even if they hate it. It's everything I've ever wanted in a co-op FPS, from the killer soundtrack, to the tight gunplay. Every weapon type feels so different, and each weapon in the archetypes is unique as well, which is a hard feat, considering how often weapons are added. The classes all have uses, varying from sneaky silent stabbing to decimating the police force in DC with very, very large guns. Maps are reused sometimes, notably the four different heists that set their stage at the same bank, but I've personally never had an issue with it, considering how often I vary between stealth and loud play. A lot of the vanilla game heists are a bit small in size, but a few are rather crazy, and DLCs top them very easily. Now, I know DLC is often frowned upon, but Overkill has gone out of their way to accomodate for people without money. Anyone can heist, no matter the heist, since clients can join DLC maps free of charge, and only miss out on cosmetics and one or two new weapons. The characters are sometimes bland, but I've loved them since release, from the classic sound of Wolf's psychotic screaming, or Dallas calling everyone 'buddy', to the new friends we've made, Houston and his love of food, and John Wick's enjoyment of the number 1. In short, it's not a game for everyone. But if you have a group of friends you enjoy, or don't mind meeting some, Payday 2 is a brilliant game, with many hundreds of hours worth of playtime waiting for your crew to tackle.   Take care, and keep those helmets flying! -Chi

Payday 2 is a blast, but if you haven't played it with your friends, then you haven't played it!  The AI teammates, while not horrible, are kind of limited. Sure, they'll shoot at enemies and pick you up, but they won't subdue civilians or crack that safe for you, so real people are key. Nothing like you and three of your homies throwing on your masks at the same time and doing what needs to be done. Learning the missions can be time consuming and fun, but there's nothing like a 5 minute mission with max loot and no cops. Having friends to manage guards, civilians, alarms, cameras, safes, doors, or anything else you need is what makes this game great. I've been lucky enough to have an enthusiastic (and artistic) crowd controller, a heavy armor/guns that never stealths (he likes to chill across the street in full gear until needed), a ghost that can walk through the buildings and find what we need while marking what to avoid, and myself the safe/door cracker. Combine those roles with some great dialogue and humor and you've got an entire weekend that never gets dull.  Payday has also done an excellent job of providing a full game while enticing you to buy more. You can purchase weapon packs that do not give you the weapons, but allows you to earn them. Same goes even more so with masks. There are a variety of masks to wear and each can be customized with patterns, colors, and materials, and all of that (masks and customizers) has to be earned from post-heist rewards. The post-heist rewards are also how to earn weapon customizations, such as stocks, barrels, grips, scopes, and more, they've got achievement based unlocks that just add that much more, and they sell mission packs that allow you to host new and different heists, but if you don't have the pack and a friend does, you can still play with them on that heist as long as they host! Brilliant!  So if you like socializing, strategizing, smashing, and grabbing then there's a good chance this game is for you. If you don't like to earn your upgrades or you don't play well with others, then you might want to pass on this one.  TL;DR - This game is fun if you're not alone and you like grinding for gear and upgrades.

One bug is where you throw grenades, molotovs, or use grenade launcher, only to hit the invisible walls near you, and then you get damaged, burned, killed, and not able to damage the enemies around you. Played Santa's Workshop for two hours, with 135 bags solo, only for team bots to glitch, and not able to walk upstairs to revive me, after a cloaker glitched as well, kicking me down as it was floating up against the wall. Another annoying glitch is where you play the Golden Grin Casino heist on stealth, were sometimes the cops can glitch and spot you through the wall many feet away, after you spend a lot of time into the game of course. Then I decided to try Santa's workshop again, restarting about 30 times, so the elves wouldn't be upstairs to avoid the glitch, then another glitch popped up were my armor was taking about 20 seconds to regenerate, when it should have been regenerating every 5 seconds when not getting damaged. Of course, failed again because of another glitch, and then lost my 25% exp bonus for quitting, just to make sure that I had my armorer deck, and all regenerating armor skills, to find out that I did. Be nice if they had more helpful skills for the one down difficulty, besides the messiah skill, when all you are doing is constantly going down, and relying on luck to get automatically revived to beat the heist, without running out of charges. The infamy tree is mostly lame, and could be better offering more different rewards, like improving more skills to help you stand a chance against the one down difficulty, than mostly exp boosts and a few masks. A XXV infamous rank should be better than a V infamous rank. The weapons should be balanced, not always the same powerful bows, crossbows, snipers, and grenade launchers, just to beat the higher difficulties. PAYDAY 2 is my most played game on steam, and definitely one of my favourite games of all time, that being said I would give this game an 8/10. Although the previous sentence may seem like a contradiction, 'How could it be one of your favourite games of all time and only give it an 8/10', well the answer is simple, the price.  Dlc/Microtransactions:  Now, I have no problem paying for dlcs, but there's a certain point where it gets a bit ridiculous, again, I'm fine paying $5 every 1 or 2 months for some dlc, I mean, it's cheaper than Netflix, but when they start adding things like 'ak/car mod pack', I feel like they are grasping at straws for unique dlcs, I mean come on, it adds like 8 mods, how is that worth real money?  My personal feelings aside, for new players, it isn't a montly fee, it's a down payment, and a hefty one at that, $100+ dollars. If any new players want to get all the dlc I would recommend waiting for a sale, or buy them on ♥♥♥ at about half the price (I have always bought them while on sale). However, that is still $50 and this is the main problem I have with this game, how much money is required to play the full game.  This was only worsened by the release of the black market skin update, a system that not only added microtransactions but also gave the skins you bought with microtransaction a chance to have a stat boost. This was later rectified, but it still happened, and it really seemed like a huge cash grab. They still have skins, but they are acquired for free in game, and don't require keys to open the boxes anymore.  Game:  In my opinion, the game is amazing, there is a lot of replayability (with dlc) and it is even better with friends, the game has grown so much since launch, they have added 12 characters, and many maps, such as: robbing a moving train, stealing warheads, stealing money from a rave, jumping out of a plane to catch cash, stealing goats with coke inside, looting during an earthquake, cooking endless (yes literally) amounts of meth, breaking someone out of prison then killing the person who put him there and even a mission where you have thugs dressed in elf costumes pack cocaine for you, so you can throw it down a chimney to secure it (also goes as long as you can last).  Over time they have also added many free weapons, some even better than dlc weapons, such as the white streak and baby deagle, as well as many free characters including: John Wick, the hitman from the movie John Wick, Bonnie, a Scottish version of big boo from Orange is the New Black, Hoxton, one of the original fan favourites of the first game, Bodhi, the leader of the ex-presidents and professional surfer bro from the movie Point Break, and Jimmy the coke hungry savage from Hardcore Henry. All the free content almost makes up for the dlc... almost.  However, the absolute best feature of this game, is the sound. The music is phenomenal, and really creates an intense atmosphere for any situation and you can even create your own playlist of songs in the sound menu. The guns are also great, the noise they make and overall the sheer amount of them is amazing. Shotguns can even be loaded with different types of ammo which imapact the mechanics of the gun (Shotgun DLC only).  Conclusion:  I really wish I could give it a 10/10 but due to the DLC and microtransactions, I can't, for each of these I have docked 1 point leaving the total at 8/10, the game is fantastic and definitely worth it, especially if you have a friend that has all of the DLCs or just friends that have the game as well.   tl;dr:  Game is great, dlc is expensive, microtransactions were a mistake, later corrected.  Happy Heisting :)   A message to new players:  - Please remember these tips if you are a new player, in stealth, when you kill a guard you   have to hold f on his dead body, or else the pager operator will know he's dead, you can only   do this 4 times.   - You can shoot open wood and metal doors that have glass on them, not the solid steel ones.   - You can be detected with your mask off if you bump into a guard.  - Shooting cameras, will cause a guard to go check what's wrong with it.  - Compensators and Flash hiders don't silence your guns, only suppressors do.  - Please ask if it's stealth before you join, and if it is, ask if it's ok to join before you do   because you might spawn in a bad spot and cause the mission to fail.  - Inspire is an ability that allows you to instantly revive teammates from a distance, it isn't  hacking  - Feign death and messiah are both abilities that allow the user to revive themselves, this also   isn't hacking  - Swan song is an ability that allows the user to walk around for 9 seconds with infinite ammo  before they go down, their health will appear empty, but this is also not hacking  - Don't kick someone because they are hacking, unless you've asked them if they are hacking,  then if they make something up, or say they are, then kick them.   - Progressing is the fun of this game, don't let hackers boost your level to XXV-100 (max level).  - Roman numerals represents an infamy level (prestige if you play COD), don't assume  someones worse because their level is XXV-10, that isn't level ten that's level 2510.  - Don't be an abusive host, don't kick people if they're a higher level and not listening to you,   just listen to them and they might teach you something, if someone is being an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥   however, feel free to kick him right before the escape :D

Genre: FPS/Crime 8/10  Story/Gameplay: Not much of a story in the Payday universe. You're part of a crew of robbers who are hired by contractors to pull of heists for money. The heists differ in difficulty and how long they can go on for. Some heists can be done in a matter of a few minutes to getting close to 40 minutes. All depending if things go well of course, which they most likely won't. If you're a beginner to Payday, play with some experienced friends. Not only will they teach you the best combinations of weapons and what to do during heists, but also leveling up and gaining money will be a lot easier.  Visuals: Payday 2 is a huge step above from Payday: The Heist. The visuals are much more moderned and detailed. Masks look great, weapons look great and each have their own reload animations, maps look great. Hell even the gloves on your hands look great. GEM mod enhancement for Payday 2 gives some more detail to the game all while removing some annoying features that may give you a slight headache from the base game. Using the mod is allowed by Overkill and you won't be banned from the Payday 2 community group.  Sounds / Voice Acting: Not much to say besides the game sounds absolutely amazing. Each weapon has their own sounds and the quality is fantastic. Sounds of gunfire differ incredibly from being indoors or outside or even far from where a gunfight is going on. Voice acting is also great, nothing sounds awkward and each character has different lines to give them their own unique personality.  For 30 dollars, this is definitely a great game to buy. When it's on sale down to 10 dollars or so, it's a MUST BUY. There are some DLC that add weapons and new heists to the game along with new masks. It's all on you if you want to buy them or not. Don't worry though, you can still play these heists! Overkill is pretty great that they allowed it so even if you do not have these dlc heists, you can still play with friends who are hosting the new heists. Quickly take note that I haven't played any PAYDAY 2 within the past two weeks due to being busy and lazy most of my time, but I do keep up to date on the news that OVERKILL puts out.  I've enjoyed PAYDAY 2 since its release, yet I am very inconsistent with playing it, same with other games I own due to doing other things with my spare time. But here's my review and thoughts of recent and past events.  PAYDAY 2's release was hyped and for very good reason. It had all the features the original game didn't have, had amazing graphics and different mechanics within each of the heists and lots of customization which every gamer loves doing and was a big step up from the first game.  (I wont talk about this next paragraph a whole lot as it does get boring and we all knew that this was the golden age for PAYDAY 2)  PAYDAY 2 was soaring through the Hot Sellers tab on the store and was doing positively well with mini updates, almost endless new DLC updates, hotfixes and bug fixes for the next two years and almost everyone who had the game knew this, and OVERKILL was walking down the correct path for a successful game (which it was and still is) and kept on looking for things to release and show the community with the passion they had.  Whilst walking down the path of success OVERKILL tripped over a set of rocks spelling out the word... 'micro-transactions'.  The Black Market/micro-transaction update from last years crimefest was very very disappointing, releasing skins and mods to try make a bit more money on top of all the DLC that OVERKILL was creating at that time which was between £2 - £5/$3 - $6 which people only really bought on sale as it went down by 75% for such a better deal. Pitchforks went to OVERKILL's necks and asked why they did this update on such a great game that didn't even need micro-transactions, reddit threads and gaming news reporters went crazy over it publishing the update wherever and whenever they had the chance.  What made this so disappointing and was one of the main things that annoyed people about the update was that all the grinded hours people put into this game, was all wasted for a couple of coins and notes from their own, or parents bank accounts or maybe some sold their CSGO skins for PAYDAY skins or just had some money leftover in their steam wallet. All in all it was devastating that grinded hours went to waste.  It was a down low for OVERKILL, for the next 7-8 months they saw many of its players uninstall the game, un-favorited it from their steam library or just left it with blue text saying 'update queued' and they was not doing anything about it. For me however I still enjoyed it and so did everyone who ignored the update, but the game did feel like a big part of it was taken out. Less players to play the game with, more people showing off their skins (which some are nice don't get me wrong) and from my personal experience, a lot more hackers which eventually killed all the fun I had for the game and eventually sadly uninstalled it.  With losing many players and fans and getting negative reviews almost everywhere on the internet about the update, OVERKILL had done what the fans never dreamed or wanted. However...  With update 100's release near the start of June, the nightmare of micro-transactions turned into a dream full of free stuff and bonuses and OVERKILL have re-gained the trust of the community, became independent by buying the IP from 505 Games and once again, became a badass game with a lot more new players.  Opening safes will be free, items inside and the safes themselves are all still available to purchase, sell and trade but it does save you the extra 2ish dollars. Would of been cool to have all the items non sell-able but then the people who have actually bought skins/safes/drills with their own money would of gone to waste and I totally understand this action.  Additionally OVERKILL said that they are working hard to make PAYDAY 2 what it was again and i'm looking forward to seeing what they are going to create for us in the future.  OVERKILL salutes us, and the community salutes you!   Oh and should you buy the game? In my opinion yes, and the community's opinion... Yes.

Is it good or bad?

Payday 2 is pretty solid as far as co-op games go.The satisfaction afforded by completing a lot of the more difficult heists is tremendous, especially when attempting the alternate routes of certain heists by doing it via stealth. Playing this game with three other friends is definitely a lot of fun and the amount of customization is fairly extensive for this sort of game. However, the grinding aspect kills a lot of the longevity of the game if you want to invest a lot of time into it. Unlocking customization items like masks and gun parts is largely dependent on post-mission RNG, so being able to really kit out a favorite gun could be an egregiously long process given the odds of a specific gun part dropping for you. Additionally, since the differences between rushing heists and 100%ing them or stealthing them are negligible in terms of benefits (despite recent patches that alter this slightly), a lot of the uniqueness and novelty of completing some of the missions fades away very quickly when you reach the ~60ish player rank due to having to grind so much.  The combination of having to repeat certain reward-heavy missions to progress within the endgame of player level and the diminishing returns (and, ergo, satisfaction) of the actual fun parts of the game makes the game somewhat of a chore if you really want to sink a lot of time into this game.  If you're looking for a game to play with friends once in a while, Payday 2 is great. There's a solid amount of free and paid DLC that comes out fairly regularly. Definitely worth it if it's on sale. But if you're really looking for something to sink your teeth into over a long period of time, be aware of the downright offensive amounts of grinding and RNG necessary to really get all up ins on this game can be more than a little off-putting.

Earning money has never been this fast!...  The revamp is quite important since the first game. If you keep the four now infamous members of the crew (Dallas, Chains, Hoxton and Wolf), your goal (get the money, ha ha!), and your enemies (except the Blooper) the rest of the game is pretty much different. In both ways.  On the good part, the leveling system is now based on experience instead of money. When leveling up, you unlock guns and skill points, which you can spend in the four skill trees. Weapons are very customizable, as now are masks. You can become pretty much any heister you want. Weapon customization has an impact on your gun as well as your discretion. The detection feature is well done, the alarm can be triggered for more reason that just someone putting his mask somewhere on the map: criminal spotted, gun shot eared, dead body found... Heists can now last several days, each days involving a different place and a different mission. In some cases, an escape event can also be triggered, in which you have to fight the police until your next escape car comes in, which adds some variety and challenge.  On the bad side, several improvements come with a non negligible downside. The most important would be that weapon attachments and mask parts are rewarded at random, during the Payday scene finishing a heist. This means you often need to play many, many heists before putting your hands on the component you are looking for. Concerning heists, they are pretty simple overall: get in, get the money/jowels/diamonds/frames, get out. And survive until the escape comes in. That's quite a difference from the first game. Leveling is also partly interesting, since all guns are unlocked before the level 40. There are 100 levels... Furthermore, high level skills unlocks can make a heist a lot faster, allowing you to leave before serious enemies come in on most jobs, removing quite the challenge. Some equipment also allows you to stay almost undetected, though at the cost of defense and power.  On a personal note, i might add that those unlocks and equipment can be game breaking, in the sense the heists don't get appealing anymore. It has become common, for instance, on stealth heists, to wear the most concealable equipment, and commit suicide if things don't go as planned, which is stupid in my opinion. But that's my opinion.  And that's why i think there are better games to play, including the first Payday.

Payday 2 is a very special game. Sure, it's easy to look at the screen shots and videos of the game and have it screen 'meh' as a shooter, but it's oh so much more. In the game, you and up to three other people must plan and execute daring heists ranging from ripe jewelry stores, secure banks, seedy meth labs, and even daylight on the streets. It's you versus the law, and you'll need your wits, gadgets, and (in most cases) plenty of ammo to survive! The game features some random factors thrown in with varying layouts for each heist, plus lots and lots of fully customizable weapons. The game also gives you leeway on different ways to approach heists, either trying to be sneaky and not alert the authorities, or go guns blazing against an increasingly hardened police force. With 5 distinct difficulty levels ranging from 'normal' to 'death wish' and unlockable skill trees, and customizable masks you'll keep coming back for more. The only drawbacks to the game are that some of the later levels are a bit 'grindy' in that it takes a long time to level up, and the rewards system is almost completely random, but the game is intense and fun and you won't even start to care about those things after a while. A must buy!

Alright, that's it Overkill. Adding drills and safes, just end it. File for bankruptcy already, you milked the money out of us for microtransactions, DLC, and all that. Even though I still play this game, I still have a very strong hatred against it. I'd just suggest going back to PAYDAY: The Heist. Or, you know, you can just go to /r/paydayupdate78 and get Update 78 before the safes and drills.  Why do I keep coming back to this game? No idea. I'd compare it to Papyrus' spaghetti, it's bad but you keep coming back for more.  Original review:  PAYDAY 2 is a first person shooter that seems to be different from the latest shooters like Call of Duty or Team Fortress 2 where you run into a building and shoot everybody up and take the intelligence or hold a capture point. In PAYDAY 2, you are put into the shoes of one of the four members in a gang known as the PAYDAY gang. The goal of this game is to go into places such as the Benevolent Bank, a jewelry store, or just a regular bank, and get whatever they have, like cocaine or smuggled money.  This game takes place after PAYDAY: The Heist, which is also a great game. Let's start comparing a few aspects in PAYDAY 2 that weren't in PAYDAY: The Heist or were revised for PAYDAY 2.  First, this game has a better EXP system. Instead of getting cash or money items to level up, you actually have to complete missions to get experience. Oh, and the money? In PAYDAY: The Heist, the game automatically unlocks you the weapons you need once you get to a high enough point in the skill trees. In PAYDAY 2, you have to buy the weapons you want for missions, such as a rocket launcher, or a bow and arrow. The money can also be spent on skill trees, such as the 'Ghost' skilltree, which relies on stealth and dodging bullets, or the 'Enforcer' skilltree, which relies mainly on shotguns and run-and-gun combat. The money can ALSO be spent on mods for your weapons, such as a silencer for stealth missions, or amplifiers that modify your gun's damage and threat. Once you get to level 100 and get enough money into your 'offshore bank account' you can become infamous, which gives you benefits such as putting a spades symbol when you speak in chat.  Next, PAYDAY: The Heist's missions are all unique from each other and you can pick them with ease, without trying to hassle the player into buying them in any way, shape, or form. In PAYDAY 2, you need to wait for all of the missions to appear on the map screen and select the one you think will suit your needs. If you don't want to wait, you can use a contract broker to buy contracts. All of the missions in PAYDAY 2 are all unique from each other and they are constantly updating the game to fix bugs and also add new missions, such as the 'Alesso Heist' where you go into an arena run by a security company named GENSEC and you have to break into their investment safes, whilst using Alesso's concert as cover.  Finally, PAYDAY: The Heist has two missions where you can stealth, one named the Diamond Heist where you go into a skyscraper and steal precious diamonds, and Undercover, where you go into a criminal's house and steal fake money plates. In PAYDAY 2, they have a mix of loud missions and stealth missions, which is what I'd love to see in games like this, where you can pick what you do in the mission.  Moving on, let's get on with the bad things with this game.  First, this game can be riddled with bugs, such as the narrator/radio guy (also known as Bain) can constantly say the same things over and over and over again, the AI can get tased and get stuck being tased, the enemy known as a 'Cloaker' can 1-hit KO you through walls, if you get handcuffed with a magnum, the handcuffs will still be on your hands even after being freed, jumping on the helicopter while it goes into the air will send you going into the air, and a lot of more anomalies.  Sometimes, farming missions isn't going to cut it with experience. Although it's better than putting in forced microtransactions, sometimes doing the most experience-wealthy mission(s) like 'Hoxton Breakout' or 'Cook Off', sometimes it can give you as low as 2 or 3 levels. PAYDAY 2 is one of the most entertaining first person shooters I've ever played, curbstomping the brown and gray brigade that constitutes modern military FPSes,  It's a four player co-op, but cast aside any comparisons to Left 4 Dead as the games are widely diffrent. PAYDAY 2 has you take part in various heists performed by the titular PAYDAY gang. Those can involve anything from something as simple as shooting up an armored truck convoy to steal the goodies to breaking into an art gallery to sell paintings to a corrupt senator, in which you install cameras to monitor his apartament to which you'll be breaking into.  Majority of missions allow you to either approach them stealthily (Taking down security measures, controling the crowd in whatever place you are currently in and making as little noise as possible) or go in guns blazing, fending off waves of increasingly badass cops as you try to complete the heist. The soundtrack is simple, loud, pumping and aggresive techno beats (Worthy of a soundtrack digital download)during combat and subdued simple beats during quiet moments. The graphics are farm from great, but bright color palette and excellent art direction make for a very good experience.  Guns handle very well and the sound effects are immensely satisfying.  There's also a quasi RPG system with four classes, various weapons and upgrades, customisable masks (which are the staple of the gang), and overall feel invoking movies like The Heat... Not much else to say but... Let's get rich.

Overkill's fanbase of 'heisters' was once very loyal and had a strong bond with the developers, but changes in development staff have altered the game's vision and direction for the worse, angering the community surrounding it. PAYDAY 2 was at one point a great game, but it peaked a long time ago. I'm not sure there's any coming back.  For those of you who haven't followed any of the PAYDAY 2 drama, here's why a lot of the community gave up on the game:     Over-reliance on DLC content to support development of the game, many of which are shameless cross-promotional tie-ins that don't even make sense within the established universe of the game world they're building (John Wick and Point Break are believable tie-ins. Goat Simulator and Hardcore Henry are absolutely NOT).    The insertion of micro-transactions. This angered many players, especially when you consider that the developers themselves specifically said they wouldn't include this kind of system in their game because of the effect it's had on other games. When said system was implemented in 2015, it was presented as a 'reward' to the community for their efforts to help build the player base. The fanbase was instantly divided amongst the hardcore followers of the development team and the players who loved the game the way it was, In 2016, the rights to the PAYDAY franchise returned to Overkill Software, and the decision to include micro-transactions was reversed, or at least altered so that players could get the items in these packages for free, following an apology from Almir himself. However, the reputation of the game and its dev team was already tarnished, and the community never had the same, close-knit relationship between the people playing the game and the people making the game.    The game is lacking in many ways, including basic features. The game's own developers encourage players to download mods to enhance their heads-up displays in ways that the base game should have provided from the beginning. Even some simple animations were missing up until recently, like the animation for jumping.   While I've enjoyed the game for a very long time (over 500 hours at the time of this writing), I just can't muster the will to care any more about the game or the new things coming from it. Play it with friends if it's heavily discounted, but don't hope for greatness.  Also, it's worth noting that console players that were promised updates for their versions of the game got shafted, with the devs flat-out ignoring that audience and in some cases, actually telling them to 'buy the PC version'.

This game is basically Left 4 Dead 2, with cops instead of zombies, an rpg style progression system, upgradeable weapons and customisable masks. The levels are mostly horde mode defense maps with stealth options at higher levels.   Pros: Payday shines brightest when you have a well coordinated team of high level characters with complimentary builds, the stealth is tense, as you sneak between guards and cameras trying not to set off alarms. When things go loud, the shoot outs are exhilerating, the music pumps hard as waves of tougher and tougher special enemies appear from every direction, kicking in doors and jumping through windows to get to your crew.  Cons: It can be really hard to get started as a new player. The stealth requires higher level skills and randomly dropped mods to be feasible, and even then there is never a peaceful option, and no stealth rewards, The skills are very interesting, but half of them are useless, and others are very over powered. The biggest downside is the limited number of complex maps, particularly at endgame, which makes it kind of grindy if you want to max out everything and get all the best stuff.   Summary: If you like co-op shooters with stealth and rpg elements, then this is a really fun game. it has a few rough edges in places, but it looks and plays like an AAA game, which is an amazing achievement for such a small indie company. It certainly kept me captivated for a long time, and I'll definately be checking out any expansions down the line. My one suggestion is to bring friends and play together.

PAYDAY 2 was one of the games that I've been wanting to get the most in 2013.  Similar to its prequel, PAYDAY 2 is a first-person shooter heist game where you rob banks, jewelry stores and other places with bots, your friends or complete strangers.   Firstly, there are many ways to do heists. You can either go stealthy, avoid alarms and avoid fighting cops. Or you can go loud and clear with everything you got if you trust your and your fellow teammates' skills. There are overall four different special skill trees that you can pick and upgrade as you play: the Mastermind, the Enforcer, the Ghost and the Technician. Upgrading different skill trees will grant you different abilities and items that can be useful for the heists. Teamwork is essential in this game as it determines how the heist progresses. I suggest to play this game more with friends than strangers for a better teamwork and experience. After getting your money that you got from a heist, you can spend it on weapons, mods and even masks.  However, I wouldn't say this game is always fun. One of the most notable issue of this game is that there aren't many heists so the game is kind of repetitive and feels it's lacking more heists. Although, the creators of PAYDAY 2 sometimes add new heists to the game, however, it pops up yet another issue. One of the annoying issues people have is almost constant updates. This game is already over 29GB and often updates, which annoys some players that aren't used to big updates.  Overall, I still suggest people to buy and play this game if they like teamwork and first-person shooter games.  + Cooperative + Challenging + Customizable  - Repetitive  8.6/10

(Please note before we start, that this is purely my opinion)   Payday 2 is a great Fast Paced Shooter which evolves around robbing/heisting banks, various stores, thug/mercenary hideouts and more. The game offers great maps, multiplayer, weapons, weapon-attachments, replay value and Masks. Don't forget the Masks!   Maps: The Maps in Payday 2 have great replay value and over-all look great. With each new time you play, certain mission-related objects change around, for example doors, loot and of course enemy A.I. so you don't get the same old crap every time.  Characters: The characters in Payday 2 mainly go by nationality, which is pretty cool in that the game has loads of diversity and add's even more replay value. Accents may be a problem with some people, but that usually ends off ok, hence there are loads of other characters to choose from which can be purchased or sometimes added for free in free content packs. Weapons: There are LOADS of weapons to choose from in Payday 2. Shotguns, Snipers, Pistols, Smg's, Assault rifles.. even a Minigun for mass cop murder! and if that's not enough, you can customize them with different weapon-attachments to change the way you play with that weapon. Again, adding more ways to play.  Masks: Masks are a huge part of Payday 2, mainly cosmetic feature, but they go further than that, it's what keeps you from getting enclosed behind metal bars! You can customize your mask to what suits you most, or well, do whatever the hell you want with it apart from drawing a ♥♥♥♥ on it (They have their boundries of course, haha). To do this, you can choose from ton's of different materials, colours and patterns to change the way your Mask looks, which is really cool. You can also buy Mask slots to increase the capacity of Masks you are aloud to have at once in your inventory, so, the more Masks the better, right?   Downsides: There's only two problems I find about this game, the friendly A.I. and the graphics.  Friendly A.I. The A.I. you get in single player jobs or multiplayer jobs where there are less than four people are dog-♥♥♥♥. To make up for this, they're given a lot more health than usual players, however they are unable to equip any other armour or weaponary. Most of the time they are meh, an get the job done when say you get downed or become your bullet-sponge, but that's it. And quite often, they barely revive you, They might start halfway and just give-up to fight like one enemy or something, Or in the worst-case scenario, they glitch and not come for you at all, ending in a mission failure on single-player.  Graphics: The graphics in this game are debatable, but in my opinion they're outdated a bit. This is more nit-picky though as I don't care about graphics too much, more about gameplay, but they could be better. However the company who made this game is fairly small, so you have to take that into account. Although the graphics have improved dramatically from the last game, it still isn't the best, but very bareable.  Overall rating: Personally, I give this game a 8.5/10, losing some marks for only two reasons which are listed above. I hope this review was atleast somewhat helpful to people who are thinking about wheither buying the game or not. Thanks for reading.

Alright. What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said? (HA, what a cliche intro! Makes a reader want to rocket his or her lunch right out of his or her stomach! It could literally make someone who's projectile-vomitting SOUP turn into a lethal hazard!)  Alright. What can I say about this game that is really rad and that I really ♥♥♥♥ing enjoy? Well, quite a lot, actually. I adore the over-the-top gameplay that this game manages to provide while maintaining a believable atmosphere. You've got endless hordes of police officers out to put your ♥♥♥ in custody and a limited supply of ammo, health, and zip-ties (the zip-ties are used primarily to keep your hostages in check.) There are special force units, too, which are constantly making an appearance as you try to find a suitable position for protection during a firefight. You've got your impenetrable riot shield guys, your taser guys who keep you shocked in place, your 'I'm-so-♥♥♥♥in'-huge-you-can't-stop-the-pain-train' guys, and even your classic Tom Clancy 'I'm-Sam-Fischer-and-I-wear-nightvision-24/7-now-let-me-drop-through-a-vent-and-karate-your-♥♥♥-to-prison' guys. Basically, tons of enemies that force you to stay near your comerades and co-operate if you don't want to fail a mission.  There's tons of stuff to unlock and collect, but it basically comes down to a ♥♥♥♥-load of customization for your weapons and masks. At the end of each mission, aside from the giant payout of cash and experience points, you're rewarded with the opportunity to draw 1 of 3 face-down cards. When the card you pick flips over, you might receive a new mask, a weapon mod, some mask-customizing materials, or even another load of cash/exp. It keeps players invested in missions that might otherwise begin to feel tedious, since although there are many maps to choose from, some maps are played more than others.  My first ten hours with this game were a blast. I played a lot of it with a friend, and taking some missions seriously while completely screwing up others kept things interesting. I've invested a little bit over 30 hours now and I'm still enjoying my time with it, but the game does have its flaws. Often you may be spotted at a location you might presume to be safe. Situations (like my personal bane, the 'I'm going to hide on under this staircas- oh nevermind, the guards have x-ray glasses,') arise frequently on certain maps, which lead me to believe that some maps are less fine-tuned than others... Seriously, ♥♥♥♥ the picture frame map - it's a messy waste of time.   It's also easy to become frustrated when your crew of 4 are overwhelmed by the endless waves of enemies who spawn right around every corner around outside buildings. Though it is the gameplay's raison d'etre, it's nice to have a slight moment of peace that allows the players to collect the ammo packs that've dropped from numerously slain enemies. High-leveled players with many unlocked perks usually don't have as great an issue with surviving, but it's common to have moments of awkward frustation when a teammate or oneself is downed and can't be saved due to everybody lacking ammo. And before I forget, y'know those things called melee weapons? Yeah, pretty much useless... Unless you buy DLC for good ones... Which I have done because this game kicks ♥♥♥... but still.    TL;DR: Game is good. Few irksome flaws. Overall I'd say buy it if you have the money, it's a jolly good time with friends... This game is imho even worse than the latest Call of Duty.   But if you love the current CoD games, you might just like this game as well.   You have to grind endlessly to modify your gear, because mods are random loot, after a successful heist. And half of the weapons are dlc-items anyway, so you would have to pay even more to equip them.   Speaking of a successful heist; it is not fun to play a game on higher difficulties with a pug. A Party consisting of four players/bots has to achieve the mission goals, to fend off myriads of brainless bullet-sponges, but above all has to work together as a team.   Problem is: Bots are just useless as team members, but many random players even try their best to nullify your efforts: They hold on to important mission objects instead of using them, don't proceed to the target zone, are yelling insults or are just plainly afk etc. There is no safeguard in place to keep them at bay, like matchmaking and penalties for destructive behavior, or at least an option to downvote these mischievous kids as a warning for the next unsuspecting player.   If you are happy to play with three friends the only enemies are technical issues, like random disconnects, lags, clipping bugs, or invisible weapons (of course with invisible iron sights). The game pers se is not demanding enough to grind on. I got millions of cash from missions but can't use them, because the mods are rare drops. And if you prefer the stealth approach, you'll will have to pay real money to get the right items or repeat lifeless missions for a very long time, just to get a silencer for your weapons.   If you enjoyed the recent CoD titles, feel free to sink your real money in this game, to earn tons of virtual money. Imho it feels more like a f2p-game with the constant grinding, technical issues and bad support.

You've got your impenetrable riot shield guys, your taser guys who keep you shocked in place, your 'I'm-so-♥♥♥♥in'-huge-you-can't-stop-the-pain-train' guys, and even your classic Tom Clancy 'I'm-Sam-Fischer-and-I-wear-nightvision-24/7-now-let-me-drop-through-a-vent-and-karate-your-♥♥♥-to-prison' guys. Basically, tons of enemies that force you to stay near your comerades and co-operate if you don't want to fail a mission.  There's tons of stuff to unlock and collect, but it basically comes down to a ♥♥♥♥-load of customization for your weapons and masks. At the end of each mission, aside from the giant payout of cash and experience points, you're rewarded with the opportunity to draw 1 of 3 face-down cards. When the card you pick flips over, you might receive a new mask, a weapon mod, some mask-customizing materials, or even another load of cash/exp. It keeps players invested in missions that might otherwise begin to feel tedious, since although there are many maps to choose from, some maps are played more than others.  My first ten hours with this game were a blast. I played a lot of it with a friend, and taking some missions seriously while completely screwing up others kept things interesting. I've invested a little bit over 30 hours now and I'm still enjoying my time with it, but the game does have its flaws. Often you may be spotted at a location you might presume to be safe. Situations (like my personal bane, the 'I'm going to hide on under this staircas- oh nevermind, the guards have x-ray glasses,') arise frequently on certain maps, which lead me to believe that some maps are less fine-tuned than others... Seriously, ♥♥♥♥ the picture frame map - it's a messy waste of time.   It's also easy to become frustrated when your crew of 4 are overwhelmed by the endless waves of enemies who spawn right around every corner around outside buildings. Though it is the gameplay's raison d'etre, it's nice to have a slight moment of peace that allows the players to collect the ammo packs that've dropped from numerously slain enemies. High-leveled players with many unlocked perks usually don't have as great an issue with surviving, but it's common to have moments of awkward frustation when a teammate or oneself is downed and can't be saved due to everybody lacking ammo. And before I forget, y'know those things called melee weapons? Yeah, pretty much useless... Unless you buy DLC for good ones... Which I have done because this game kicks ♥♥♥... but still.    TL;DR: Game is good. Few irksome flaws. Overall I'd say buy it if you have the money, it's a jolly good time with friends... Okay I will split this review up into 4 parts: 1. Gunplay, 2. A.I, 3. Co-op vs solo, and 4. Enjoyment.   To start things off lets talk about Gunplay.  The Gunplay is a little bit better than 'Payday The Heist' although the guns can easily be fired from the hip. Some weapons have some decent recoil while others feel like you are firing a airsoft rifle.  I rate Gunplay a 6/10     Next I will review A.I. (Teammates, cops, etc)  Your teammates are really stupid, they will hit their targets (sometimes) and they won't help carry bags, fix the drill, or tie hostages. Alothough if you have a team of 3 the only A.I. is a great healer.  Next up, Cops. The cops are all pretty dumb but they have some quite entertaining ragdoll physics.  And last and least, Hostages. They are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  I give the A.I a total of 4/10 Teammates 5/10, Cops 5/10, and Hostages 2/10    Third I will talk about Co-op vs solo.   As I said before the A.I. is pretty stupid but this game can be played solo no problem. However, The Co-op is one of the best parts in the game (if you are with friends). No a lot of games can give you the: Panic, excitment, strategy, teamwork, and timing that this game can. the Co-op is the best part about this game hands down.  Co-op 10/10, Solo 7/10 (solo is manly for just needing extra cash fast or not connected to the internet).      And last but not least, Enjoyment.  The enjoyment is all up to the people you play with. I play with randoms a lot and I still have a blast although sometimes you can come across the people who kick you for 'screwing up' or 'bringing the wrong gun'. If you are with friends, this game (and left for dead 2) is a great game to play with them.  I rate enjoyment: with friends 10/10, without friends 3/10 to a 9/10.    All together I give the game a 8/10.  I highly recommend this game if you are getting bored of something like Left for dead 2 or something like that and at this price (at the time of the review the game was $7.49) what do you have to loose. at 30 bucks I would wait for it to go on sale to about 20 or below.
