This game is a one of the best co-op games ever made. I played the first payday and this one is definitely an improvement in all forms. This game will satisfy your fantasy of robbing banks and whatnot, and it is highly influenced by famous heist movies like 'Heat' and 'The Town'. You want to go gunblazin' with no plan -Check, you want to plan your heist and use stealth -Check.   This game is a 4-player co-op game, so you are going to need a good group of friends with voice chat for the best experience, although the matchmaking in this game is not so bad. The heists are variable and range from banks to gang hideouts to armored trucks and a lot others.   There is a skill tree system, having 4 trees: Mastermind, Enforcer, Technician, Ghost, and a new one Fugitive. These are important as it gives each player a set of skills that can be used in every heist depending on the situation. You can mix skills from different trees or you can ace one tree completely, but you can only do either as your skill points are limited. A crew with each member acing one different skill tree makes the perfect team.  On the downside, the heists can get repeititve but only after a longtime, the graphics are average at best if it matters to you. and the enemy AI is not 'particularly' smart.  All in all, if you are looking for a good co-op game with continuous updates and an awesome developer 'Overkill', this is the game for you.

Payday 2. Game of many titles: DLC Simulator, Winner of Worst AI Competition, maybe even Sell-out. Either way, let's review it.  ------------------PROS------------------  -Heists. Yes, the missions. Diverse and many, this game gives you a little bit of everything you want. From the most simplest of heists, the basic robbery of small stores, to the most overly complicated heists of all time, massive bank with huge vault that takes 15 minutes to open, even a 'heist' where you cook meth with instructions from google. Everything rolled into this game. Even some stealth missions to tingle those Oceans 11 nuts you've got stored away in those forget-me pants.  -Guns. So many gosh darn guns. Assault rifles, LMG's, SMG's, Shotguns, pistols, and every miscellaneous gun you could find in between, all wrapped up complete with loads of custom modifications for them.  -Stealth. Yes, it's flawed. Yes, it's difficult. Yes, you might have to answer a pager just to say you ordered a pizza. But it works, and it's (usually) fun. If you really have trouble, play Shadow Raid by yourself until you get the hang of it. That's what I did.  -Environment. Control hostages, board up windows, drill through safes, blow open walls, you name it, this game has a heist where you can interact with it. On that note...  -Objectives. These are usually well placed. Money looks very appetizing, and stuffing it into bags is great fun. When you have to leave behind even one dufflebag, it hurts. Drilling into vaults is also great, but... well check the realism con later on.  -Visuals. The game looks sharp with good looking masks, escape vehicles are made to look like godsends near the end of a long and treacherous heist, and all interactables usually look natural.  -Content. Ignoring price tags, this game has LOADS of content. DLC's provide extra weapons, masks, characters, heists, and such. Any DLC mission is also available to those without the DLC, but join someone who does, making it easy to play all the heists. Even base game, it has alot of content.  -Multiplayer. Well executed to say the very least. Easy to use drop-in system allows you to find the heist you want easily, even if it's already mid-level. Servers are good, and the community isn't too cancerous.  ------------------GRAY------------------  -DLC's. If you get them all on sale, they can give you alot of fun. However, there's just too many DLC's too purchase every new one as it comes out. It would be easy to fix too: just group small DLC's into larger expansions. Group all the Gage packs, then character packs, then heist packs. That way, DLC's would need to be individually purchased. Or better yet, make less paid DLC all together, and people won't be scared to buy the game.  Characters. Yes, yes, story isn't what Payday is about. But, if you incorporate characters, you have to make them have either good storys, or no backstory at all. I'd be fine just rolling into a bank heist knowing nothing about the character, just make your character packs all visuals. Just please, for the love of Gaben, don't try to make Hoxton have a backstory, or have Bain blabber on and on about pointless garbage mid-heist. First off, Bain annoys the living crap out of me, second his ineptitude for giving commands or giving advice is a real thorn in my scrote. Third, he acts like a whimp if you get caught. 'Aw! I must've miscalculated something guys! Please forgive me!'. It's okay, jack-♥♥♥. It's not your fault, it's the heisters' faults. On the good side, their characters all look the way they should. Heisters look hardened, you bosses look like they are well put together. I personally love the Dentist and the Elephant, they look like professionals. Voice acting is...well you can put together your own opinions from watching gameplay or something.  ------------------CONS------------------  -AI. The AI is so freakin' bad. The default team-AI's won't fix the drill, pickup bags, or bring heavier armor. They tend to get stuck pretty often aswell. The enemy AI is pretty abysmal as well, walking in to moltov'ed areas, meat-grinder tactics, and even waiting at power boxes long after they pulled the switch. You can usually deal with all of this, though.  -Developers. For a while they were absolutley fantastic. They put out solid community stuff, dealt with any bugs people had, even made a cheater's tag for those who decided they didn't want to wait for the good stuff. Didn't ban for cheating either, which in my opinion was a solid move. But lately, they've been falling short. It seems like they let their success get to their heads. Come'on guys, micro-transactions? With this many DLC's? Just read the articles.  -Fixing ♥♥♥♥. 'Drill's broken.''Drill's broken.''Drill's broken.''Drill's broken.''Drill's broken.' Over and over, fix the drill, turn on the power, answer the pagers. All of it is just too often. The drill should jam once, maybe twice. The power switch situation? Put a bigger cool-down on the cops ability to turn off the power. It gets really damn annoying.  -Realism. Call me crazy, but I'm pretty sure swat teams don't just shoot the living ♥♥♥♥ out of a bank full of hostages. The police will constantly send wave upon wave of SWAT teams to kill you, even when you're clearly killing all of them. I played the big bank heist and single-handedly killed 411 police officers and 10 civilians with a ♥♥♥♥ing flamethrower. 411. The approximate size of DC's police force is 3,900 cops. That means I, one man with a ♥♥♥♥ing flamethrower, killed nearly a tenth of all the cops in America's capitol. AND THEY KEPT THROWING MORE AT ME. Which moron thought it was a good idea to just send them in, one after another, into a giant flame-filled corridor? Why not just surround it and ask for our demands? We have hostages, we could say we would kill some if they came into the bank. But do we? No, because roasting them all with a mother ♥♥♥♥ing flamethrower is much more effective. Look, I know Payday 2 is an over-the-top action filled shooter about being a four man army that robs banks past the point of even needing the money, but come on. Why can't we just keep them at bay with threats of harm towards civies? Maybe we could execute one if they try to sneak in or try to snipe us? Eh, whatever. What's done is done.  Price. Dude, just lower your DLCs' prices already.  ------------------TLDR------------------ Overall, the game has alot of flaws. But so does everything. It's a solid game with good shooty-bangs and nice action-packed heists just like in the movies. I give it a breezy 8 out of 10.

I have over 400 hours in this game at the time. This review is gonna be me talking about the game and it's features and all that and then me scoring it. There are lots of different heists that you can do and many of them have a few different ways to do them. We have the classic bank heists, jewlery shop heists and all that, and then we have the really different ones: there's one where you try to steal a samurai armour from a giant warehouse, one where you try to steal a nuclear bomb from a train or from a shipping boat, a few that have to do with drugs and cartels, and a few other ones that aren't just your classic bank heist. Each mission can be completed the hard way, fighting agaisnt waves of cops, or the easy (not really all that easy sometimes) way where you do it in a stealthy manner. There's lots of different weapons and many attachements for each giving you lots of customization in how you want a certain weapon to be focused on or on how it will be played, a skill tree where you can focus on being a tank, a medic, a stealthy based guy, a low armour but high dodge chance character or a tactitian. Each way you choose your skills will highly change the way you have to play to get the most out of those skills. There's difficulties for every type of player. Normal, for the casual player, Hard, for the one that wants a little bit, but not much, of a challenge. Very Hard, for the player that wants a slighty harder mission with stronger and different types of enemies, Overkill, for the player who wants a real challenge. Finally, Death Wish for the people who want to try the mission over and over again... You can eitheir play with pre-made lobbies or just play in a public match. If you don't have a certain DLC but want to play a mission from that DLC then you can just ask a friend to host that mission (they'll need the DLC of course) or join a public match of someone hosting that mission, which means you technically don't need to buy any DLC to play every mission in the game. Cheaters aren't much of a problem since for the most part the game is cheater free, although if you do have a cheater in your lobby you and the other players can just kick him. Cheaters usually just fool around but don't kill you or troll you. Now for the scoring part: Gameplay 9.5/10 , a 10/10 in this category is very hard since gameplay can be very subjective, for the most part the game is fine, there's the occasional glitch every now and then but for the most part it's fine. Missions are enjoyable and have their touch of enjoyment. Graphics 7/10 , the graphics are fine for a 15£ game it's but aren't anything revolutionary. They're fine as long as you're not a person that only enjoys photorealistic games. Lore/Stroryline 6.5/10 , it is a shooter but it does have its touch of lore. The characters have stories behind them, missions are usually tied to some kind of cartel or source, every mission is obtained by one of  Crime.net's  members and it's quite nice to know how a certain member from the gang has come about to join it.  The game is very fun to play with friends and will keep you bunch entertained for hours and hours.

Okay I will split this review up into 4 parts: 1. Gunplay, 2. A.I, 3. Co-op vs solo, and 4. Enjoyment.   To start things off lets talk about Gunplay.  The Gunplay is a little bit better than 'Payday The Heist' although the guns can easily be fired from the hip. Some weapons have some decent recoil while others feel like you are firing a airsoft rifle.  I rate Gunplay a 6/10     Next I will review A.I. (Teammates, cops, etc)  Your teammates are really stupid, they will hit their targets (sometimes) and they won't help carry bags, fix the drill, or tie hostages. Alothough if you have a team of 3 the only A.I. is a great healer.  Next up, Cops. The cops are all pretty dumb but they have some quite entertaining ragdoll physics.  And last and least, Hostages. They are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  I give the A.I a total of 4/10 Teammates 5/10, Cops 5/10, and Hostages 2/10    Third I will talk about Co-op vs solo.   As I said before the A.I. is pretty stupid but this game can be played solo no problem. However, The Co-op is one of the best parts in the game (if you are with friends). No a lot of games can give you the: Panic, excitment, strategy, teamwork, and timing that this game can. the Co-op is the best part about this game hands down.  Co-op 10/10, Solo 7/10 (solo is manly for just needing extra cash fast or not connected to the internet).      And last but not least, Enjoyment.  The enjoyment is all up to the people you play with. I play with randoms a lot and I still have a blast although sometimes you can come across the people who kick you for 'screwing up' or 'bringing the wrong gun'. If you are with friends, this game (and left for dead 2) is a great game to play with them.  I rate enjoyment: with friends 10/10, without friends 3/10 to a 9/10.    All together I give the game a 8/10.  I highly recommend this game if you are getting bored of something like Left for dead 2 or something like that and at this price (at the time of the review the game was $7.49) what do you have to loose. at 30 bucks I would wait for it to go on sale to about 20 or below. This game was great at its launch, but no one was prepared for the horrible changes to come.   I was very excited for this game and stayed up all night to get it at launch. My god was that a waste. The pre-download they had done failed and i needed to instal it again, some people couldnt even download the game. The thing that baffled me was that they put how to fix this problem ON THE TITLE SCREEN. I mean, seriously? Tell people how to get the game, in the game. Good job guys, regroup next week. Once those problems were fixed, the game was mostly enjoyable.   Some skills were and still are almost a complete waste of time. Take Insider Man for example. The worst heist it applies to is the Bank. It gives you the same blueprints of the bank everytime. So 50% of the time. you were tricked. Although it's easy to see right away in the mission that the asset was wrong and change the plan, you've still wasted the money and skill poits on it. What so you think of when you hear Stockholm Syndrome? Was it someone being held captive? No, that would be insane. The Stockholm Syndrome skill will let nearby civilians revive you if you interact with them. The problem is, when you go down, you've been detected most likely and all the civilianns have ran. Now you might think a hostage could set do this if you are near one, nope. There are still other perks that act like these, but i mained Mastermind so these are the ones i am most familiar with.  Aside from the broken skills, the updates and dlc are what really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off about OVERKILL. After the rough launch day, they managed to fix some other bugs in the passing weeks. The only update that i actually enjoyed was the new stealth thing, where you now had a meter of detection for your overall loadout. The newer updates have really annoyed me. The introduction of Deathwish and the anti-farming feature, are what have made me give up hope for this game. Deathwish gives a miniscule exp and cash bonus and dumb achievements. With the anti-farming feature, it stopped people from farming Rats, however that put a damper on other jobs. If you do a pro job and fail then try again, you get reduced exp. If they never once thought that people would take advantage of the fact that Rats can take less than a 15 minutes to do, with a ton of exp to reap, then they should have just removed the option to blow up the meth lab in Day 1. Other holiday updates added achievements and masks that are impossible to get now, so if you were planning on acing the game, then good luck.  DLC. OVERKILL you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. They have done nothing but cheat us of it. If you pre-ordered the game, you got the first DLC free. Even thought it was free, I still felt like my money was still stolen from my wallet. We were promised 5 DLC packs to come out by summer 2014, 3 have already been released and have been terrible. As mentioned, the first DLC, Armored Transport was a complete fail, adding stupid missions that were very hard and added nothing new. From the name, i assumed it would be something along the lines of shooting out the back of an armored car after a heist, or stealing back your loot from an armored truck after failing an escape. My second assumptions was half-fuffiled, but in an atrocious way. The other 2 DLC have been weapon packs, adding more unimportant weapons and repetitive achievement(a lot of 'wear this mask and kill X amount of people). I expect that the other 2 DLC that have yet to have been released will end up being more weapon packs.   After awhile, with so few heists and variety, the game gets boring. Some heists are completely useless to do after a certain point, like Jewelry Store and Four Stores.  Finally, (I can't remember if we were promised this or i made this announcement up) ADD SAFE HOUSE CUSTOMIZATION. I want to use my offshore money for something other than buying contracts and an over-priced slot machine. I want to know that I've moved from a mediocre laundromat, to a slightly fancier laundromat or anything else. Just let me buy a new base, so i know that all my hard work robbing and almost dying have been worth it.

PayDay 2 is an excellent game in regards to its focus on cooperation and gameplay. Now bring in Overkill's method of handling new content to the table and your wallet's in for a treat. After a while of play it does feel as if the game's content is severely lacking thanks to the overwhelming amount of paid downloadable content available. Unfortunately the paid downloadable content is the majority of the game's content. Without the game's downloadable content, you'll find yourself relying on others to play jobs and heists that you don't have access to. You'll also discover that you're missing out on alot, especially the game's vast amount of weaponry. Overkill really should have worked more content into the base game over time rather than having it be downloadable content.   Overall it's a recommendation from me as it can be extremely fun with friends and randoms alike. If you enjoy the base game, a good sum of the available downloadable content packs add even more to the experience. Just be wary this game can vary well lead to an empty wallet. I bought it on sale during Steam's last Winter Sale and since then I've spent plenty on it to keep me entertained. Think of it this way, it's like buying a house but when you go to your newly owned property to move in you realize there's only the foundation in place. Each DLC builds onto the foundation which eventually makes it a full fledged game. Either way, if you decide to build upon the foundation or not it's still worth checking out!  Update:  Thoughts on microtransactions? All I have to say is, props to Overkill for ruining their reputation even further by adding microtransactions.   Note: Is it a coincidence that positive reviews for this title were suddenly deemed unhelpful just after the addition of microtransactions? I think not. I find that funny, as I for one don't approve of Overkill's poor choices when it comes to how they handle the game's new content either.

TL;DR: Good game. Sucks that you have to pay so much per DLC.  It's a good game. It costs $20 as of the time of writing (26/6/15).  The DLC is a little excessive.  Do I want to pay $7 (more than a third of what the game costs) to get access to one single 20-40 minute heist?  No. Not really.  Do I want to pay $5 (a quarter of the game's price) to get access to ONE new character that I can play as? (purely cosmetic)  No. Not really.  Would I recommend this game?  Sure. Just don't think you should buy the DLC. You can still play the heists (just you can't load them up yourself, you need to join someone who has it up)  I don't enjoy saying this. I've had > 350 hours of fun playing this game, so that's a testament to its playability. However, don't spend all of your money. I bought a lot of DLC for this game, and I don't regret it, but I'm at the point where I don't WANT to buy any more. Ingredients 2 large eggs Salt and pepper 2 to 3 tablespoons shredded cheese (optional) 1/4 to 1/2 cup filling, pre-cooked if necessary (optional) 2 teaspoons unsalted butter Minced parsley, to garnish (optional)  Equipment Mixing bowl Whisk 8-inch nonstick skillet Spatula Dinner plate  Instructions 1. Whisk the eggs: Crack both eggs into a mixing bowl. Whisk the eggs until completely combined, and season with salt and pepper. If you\'re adding cheese or other fillings, make sure they are prepped and nearby. 2. Warm the skillet and melt the butter: Place an 8-inch skillet over medium-high heat and melt the butter. Tilt the skillet as the butter melts to evenly coat the bottom. When the butter stops sizzling, the pan is heated and ready. 3. Pour the eggs into the skillet: Pour the whisked eggs into the skillet. Immediately tilt the pan so the eggs coat the entire bottom. The eggs should sizzle on contact; if not, continue cooking, but remember to heat the pan a little longer next time. 4. Drag and push the eggs to form waves: Use a spatula to gently drag and push the cooked eggs from the edges toward the center of the pan, making space for the uncooked eggs and forming waves in the omelette. Tilt the skillet so that the uncooked eggs flow into the open spaces. 5. Cook the omelette for 1 to 2 minutes: The omelette will finish cooking in 1 to 2 minutes. When done, the bottom will be set and the edges will look crisp. The top of the omelette should still look fairly wet and uncooked, but there will no longer be any loose, easily flowing liquid egg — the omelette will continue cooking off the heat, so finish when you think the top still seems a bit underdone. 6. Top with cheese and fillings: If using, sprinkle the cheese and fillings down the center of the omelette. 7. Fold the omelette: Fold the bottom third of the omelette over the center, and then fold the top third down. Alternatively, fold the omelette in half. 8. Slide the omelette onto a plate: Gently slide the omelette onto a plate and garnish with parsley. Eat right away while still hot.

I'm neutral on this. I used to love this game so much. I wouldn't have spent almost 600 hours playing this game otherwise.  I loved the idea of being in a criminal's shoes, executing heists and battling against different types of law enforcers. I loved the huge customization abilities in the game. You could choose from a hundred masks, change the look of it, put on patterns of different colours and get a very unique mask tailored to your tastes. I loved the feeling of planning out heists with your friends and trying if it works. I loved the skills and perks you can choose to make dozens of possible builds. I loved the adrenaline you get when doing stealth, always on the edge of your seat trying not to mess up and get caught.  It was my most favourite game in the world. For a while.  I stopped playing for a few months due to exams and when i got back, I cleared my progress, raring to try out the updates. But then I realised something. In short terms, it was a mess. dozens of DLCs were pumped out while I was gone. everything was not user-friendly. After playing some more, it honestly felt like an early-access game. Unless you follow the development of the game closely from the beginning, you will have problems understanding. You would have questions like 'Eh? How come there's this old japanese dude with me suddenly? what's the story there?' 'Whose locke? so Murkywater is our friend?' and then you play one of the older heists and 'what!? so we became rivals all of a sudden? or were we rivals from the start?' 'Why is this Jimmy dude asking us to go scan bodies in a russian lab all of a sudden?! Where did Jimmy come from?! What's Akan!?'   I hope you can see what I mean. They made a mess. I felt like that moment where you come home and see your house torn up by your pet. They didnt bother ordering the missions they pumped in, expecting each player knows what is what. you have to watch an entire movie worth of trailers to barely understand. I spent hours on google and youtube just to figure out what is happening in the 'storyline'. They shouldn't just put up a screen where random missions appear and you just choose from there. They should make a mission tree or something, unlocking more heists as you progress. I've seen so many new players go on missions i would imagine they would find immensely hard and confusing/  What makes me more dissapointed is that they locked most of these updates behind a paywall. almost half the weapons, characters, heists and other stuff is DLC. You gotta invest like a hundred dollars just for the full game.  TL;DR  This game is a good game. but it used to be better. much much better. back then i would have given it a solid 10/10. now I'd give it a 6/10. unless you're willing to buy 100 dollars worth of DLC and hours watching DLC trailers to figure out the story, don't buy it. The DLCs are basically game updates.

It's almost painful to try and continue comparing this to L4D, but it still works. Neverending PvE: 4 humans against droves of weak fools and a few oddities in multiple scenarios trying to achieve some objective other than survival. The differences are why people started playing this game back when it came out and also why so many have 'left'. The DLC went from free, to paid, to pay2win, to cosmetic. Pay2win in a PvE. Bleh. The gunplay in this game is more than addictive, it's somewhat empowering. When playing with no latency on a great processor, the NPCs will give a great challenge at higher difficulties.  The meta is deeper than expected for an FPS, treating it much like an RPG. Skill trees and perk systems collide to allow dozens of playstyles, most able to integrate with other players' skillsets. Some skills improve your gun use, and others will allow for specialized weapons to be used. Multiple skills will give benefit to the whole team, but can not stack. Healers, tanks, rouges, and summoners all have their place in this modern crime game. The 'best' build ends up being an insta-reviver DPS, though.  With the choice of quiet or loud comes so many decisions, such as preparation for the possibility of failure. In many heists, stealth is damn near impossible to keep up. Some might choose to pack armor, others might choose to wear it from the beginning and bring an ECM jammer, and some who liken themselves to ninjas choose to bring nothing but two silenced pistols. Some people call this the best stealth game ever. I haven't played many others, but it seems about right to call it that. The guards have more sense than average and the visibility system can be brutal. Break a light? Guard figures s--- out and calls the cops. You'll never be able to truly see through walls with heat scanning, but your skills and leverage with employees will give you access to CCTV and motion sensors.   It's a g--d--- MMORPG as a shooter

So I've played a lot of this game. Like, a lot a lot. And I've written a lot of reviews for it over the time I've played it. However, recently because I grew so utterly cold to it and have nearly no intention of coming back, I feel like I can finally write a very honest review about it. Payday 2 is an excellent game. At its core, it's extremely fun, hectic shooting, the feeling of bagging ever-expanding bags of loot, the feeling of tweaking weapons to fine points for just the right balance of power, the feeling of raw energy pumping through your veins as you wade through oceans of enemies and hope that you and your friends can hold the fort. Payday 2, in a vaccum, is one of the best games that I've ever played on a sheer 'game' level. Notice the 'in a vaccum' qualifier. Payday 2 as a study in game managment is a documentary about the willingless to make faustian bargains of your fans' adoration for yet more money. Remember those simple days when what we complained about were DLC's? Good times. Payday 2 has (off the top of my head) around 28 dlc's. Probably more, and soon. And they are for the most part worth the fairly reasonable price of 5-7.5$, with a few exceptions. At the start, they were mostly very content-intensive, with a lot of bang for your buck. That line started to sink, though, as it was releasing straight-up triple weapon packs, with some being themed super hard at the expense of being actually useful. Some were straight up ads you payed for, like the Allesso and Point Break heists. That being said, both heists aren't bad because they're bad heists, they're bad on principle. These people collaborated with Goat Simulator. They have no shame when it comes with who they collaborate with and then asking you to pay to see the extended advertisment. And then the microtransactions. If you have any gripes with microtransactions in this game now, you weren't there when they hit. It was ♥♥♥♥ing D-Day. They added stat bonuses to certain skins so you could actually shell out money for an in game boost. No, I'm not talking about a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ mobile game, I'm talking about the game that I just praised extensively. There was so much ♥♥♥♥ flying at Overkill and anyone who dared be affiliated that it's astonishing that Overkill fixed it so slowly. Now, they're basically just skins from CS:GO or one of the seventy games that are realizing where the real money is now. They are, in retrospect, much improved from the old way. The boosts are now seperate and you can't go six heists without tripping over one. At this point, I'd played so much of the game that I was already experiencing some shock fatigue on the whole 'Ovk are milking us' argument. And now, after the smoke cleared, my hypothesis is that they aren't just milking the oldies, but trying to usher in any new players they can into their elaborate mousetrap. This is a vicious cycle. But through all that, the misuse of the community, the constant dlc's, and the paid advertisements, I find that I can still reccomend this game. It's been a bumpy ride, and Overkill are still shifting things around with dangerous potential to ♥♥♥♥ everything up, but if you strip away all that political crap, buy yourself an eco list of dlc, and play the game, you'll have a ♥♥♥♥ing blast. This game is great, and though I grew tired of it, you may not have to live in the world of DLC milking and microtransactions that I did.   TL;DR: Stay smart with your money, and you'll have fun. Don't, and you're just another pawn.

Payday 2 (I can't understand point of using capital letters as name) is First-Person Shooter with with emphasis on 4-player cooperation (which doesnt mean you cannot play it with smaller amount of players or even solo).  Goal of the game is to climb criminal ladder by increasing wealth, reputation and later infamy levels, gained by completing various heists. To do it, player has to get his mask, gun, unlock some skills with gained points and pick his character. All of it will be covered. Starting with heisters: at this moment (June 2016) player has 16 heisters to choose from - at least in theory. Some of them require you to buy character pack dlc, others require joining PD2 Steam group, there is even one that requires you to complete specific heist (game lore; this heister was member of original Payday gang back in PD: the heist, but got incarcerated between games. Now has to be broken out of prison). Characters themselves are purely cosmetic - they differ only with appearance (if you play as one - all you see are their arms) and voices. Pool of heisters include vast amound of different criminals: from professional bank robbers, through hitmen, burglar, adrenaline junkie to former yakuza member. There is even a coke-addicted psycho, so as you can see, you have a lot to choose from.  Masks. Place to show your artistic nature. Starting with characters original masks, playing more heists gives you more card drops (after heist, you have to pick one from 3 cards, containing random mask, material, pattern, colour, weapon mod, cash, exp or skin safes), which gives you masks and materials to customiste them. To do it, you pick mask then material, pattern and colour, then pay customising fee. There are so called infamous drops: special, extremly rare items, being so special for their looks, for example golden material. Just go, play and get more stuff and create cool masks.  Weapons - only fool would try to rob a bank without a weapon. There are lots of weapons aviable, with mods to further customise them: grips, sights, stocks, sometimes ammo - whatever you want. Player can take primary and secondary into battle, choice ranging from assault rifles, shotguns, sniper rifles, SMGs and even granade launchers and Flamethrower.  There are also melee weapons. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of them. Prison shanks, knifes, axes, or even greatswords. There's lots of stuff to pick to suit your playstyle. Only problem: lots melees and guns are locked behind DLCs.  Skills. Players get one skill point per level. They are plenty skills in 5 skill trees (each contains 3 subtrees). There is no way to unlock every skill, so you have to choose what you need more. Skills give you advanage on the cops. You can get large damage bonus on suppresed weapons, be able to revive teammates by shouting at them, increase damage on selected weapon group, get stronges armor ect. Pick whatever you need.   Perk decks are ncie sidekick to skills, giving you additional edge. They direstly influence your playstyle: some perkdecks focus on helping your teammates, giving you enought dodge stat to play without armor, heling from kills, melee hits and so on. You unlock them with leveling up: recieving exp will also give you perk points on differing conversion rates. Then you unlock the perks, equip them and kill the cops. By the way, these are sets, you pick whole set, not just couple of skills.   Heists. There are lots of them, but they aren't really common heisters jobs. I feel Payday crew should be called terrorists: there are of course regular jewelry store hits, banks of various sizes. There even is a nice, big casino. So why terrorists? At some point gang hits paramilitary base (4 times), stealing nukes, cooking meth, derailing the train with bomb, and so on. Huge amount of heists, nice payouts - just keep heisting.   While most of heists are to be completed loudly. There are also ones that are to be done quietly. This is challenging, but gives a nice exp stealth bonus. Also, there are no waves of cops to kill you.   Gameplay itself is simple. We have waves of cops trying to bring you down, when you have to complete objectives (mostly this broke ♥♥♥♥ piece of ♥♥♥♥ drill). Cops have special units, like heavily armored buldozers, tasers, shields and my favourite sneaky cloakers - guys who can down player with one hit. Players hate them.  Players being downed have 30 seconds to be revived, otherwise they go into custody. Then they can be traded for taken hostages. Thats it in short.   DLCs. In no other game review I would mention them, but here they are quite a fuss among players. As for me, this is the way of keeping the game alive even through the time that passed since launch. And as nobody wants to work for free - that's why they are paid.   Overally, I like that game - watching how my ingame accounts increase all the time, kill cops, hitting stores ect. If you enjoy coop games (even though some people are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥) and like being the bad guy - just buy it.

Read this review if you are:  A possible player considering PAYDAY 2 as a future purchase.  A new player considering whether or not to buy some/all of the DLC. But here's something people need to know about the DLC before they buy it (or hate on it): IT'S NOT REQUIRED TO PLAY OR HAVE FUN! All the DLC is extra content that can appeal to certain players. If it was required, they would have included it in the base game!   To be honest, when I buy PAYDAY 2's DLC, I don't think of it as buying DLC. It's more like making a 'Donation of Appreciation' to OVERKILL to let them know that I still love the game and will continue to play it. Why? So here’s my message to you:  Possible Players: If you are serious about getting PAYDAY 2, just get the base game and no DLC to start off with. If you are unsure, try the demo first.  New Players: If you like the game and want to give back, start with one DLC of your choosing and see how it goes from there.  Current Players: If you love the game and want to give back, buy the any DLC(s) that you want.  Current HATERS: If you don’t like the fact that they made all the paid DLC, just don’t buy it. If you just hate PAYDAY 2 in general, and hate on it because you think current players have to buy it to continue playing, that’s NOT TRUE! While the learning curve is a little higher than most FPS out there, it is a tremendously enjoyable game. It has a lot of depth and re-playability thanks to the skill trees/perk decks, countless weapons/mods and so many varied heists. The story is a little disconnected because you can play the heists in any order but you can eventually piece it together. The Web Series and DLC trailers are also very good sources for the story. The characters are quite likable as well. The sounds, graphics and gun play are very satisfying. The ability to play many mission loud (guns blazing) or stealth is rather entertaining as well. While going loud is fairly straightforward, stealth is the tricky part to master. 9/10, because the game has a couple glitches and crashes that can get a little annoying.  Edit 10-18-2015 : Despite having mentioned in the past that microtransactions would never be implemented, they eventually added it during a 'free' event. I have nothing against microtransactions for games that are cheap, free or have no DLCs. However Payday 2 is not free and it has a lot of PAID DLCs. I would be ok with such a system in that game under two conditions : - do not force players to spend money in order to open their safes. It could be done through drops or special events. People that still wish to open their safes faster would be free to use the market. - do not provide stats with cosmetic paid items, that is technically PAY 2 WIN even though it is only a PvE game.  Edit 10-28-2015 : Drills are now a drop but they are so rare I have seen only one drop (a friend got it) in about +100 games. Overkill management and PR is really poor (looks at Bo and Almir), they mentioned having increased the team from 25 to 75 and yet can't find resources to fix core engine issues like desynch, crashed lobby, client side stealth issues, server migration...). And that's not even mentioning the poor Console support.  Edit : November 2015 : The COP final reward dropped. it was 1 / 25 skins as promised but ... of varied conditions, different rarities and some have boost. Where are the skins they promised would be cosmetic only made with love and care when you get a completely scracthed up skin? Not to mention that 3 skins are Legendaries and have not dropped as of December 16th, 2015. I am starting to question the Legendary drop rate now. Overkill acknowledge they ♥♥♥♥ed up and stated they will go back to the drawing board. The Point Break heists are both pretty good and really action packed. Most of all is no drill waiting and a couple interesting mechanics.  Edit December 2015 : Overkill announced stat & team boost will be added as free drop in the form of mods. There will be 10 of them collectable through the card drop or a monthly side job. You would think it would be the perfect time to replace stat boost skins with a cosmetic replacement like stat track or visual effects... but no. Overkill wants to favor rich players by leaving them the options to instantly buy power/stat without having to wait or earn a drop like the regular players. Overkill also came up with a suggestion for the botched COP reward. They are now polling forum users for a list of 10 masks to be 'mega-fied'. I suggested to do all remaining and future heisters in order to keep style consistency with the 4 original megas. But you would be amazed at the amount of trolling or maybe just purely bad taste going as suggestions, Kawaii being among the most named.  February 2015 : A lot has happened since the last update. The boost mods are very common and drop fairly regularly, making stat boost skins pretty much pointless. I am thinking they should think about converting those to something else, like Stat Track or cosmetic effects.  As for heists, I have been pretty impressed. Point Break is great and nice change of pace and gameplay. Santa's workshop is predictable but still much more enjoyable than Cook Off / Labs Rats or White Xmas. The Goat heist is hard and lenghty but overall pleasant (I have yet to do it on DW).  COP, 3 masks have been revealed, they look ok but I was hoping for more heisters masks. Hopefully the next one improve upon the 3 earlier ones.  Just today, the Wolf Pack has been announced. It contains ports of Undercover and Counterfeit and is free from Owners of PD:TH Wolfpack. Which is a pretty nice move. Overkill has also improved their PR, but it is not yet up to the level I would like. The changes and good content released the past 3 months reflected positively on the company and the game. I will recommend that game once more.  2016-11-23 : lots of stuff happened, community safes, new levels, new difficulties and long awaited safehouse was released. Also a huge mess up with Community skins and COP safes being awarded to people who should have them is being cleared up by valve. Otherwise I am mostly working on the badge xD

Payday is an amazing, Co-op, strategy based game, which involves all four members of your team, especially in the situation of participating in a deathwish based loud, for every team mate to engage and work together in order to complete the objective.  Compared to everyone else, i wouldn't say i have a mass amount of hours, however i have played this long enough to know that this is an outstanding game, i first started playing in December 2013, and the game has come a long way, generally i would take a game, and try to find things to critise things about it so i can address what needs improving, and honestly, there is only one trait to this amazing game.  The content released is generally brilliant, i take on board amount people dissing the micro-transactions, and the practical hault of free-DLC, but honestly, i almost own every DLC in this game, and i am proud to own every one of them, each one has there own unique boosts, not forgetting to mention the large variety of DLC Guns, the free guns that you get with the base game are amazing too, but in my opinion, the DLC in this game is worth the investment in order to increase the overall enjoyment and experiences you will face in this game.  As you can see, i have quite a significant amount of hours on this game, and i felt it would be appropriate that i wait quite a while so i can compare where Payday was, and is now, and honestly i can say right now, that the only direction this game has been heading in is a good one, content is amazing, of course no game is perfect, but this is one of the games out there that is closest too it.  As i said earlier, there was one thing i could critise about this game, and only one, and that is the mass amount of de-sync you can find in the co-op stealth, if your the host, you will not experience this, but if you have your buddy as a host, and yourself as a player, then the desync plays as a major negative factor in this game, because you can quickly run past a guard, and when your in cover only then does your detection begin to go up, and sometimes i've actually been detected 3-4 seconds or even more after getting past the guard, this kind of encourages me to play in this way because i think that i am able to do things that i clearly find out later, due to desync slapping you in the face, that you cannot actually do, you might be crouching infront of a guard from significant distance, and then go into cover, but then he started seeing you because of the siginificant amount of desync, i'm not going to go to far into this, but the players that enjoy stealth, and have played for a time, generally get the idea, that desync, if your not the host, is a REAL pain, as i have mucked up the heist many times because of the de-sync issue.  Apart from that one little negative factor, the game is overall amazing and i definitely recommend it to people that enjoy working as a team, or even solo if you really wish, to push to complete the objective in a team of fighting waves of enemies, or just the guy, that enjoys the solo, stealthy approach, this game is one of the best out there, and although this game has been critised a lot in the past, i support the developers for how far they have came, and even till this day does this game still has a mass amount of potential, this my friends, is one of the best.

I have very mixed feelings towards PAYDAY 2. It is a good game... If you have friends to play with. That's the only time it will be fun to play  Let's start with one of the biggest problems- The community. The community is absolutely atrocious. You will mostly find people playing the Hoxton breakout, Cook Off, or Election day. And the moment they see you as a low level, you will get instantly kicked. The moment they see you don't have the right item, you're kicked. And everyone practically insults each other one every. Single. Thing. It's atrocious.  Back in PAYDAY: The Heist, people were more focused on working together to get a job done. Now, the game has turned into a grind and cash grab. You will visit the heists I mentioned above to get more experience so you can level up, buy more skills, more guns. And when you hit level 100, you will eventually become infamous, because stealthy heisters want to be more known [ Logic ]. And you will repeat this process... 25 times. Just for new masks. Becuase masks in this game are the equivalent of hats in TF2.   Next, the single player. If you enjoy playing single player, do not. I repeat, DO NOT get this game. The AI is pathetic, it will not do any basic objectives whatsoever. The only thing good about the AI is that they are good bullet shields and they will help you up when you're downed. Unless it's a tazer and the other AI is downed too, then it just glitches the hell out. They won't carry bags, fix drills, pick lock doors, etc. And for some reason, OVERKILL thought it was a good idea to only give you two AI instead of three when you play single player.   The biggest problem about this game is simply that almost everything is a DLC at this point. And the game feels so unfinished that it may as well be in early access. With over 100$ worth of DLC, you'll be required to spend more than 40$ just to get a good game experience with the weapons, heists, mods, etc. Pick them up when they are on sale, but it will still take a large chunk out of your wallet if you want to get the good DLC's, or all. I would honestly suggest just gettign Courier mod, and all the heists, so you can atleast change things up a bit.  Now, for the pros. The game is absolutely marvelous when you can play with your friends, and even better if you can talk to each other and play. Coordinating with your friends and actually managing to pull off a heist, whether stealth or loud, is extremely satisfying and keeps you coming back to play the game, over, and over, and over again. Only with friends, however. But that teamwork between your small four man crew is great. And you'll go on to play more heists... If one of you buys them. I have very mixed feelings towards PAYDAY 2. It is a good game... If you have friends to play with. That's the only time it will be fun to play  Let's start with one of the biggest problems- The community. The community is absolutely atrocious. You will mostly find people playing the Hoxton breakout, Cook Off, or Election day. And the moment they see you as a low level, you will get instantly kicked. The moment they see you don't have the right item, you're kicked. And everyone practically insults each other one every. Single. Thing. It's atrocious.  Back in PAYDAY: The Heist, people were more focused on working together to get a job done. Now, the game has turned into a grind and cash grab. You will visit the heists I mentioned above to get more experience so you can level up, buy more skills, more guns. And when you hit level 100, you will eventually become infamous, because stealthy heisters want to be more known [ Logic ]. And you will repeat this process... 25 times. Just for new masks. Becuase masks in this game are the equivalent of hats in TF2.   Next, the single player. If you enjoy playing single player, do not. I repeat, DO NOT get this game. The AI is pathetic, it will not do any basic objectives whatsoever. The only thing good about the AI is that they are good bullet shields and they will help you up when you're downed. Unless it's a tazer and the other AI is downed too, then it just glitches the hell out. They won't carry bags, fix drills, pick lock doors, etc. And for some reason, OVERKILL thought it was a good idea to only give you two AI instead of three when you play single player.   The biggest problem about this game is simply that almost everything is a DLC at this point. And the game feels so unfinished that it may as well be in early access. With over 100$ worth of DLC, you'll be required to spend more than 40$ just to get a good game experience with the weapons, heists, mods, etc. Pick them up when they are on sale, but it will still take a large chunk out of your wallet if you want to get the good DLC's, or all. I would honestly suggest just gettign Courier mod, and all the heists, so you can atleast change things up a bit.  Now, for the pros. The game is absolutely marvelous when you can play with your friends, and even better if you can talk to each other and play. Coordinating with your friends and actually managing to pull off a heist, whether stealth or loud, is extremely satisfying and keeps you coming back to play the game, over, and over, and over again. Only with friends, however. But that teamwork between your small four man crew is great. And you'll go on to play more heists... If one of you buys them.   I would only suggest getting this game if you have friends who are willing to get it too, or already have it, or you plan to get a four pack to give to your mates. Because the only way this game will ever be fun is when you're playing with your friends. No other time. Yes, they may keep dishing o9ut DLC's, but that also just means updating it regularly. For a price. Still, amazing game.   TL;DR version  Single player- Horrible.  Community- OH GOD NO. BACK HISSSSSS.  DLC's-SO... SO... MANY...  Updates- Very Frequent. Playing with friends- Amazing.  Only get if you have friends to play with.  6.5/10

***EDITED***  So the developers made an awesome concept in Payday 2. The heists can be a lot of fun and there used to be tons and tons of positive things to say about the game.   However the developers released a constant stream of what could reasonably be called over-priced DLC to fund the game. A lot of it included superior gear and such, which smacked a bit of P2W but end of the day at least they were continuing to actively support the game and that's a good thing. Buying all the DLC for this game is way, way, way more expensive than buying any other AAA title and all its expansions out there but at least it felt like a good sized chunk of content. This game isn't good because the core design is flawed. The gameplay consists of generic FPS mowing down countless enemies which is extremely simple. The other portion of the gameplay involves looking at a timer count down until you can move to the next objective, where you will watch another timer countdown, and then another....until you finish the level.  Despite attempts to implement a strategy element into this game, there still isn't any. There are different branching classes that you can pick but there are clearly optimal ways to skill your character which generally involves getting as much tank as possible.  It's hard to recommend a game that shipped unfinished. The majority of the levels upon release were really just the same level with one alteration, and it remains that way today. The small number of actual missions to complete make this game something you can clear in a few hours with friends and the replayability value is really only in maxing out all your levels so you can become 'infamous' -- essentially, reset your levels like prestiging in call of duty.  This game actually had a lot of promise however it is squandered on poor level design where you're really only there to camp for X minutes while fighting enemies that have extremely poor AI and have predictable spawn points that you can camp.

So,   The first thing you feel when jumping into the game is how badass the setting in. Woof, finally a good cops and robbers game! The music is fun and add a lot to the action sequences within the missions and it sets an awesome ambiance. The mechanics seem to be split up into stealth and combat, both of which are playable and fun. The shooter mechanics are at the standard of most FPS titles nowadays. The stealth mechanics are straightforward and are fun. Their features include guards on patrol with field of vision, cameras with dead zones and small objectives. While neither of these aspects are revolutionary, some innovation on the developer’s part is to meld them together nicely into missions where a mishap can turn a stealth mission into a hot fury of bullets and dead cops.  The challenge level and fun factor I find are linked to access to competent teammates, which are in turn affected by the amount of big guns or perk decks unlocked in DLC. While this is somewhat of an annoyance, and you sometimes find crappy team mates, it hardly cripples the game on the spectrum of P2W. I see it as a coop game, and if your buddy has better guns you should be happy. It’s collective winning. If there were a PVP element I would disagree, but KD isn’t affected. You can still access DLC maps/heists if someone else hosts and get achievements for it, just not host the DLC maps you don’t have yourself.   As mentioned, DLC has a big impact on some of the character/weapon/class customisation options. If you don't have any DLC of which to speak of, you may find yourself underpowered in a few cases. They also have a whole micro transaction business model that apparently breaks the game. These come in form of safes, which are dropped randomly in loot at the end of heists along with the more rare drills. The drills can be purchased online and when combined with safes give a random weapon skin. Rarer weapon skins give damage boosts. Can you still have fun without them? Yes. P2W in a PVE setting isn't that bad all things considered and the advantages the skins give aren’t that gamebreaking.   Final verdict:  Fun, I like it. I bought it during the steam summer sale for cheap (less than 20$CAN) and it came with a bunch (4-6?) of DLC. I don't recommend getting it full price and paying for all the DLC at their current average price of 5$ CAN. If you do, it may end up costing something like 60$, the average price of a brand new game. If only Gabe Newell were a Marxist. But Obama just haad to ruin that.

TL;DR: Great game, Lots of missions, Lots of upgrades, Too many hackers. I'd rate this game a 9/10 because after a while it can get boring  This game should be called Heist Simulator 2013. When the game had first came out it was the sequel to Payday: The Heist which i didn't like nearly as much as Payday 2. I didn't purchase Payday 2 myself a friend had purchased a 4-pack of the game before it had launched and asked me to play. This is one of the first games that i had on Steam on the day of release being one of the first 1000 players to log in i had instantly enjoyed it. The introduction was amazing, the characters seemed to have a huge backstory and was pretty good on it's own.  In Payday 2 the entire goal of the game is to break into vaults and complete missions setup through contacts such as Vlad, The Elephant and others, Ever mission has several difficulties that are increasingly more rewarding based on what difficulty you play.  Payday 2 is still very commonly updated and has a decent sized community although like other partially online games the community has been invaded by cheaters and people who ruin the game for others.   I should also mention that their are tons of weapons and upgrades, not to mention 4 unique skill trees that provide you with many benefits if you choose to pick one of these skill trees.   The heists are all very unique and have you doing a wide array of objectives from being a small town crook breaking into a jewelry store to stealing rare and expensive paintings to robbing national banks. This game even has you make meth and sell it.  A new addition to the game is the live-action intro for the game which couldn't be better put together and is just truly amazing and a great work of art, there should be a Payday 2 movie.  Although this game yields a lot of playtime, if you decide to play with random people you might encounter a hacker that will ruin your experience. After playing the game for a long time the game can lose it's value, but that doesn't matter because the next patch usually includes new heists or something to explore and see.  I rate this game 9/10.

So after I finally buying all DLC for this game (3/22/2016). I now feel I can fully review this. I am going to seperate this into 3 seperate groups: The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly.  The Good +The community is not as bad as people say. People who say they always get kicked normally have a reason. +The teamwork element of this game is fantastic. +Alot of variety in weapons +Game is not too demanding in specs. I'm running it on medium-high on my 1.5GHz AMD A4-5000 & AMD Radeon 8330 +Loads of content +Lots of achievments +You have a sense of accomplishment (almost) every heist +As somewhat sais above, it encourages teamwork, but it's also just as fun if you want to play by yourself +Multiple ways to do (mostly) every heist. +99.9% of the glitches are hilariuos and not even game breaking. +In-depth skill system so you can choose what role you want to play on your team  The Bad - The third=person animations (but funny as hell) - There are alot of glitches and exploits to earn alot of money, ruining the fun factor and turns into Farming Simulator 2016. - The DLC in this game is fairly cheap, but is about $150 CDN for every single paid one. - This game is P2P (Peer to Peer) and the stability of the lobby depends all on the host. But usually it's on the Dev's side. - Lots of glitches (But like I said above, not game breaking)  The Ugly (Basically the complaints. There's gonna be long comments) - MICROTANSACTIONS: WHO CARES! The developers need money to make the game better so wether you choose to or not, it's up to you. It's not like other development companies have broken a promise. It's called Buisness. It happens.  - Hackers are about the game. But usually they host their own lobbies. If you're stupid enough to turn off auto-kick cheaters and you don't want cheaters, it's on you. Plus they're nice people. They just want to have more fun. - The content of some DLC is quite underwhelming, The Gage Historical pack is one. Even though the weapons are fun to play with, they're not too great.  That basically sums up my review. I would highly reccomend this game as long as you're not a butthurt about new things (and have friends). Wether you buy it or not is totally up to you. But If you do, buy the GOTY edition on sale. It usually goes for around $13 CDN. Now I leave you with a poem I made (maybe this will convince you more than my review did idk):  I was only 13 years old.  I loved PAYDAY 2 so much.  I had all of the DLC's. Even the Christmas Soundtrack. Every night I would Pray to Almir.  'Hoxton is love' I say, 'Hoxton is Life'.  My dad bursts into the room and calls me a cloaker. I knew he was just jealous of my Devotion to Hox.  I called him a level grinder. He slaps me with a money bundle and downs me. I'm in jail now. And my face is full of paper cuts.  Then I feel something touch me.  It was Hoxton!  I was ready.  I weakened my vault for Hoxton. He screams 'It's PAYDAY fellas!' and grabs me with his powerful, British hands. He starts to use his thermal drill to penetrate my vault.  The thermal paste hurt and melted my skin. There were 300 seconds left, but I was doing it for Hox.  He calls Bain and fills my offshore account with loadsamone and grinds me to the next infamy. Then my dad bursts into the cell.  Hoxton looks him in the eye and says:  'Did ya miss me ya ♥♥♥♥♥♥!?'.    He then get blown out of jail by the PAYDAY Gang.   Hox is love. Hox is life.

I don't believe it. After 2.8 years, I'm actually about to recommend this game. This still comes with some heavy caveats, but it has at last reached a state that I can say is worth picking up. Two major changes have inspired this. One: The effective removal of microtransactions. This is hardly praise for the game, since it should never have been implemented, ever. However, of all the developers that have tried it, OVERKILL is the first I've seen that has actually canceled it after it was implemented. There is no way to completely remove them, since safes still exist in the game that require paid drills, which you can still buy for existing safes, but these safes will no longer drop in the game. All new safes will be free to open. I'm somewhat appalled at how quick the community was to 'forgive' OVERKILL with a flood of glowing reviews due to this change, even after their long-term treatment of the community. I don't think it's possible to forgive them. Again, it never should have happened in the first place, but the gesture is appreciated. Two: A rebalancing of skills in the game. Every single skill is now viable and worth picking up, and every skill in each branch is closely related to each other, so you never feel like you're 'wasting' points on one skill to reach another. Old 'necessary' skills are now unlocked for everyone without investment. You can try any combination of skills and still be useful to your team.  If you pick up the base game, everything has now been balanced well enough that the base weapons have decent variety and can be competitive with DLC weapons, but brace yourself for a massive wall of locked content. If you intend to pick up any weapon or character packs for the perk decks, spend plenty of time researching and reading reviews to see what's worthwhile for you. There are many heists you can't play, but you should be able to find someone who can host them for you. With the latest update, there is enough content and play variety to explore to keep you uniquely entertained for plenty of time to make it worthwhile...but it comes at the price of lots and lots of locked content, and a big, big install size. Think carefully before deciding how much to invest, because even though OVERKILL has been doing their best to make the right decisions after the Goat Simulator DLC (yes, really), we've been burned by them before.

Payday 2 is a huge improvement over the first game. Although I enjoyed playing the first, I found several aspects of it quite basic and uninteresting, such as the level up system. In Payday 2, this level system has been thrown out and replaced with diverse skill trees and specializations for 4 different class types. The level system isn't the only improvement though. The weapons are much more realistic and fun to use and the sound effects are incredible (including the amazing soundtrack). The heists are more varied and much more complicated, with many different random elements that change every time you play.   It’s very satisfying to pull off a difficult heist and get paid lots of money. Compared to the first game, this money can actually be used to buy things! After you finish a heist, you will get a random drop of either weapon parts, masks (or mask parts), or extra money. These can be purchased and used to customize your gear. The customization of the masks is really interesting as there are supposedly hundreds of different options.  The gameplay is solid with intense firefights and good stealth opportunities. This allows heists to be completed in different ways. The special enemies from the first game make a return (although I haven’t seen any Cloakers yet). Something else that returns from the first game is the supremely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ civilian AI. Quite often they will get up and run in front of players as they are shooting at police. Sometimes they even run away from the police which is understandable because the police pretty much use them as cover. This AI is the only core issue I have with Payday 2 so far. There are infrequent crashes, but I think these problems will be fixed in upcoming patches from Overkill.   I love Payday 2 and it’s one of my favourite co-op games ever. It’s fun, exciting, and good to play with friends. I highly recommend it to people who enjoy shooters and certainly to those who even remotely enjoyed the first game. You will get a lot of hours out of this one, I know I will :)

It's no big secret that Overkill, PAYDAY 2's developers, have made some questionable choices in the past few updates. Between weapons skins and a number of uninspired DLCs a lot has gone down, often for the worse.   But  Beneath the shady marketing gimmicks, beneath every 'Medieval Pack' type DLC, PAYDAY 2 is still a co-op experience nearly unmatched in depth. Every heist of reasonable difficulty requires some level of coordination, be it as simple as providing covering fire for a busy teammate or as complex as assigning specific task to specific players. The combination of skill trees and perk decks leads to a highly customizable experience, while the large number of similar yet ever so slightly different weapons means one still has flexibility within a specific build.   The variety of heists, even in the base game, is impressive, ranging from the sneakest of sneaks, to the shootiest of shootouts, and everything in between. Often the outcome of one day of a heist can and will affect how the second or third day plays out. Much variability to be had.  On the note of DLCs. Personally, I think there are DLCs out there that are very much worth your time, and the uninspired ones that Overkill has garnered a reputation for are surprisingly few and far in between. As I glance at a list of DLC, I find maybe four from over twenty that I would consider truly awful. The rest serve to bring a lot of needed variety into the base game, be it new weapons, characters, or heists. There is the cost, of course, but frankly with Steam sales it essentially becomes a nonissue. I simply waited until a sale, then dropped a ten spot and scooped up all the best DLC for the game and believe me it has made it that much more enjoyable.   So say what you will about PAYDAY 2 being a 'DLC simulator'. Spew as much garbage as you want at Overkill for weapon skins and what not. But at PAYDAY 2's core still lies one of the finest mulitplayer video games on the market. And frankly the DLCs aren't as bad as they're made out to be. Especially when, on sale, a lot of the best ones will run you about a dollar. If you're on the fence about PAYDAY 2, trust me. It's worth your while.   Also there's skydiving. And chicken masks. And is home to the deadliest forklifts in the universe.

It's a good game, plenty of fun. The negative reviews are mostly about the company (whatever) and are mainly concerned with the excessive DLC. Good news, there's a solution: Get money. Wait for a sale. Spend $20. Alternatively, you could spend $0 on the DLC and enjoy the core game and its numerous free updates.  Payday 2 is essentially Violent Capture the Flag. Every level involves carrying around loot or objectives and bringing them to a safe spot. Both the stealth and 'loud' flavors of these missions behave as expected, and the game mixes up the objectives enough between rounds to keep the formula from growing stale.  There's a plethora of weapons, masks, and modifications in the vanilla game, but the bulk of them are now behind pay walls. It's not truly an issue, since any level can be approached in a wide variety of ways, and none of them are impossible (or for that matter, any harder) without the DLC. All of the skill trees are available without DLC, though more 'perk' and weapon options are available to purchase.  My biggest gripe is the latency: no matter how great your connection is, there will be lag between what you see and what your teammates are doing. I've shared a network with other players at a LAN party, and there was still 4-5 seconds of lag. It becomes even more pronounced online, where I've experienced up to 15 seconds of latency issues. This is, frankly, unacceptable in a game that depends to heavily on tight cooperation. Stealth missions can easily be ruined because a player wasn't alerted that a guard sensed them until several moments after the fact. Payday 2 feels like a very unique shooter, with a large variety of heists and skills etc. I'll cover a few categories:  Gameplay: The gameplay is unique, with a nice feel to the game. Although sometimes the game can feel clunky or lacking in some areas, these problems can be fixed with a few mods. The graphics of the game are nothing spectacular, but they aren't bad by any stretch of the imagination.   Skills/Classes: 'Classes' aren't really a thing in Payday 2, but skills most definitely are. With 5 different skill trees, all with a reasonably large number (don't know the specific number) of skills, the game feels varied with each different skill you pick. You will (mostly) notice a difference in gameplay depending on the skills selected, which leaves room for different types of skill sets and play styles. There are some skills which are clearly 'inferior', per say, but that in no way makes the game unbalanced (unless you pick all of said skills). Occasionally, the developers will come out with some kind of skill or perk that is unbalanced in some way, but they usually fix it quickly enough. Speaking of the developers, let's go on to a more recent and sensitive topic.  Micro transactions: At the beginning of time, when the developers first announced this game, they said it would never have micro transactions. They didn't lie...until recently. They added weapon skins, which are almost only obtainable if purchased (I know, I know - Card drops. But the drop chance for drills is so low, it might as well not exist). To get the weapon skins, you must get safes and drills. The safes are relatively easy to obtain. The drills are the problem, with an insanely low drop rate. If you don't mind the weapon skins existence and you choose to ignore them, then that's NO problem for you. You don't even need to read the rest of this paragraph! But, if you fall to temptation, or get a thrill from opening things that you think 'I'll get lucky this time' and then end up giving you the same skin as the last fifty times you told yourself that, then it can be a bit of a problem. I suffer from the second, and have spent a reasonable sum of money on skins for guns. I haven't ventured down the road of buying legendary skins for hundreds of pounds/dollars, but I have spent large sums. It isn't game changing, but for some it is an annoyance.  DLC: Dear god. Next to micro transactions, this is one of the most annoying things for many in payday. It is LATHERED in DLC. The DLC's aren't 'needed' per say, but they are very very game changing. I have bought most of the DLC's, in an attempt to get better equipment and more varied skill and weapon sets, but I personally dislike the high number of DLC's they have. It's a difficult subject, and for some it ruins the entire outlook on the game, so look into it before you buy.  Story: The game has some sort of jumbled up, hard to follow storyline. But honestly, it isn't even worth paying attention to. That's a personal view, but I feel that the story is so indirect it might as well not be there. That's literally all I have to say about that. Now, for the final paragraph, and my favourite...  Characters: The ****ing payday characters are some of the best characters in games I've played. The dialogue is mostly comedic, and all the characters feel like different people. Whether you want to be Hoxton (OLD, NOT HOUSTON...Damned impostor), an angry British guy who uses swearing like its his second language, or Jacket who speaks through audio recordings or Bonnie, the Scottish female equivalent of Hoxton who has a comedic accent and interesting lines. All of the characters are interesting and fun to play. They make no difference to gameplay, just dialogue, so you can pick your favourite based purely on characteristics.   So, to conclude, Payday is an all round good game about robbing things and killing people and all those fun, illegal things you can't do in real life. Its one of my personal favourites, and I'd recommend it to almost anyone to try.

This review used to be an intentionally inflammatory two word remark. I don't normally write serious reviews but here it is.  1.  Crime.net  is an overly elaborate server list that wastes a lot of time for seemingly no reason. Buying contracts solves a problem that really shouldn't exist to begin with. 2. Game is 100% grind. Grind for skill points, grind for perk points, grind for money, grind for unlocks. What's wrong with just playing the game? Why does everything in modern games have to be about totting up some arbitrary numbers and then pitting those arbitrary numbers against real-time random number generators? Is that our only sense of accomplishment now? These number games have their place in RPGs but have no business in a twitch action shooter/stealth game simulating the things that the player's input should be responsible for. I think I'll just play Left 4 Dead, thanks. 3. Daily jobs with player-selected rewards is a good system that, once again, solves a problem that really shouldn't exist to begin with. The grind exists to artificially extend the length of the game beyond its meagre amounts of actual content. This also serves as an excellent way to incentivize players to pay up for DLC content. You know what we call this model? 'Free to play'. 4. Stealth is boring and often involves sitting around and waiting once all guards and civilians are dealt with. The stealth-only missions are worthless and I only want to avoid them like the plague. 5. Even if you seek out loud missions the game discourages you from playing them too much by inducing a penalty for repeat plays. 6. Mission selection is trash without all DLC packs. Also, all DLC amounts to around $80. How about I just go buy another game with that money, Overkill?  But hey, sometimes it's just fun to play with friends.  Oh, and Simon Viklund's soundtrack is great, as always.

Not sure why every ♥♥♥♥♥y comment I see complains about Microtransactions. For real, everything that could be considered a Microtransaction is completely pointless to the main game. If someone wants to pay for the chance at a skin, then who the hell cares? Let them, that's their money. Microtransactions should only ever been an issue if it impedes or slows progress in the game.  Here's an actual review of the GAME.  From what I can see, the game has gone through several changes since its release, not all of which I like. Older versions of the game did not have the Pager System as prevelent as it is now in stealth missions. The legitimacy of a Pager system on guards that are killed completely silently is in question for me, I don't see it as a good addition, but so be it. Only being able to carry one key card at a time, stupid. Being unable to carry more than a maximum of 6 Cable Ties? Seriously, those things are small. I could carry 100 of them if I tried. Especially with all the guns I pack.  Anyways, I understand the need for game-balancing, but there's better ways to do it.  Overall, I enjoy the Stealth portions of the game MUCH more than any Loud portion. Partially because I play solo or with one friend. Loud missions in high difficulties tend to go wrong pretty quickly when your AI teammates are all but useless. So there's a downside. Stealth provides a proper challenge, but due to the aforementioned issues of carrying capacity, it also unfairly challenges me. I press on anyhow and am satisfied that I can do most of the Stealth-capable Missions solo on DeathWish. Oh, and to hell with DeathWish Loud missions. Like, no. (Note: I have not gotten the supposed meta-Perk deck at this moment).  The game is undoubtably more fun with more people, and I'm hoping to get together more of a group, because going solo does get tedious and loses its fun after awhile. I do think there is an ungodly amount of DLC, but here's the thing, none of it is required. Pick and choose what you want to get or don't get any at all. It's a game, you pay to play. If there's a mission you want to play, yes you have to pay for the mission. Just like you pay for the game. Wait for it to go on sale, Payday 2 goes on sale fairly often compared to most games. The DLCs become real cheap.  Overall, I think if you've read this far into my review: Research the game. Watch it get played on Youtube and make a judgement call. Better with friends.
