Ah man, payday 2..... where to start on payday 2. A game about heisting and getting loot,where being geedy can be great motivation, or your bitter end. The sound in the game is phenominal, as are the visuals, but i have always been a man about gameplay myself and it has tons of that. Mechanics wise it works well as well, although there are a few options in stealth which sometimes make your head scratch, but that is what i am a perfectionist who will repeatedly try the same mission over and over till i reach that blissful perfect score. And in this game until you fully understand the core mechanics you will probably be doing alot of loud heists. That said going in loud is still great fun, watching a head pop is always great, but what truly sets it apart is how you plan, makingor breaking certain missions with the equipment you bring. Surviving a loud DW mission in a suit after stealth breaks with no doctor bags, always gets the adrenaline pumping, and maybe even your budies hating each other when it does fail.Of course the difference can be between firing and not firing, sometimes the latter being the best sloution so you can hold out a little longer and not be instanly gunne down, especially on DW. And speaking of DW, the game definately takes a drastic difficulty spike, compared to overkill and below, but not a bad thing, because it gets the nerves going even more knowing one wrong move can doom your team. So obviously, this is a coop driven game, where singleplayer was never originaly planned, so its not meant as much for singleplayer as bots cannot do objectives, or carry bags, but they do make mighty fine meatshields! Even though its not geared toward singleplayer it is still good even by yourself, and really thats when the learning really takes place, where you can learn your xxx's and ooo's on stealthing, unless you have a good coop buddy to teach you. And OVERKILL has continued supporting this game for quite some time and will be adding even more, so it will continue to expand. From the guns, to masks, this is an all around great game, to the little gems, and videos. To bad they dont have a video archive, where we could go back and watch our favorite intro videos, which are actual continuation of our fabled journey through D.C. All in all great game keep Heisting!!!

Review  After my friends have bugged me to get this game, I finally did. It is an action-packed multiplayer shooter where you have to complete various heists of different difficulty. It is fun with friends, but that's about it. Joining games with random people is a nightmare because they often ragequit, and the singleplayer is just a fail. On singleplayer, the AI don't do anything to help you, so it's basically just you doing all of the work. Most of the missions are fun, but others are just plain stupid. The mission selection screen seems like the developers thought it would be a good idea to make players wait for missions to randomly popup, but it is not. After you complete each mission, most of the money goes to an 'off-shore account' where you basically can't ever use it except for buying certain things. In my opinion, they should have just not told you most of the money is going to an off-shore account, because it makes players rage when they see how much they actually get. As for buying upgrades, everything in the shop is ridiculously expensive. The game is pretty fun for trying to work together as a team though, and the developers did that pretty well. For most heists, you have to choose whether to stealth it, or go in guns blazing, which is another feature that I really like. Team work and strategy in my opinion are the two things that the developers did really well.  Bugs  I didn't notice very many bugs, but the AI is horrible. Cops just stand there shooting you and rarely go into cover. Same for the AI of your team-mates when you don't have 4 players.  Overall  7.5/10  If you don't have any friends to play this with, I don't reccomend getting it. If you have friends to play with, it is a great game to have fun with friends. The price is way too high for the quality you get. The game does manage to be fun most of the times with friends, which is why I reccomend this and gave it a 7.5 instead of a lower score

When Payday 2 first came out it was a very entertaining, if not difficult game. Even so the somewhat high skill cap encouraged team work, adaptability, and most importantly tenacity. Then the first updates came and they were a welcome gift from those at Overkill. Some more guns, a few different playstyles, and even a fun story to play through multiple heists. The DLC was priced a little high for some people but it wasn't nessasary to play the game.  Now we come to what I see today. I see a game that doesn't require teamwork, or skill, or even god forbid the will to finish a heist after a mistake. I see a game where DLC is needed for most average players to even have a chance at beating some of what used to be heists to train on. I see content being rendered obsolete by the constant power creep that you see in many online games. But where most try to balance out everything only the most recent additions seem to matter here.  I cannot recomend this game to anyone at this time. It is not worth the money.  If you must play Payday wait for Payday:The Heist to go on sale.

Well I have not got onto DLC just yet.  DLC in this game is.. kinda forced/needed to actually play the game. I am not saying you do not need to get DLC however some of the packs are actually good and offer rather a lot of different play styles and weapons. Some of these DLC packs however are really really terrible. As such e.g (John Wick Weapon Pack) It is $4 for me and you basically get nothing. Now like I said this is not forced. Besides that if you can look past DLC, the game is very well made. It has a great community. (before it dies) and I have always enjoyed it personally. Skins. Well.. Are alright they are a nice touch. Safes. Just why. And most maps are fun. Apart from Shadow raid on One down when your friend throws a grenade hoping it will help...  I would recommend this game if you are looking for a casual shooter. But if you were really looking into buying DLC or other types of more content for it. Just wait until a sale.. Since I last time I had revised my review, Overkill have changed many things in the past months.  One of the big problems that people felt was 'Pay to Win' was the fact that if you bought into the micro transactions you could get a Stat Boost weapon skin, as the name says it would boost a specific stat for the gun with the skin equipped on it, since then Stat Boosts and Team Boost are both available COMPLETELY FREE from the card drop system and monthly side jobs (I have gotten a ton already) and on the bonus side these stat boosts can be equipped on any weapon, not just the ones that they chose to have a skin.  Now that they have made the stat boosts available for free to all players via card drops and monthly side jobs I hardly feel that the 'Pay to Win' aspect of these skins are there, or should I say a big problem anymore.  As for the absurd amount of DLC the game contains I hardly see any of it is necessary towards an enjoyable time on PAYDAY (Unless you plan to host your own game), since the Rebalance and the addition of a community LMG and Sniper the DLC seem hardly 'Pay to Win' At least for a majority of them, there are some which make the game rather easy (To the point that I don't touch them as I feel they are rather cheap) would be the Sokol Character pack's Grinder Perk deck (Gives you regenerating health for shooting cops).  As for this, I do feel the need to address this tiny detail, the developers in the past have made several promises and never came through on them or released a lack luster version of their promise as well as lied.  Though, the game as a product is really well made, it's extremely fun, has a great soundtrack and gives you reasons to keep playing as it's still being updated and receiving fresh content even after 2 years. I may not like somethings regarding business practices or some of the content that has been released but I would be lying if I told you, I had no fun with this game, as I still play it today.

I personally love this game. I've had it for almost a year, and it instantly became one of my favorite games. I play it with my friends, I play it by myself, and it has countless replayability. Now the DLC, that's a whole different story. Yes there are weapon packs. Yes there are heist packs. And yes, there are character packs. But even with these, the game is still very playable and very fun. I didn't own any DLC for 5 months and I still played. Now their are DLC that I recommend getting like some of the weapon packs and a few of the heists, but get them on sale. It's 50 bucks for all the heists alone. I bought almost all the DLC (none of he character packs) for $20 during a small sale. Now that I've gotten all that out of the way, why don't you buy this game, maybe buy it for your friends, and play this game. I played the first game (PAYDAY: The Heist), and I LOVED it. I was so excited to finally see PAYDAY 2 announced.  I preordered it along with my cousin and some friends, and we got beta keys and played the beta. It was amazing. New graphics, heists, weapons, all that.  Then it finally came out, all this new stuff was amazing. I didn't really get to play it much until now, which, I can say completely, is very, very, very disappointing.  The game is fun. It always has been. It's challenging and sometimes rage-inducing, but it's a ton of fun. Playing with friends is obviously the best. While there is a good amount of content you get with just buying PAYDAY 2 (not GOTY), I am very deeply disappointed in OVERKILL for doing what they did with this game.  Over half of the content is locked behind a paywall. That means you buy a game for $20 and you get less than half of what you should be getting. They want you to buy DLC for almost everything in the game. From weapons, mods, and heists to masks, colors, materials, and patterns. It's absolutely ridiculous and it's a horrible business model.  Let me put this into perspective.  -You launch up Four Stores as a newbie on Very Hard. Kinda challenging, if you've never played before/don't have much experience. -You complete the heist, grabbing all possible loot, losing 2 of your friends, and having a rage fit because you got downed right before you escaped, leaving your last friend to complete the mission. -You receive your money, earning x amount of dollars. It feels nice to finally get your hard-earned, ill-gotten gains. -You get to the PAYDAY screen, and you pick the left card. The other two cards flip, revealing a mask and a weapon mod. -Your card flips, and it reveals a mask. -You go to your inventory only to find that the mask you just spent 45 minutes getting is only available for you to use IF, and ONLY IF you spend $4.99 more to buy the resperctive DLC pack.  Yeah, that's pretty much how it can go. It's not often, but the number of default unlockable masks compared to DLC masks is staggering. The DLC masks make up at least over half of the unlockable masks. This is the same for weapons and weapon mods. In fact, there are more DLC weapons and weapon mods than there are default. Payday 2 is a fun game. That is why I recommend it, because in truth, it is probably one of my favorite games. HOWEVER. Overkill has been sucking money out of the hundreds of thousands of people who play the game, and that is not cool at all. The only way I can actually recommend you buy this, is when it and it's DLC's are on sale, that way you can give them the least amount of money possible. Because they don't deserve it.   However, this isn't a review on Overkill, this is a review on the game Payday 2, so here we go.  Pro's- -4 player Co-op, with friends or with random people -Several perk trees to use, which allow you to play the game in different ways based on preference. -Several perk decks to use which further expand your playstyle, BUT.... you have to pay for a lot of them -Gunplay is fairly decent and there's a wide range of guns to use, BUT... you have to pay for a lot of them -Wide variety of heists to do BUT... you have to pay for a lot of them -An incredible amount of masks you can customize with an obscene amount of patterns, styles, and colors, BUT... you have to pay to get most of these things.  Are you sensing a pattern here? All the pros have cons tacked onto the ♥♥♥-end of them, all because Overkill decides everything has to cost money.  Cons- -You have to pay for alot of the game.  -Dear lord the MICROTRANSACTIONS. I've decided to not talk about them until now, because this is a pretty 'sensitive topic'. Basically, Overkill said they would never put microtransactions in their game. But they did. It wouldn't be an insanely big deal if these were JUST weapon skins, but they ACTUALLY EFFECT YOUR GAMEPLAY. Now, this isn't a game like CS:GO, so you're not going to be using these skins against other players, but come on. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. -Co-op with randoms is difficult. Most people don't know what they're doing, and won't listen to simple commands etc. You're better off finding a group of your friends, or getting lucky and finding a group of randoms you will stick with.  This game doesn't have that many cons, as you can see. The only problem, is the first con is tacked onto almost every pro, and if Overkill just let you buy the game and enjoy it in it's entirety, this would be one of the best games i've ever played. But almost everything costs money, and until you pay, you're not going to be experiencing the full game.  Once again, I RECOMMEND THIS GAME. It's fantastic, and fun with a group of people. But I only advise you buy it when it's on sale as cheap as you can get it.

PAYDAY 2 is a crime game set across all of the United States. The main antagonists are known as the Payday Gang. Dallas, Chains, Wolf, Houston, and Hoxton. PAYDAY 2 expands on the concept of it's predecessor, PAYDAY: The Heist with more characters, weapons, heists, and more. And the game is damn amazing. OVERKILL has made a truly wonderful game that plays well, looks ok, runs meh, and has a great soundtrack. The game recently had a surge of hate from it's community, but that has since been dealt with for the most part, and I gotta give OVERKILL massive props for giving the people what they want. More than likely, I will be continuing to play this game for the 18 months they continue to support it.   Though the game is a little glitchy, and does tend to crash a fair amount, which is frustrating, not to mention the net code needs a ton of work. There's way too much desync, and disconnections from other players unless you have a wired connection.   But, all that said, this is one of the best games to play with friends, and a good way to live crime without consequence. This game gets a well deserved 8.5/10.

Dear reader; i actually do recommend this game. The thumbs down is only here to send a signal to all the game-devs around. Read about the introductions of Microtransactions in Payday2 if you want to know more.   This is another good example on a great gameconcept turned sour. You get to play the crook who steals n kills his way to a virtualfortune in coop or solomode.This can be done loud, masks on and guns blazing, or stealthy with sneaky ninja-approach. Its spiced up with skilltrees in a rpg-manner most gamers are used to.  It could be a really good game but theres so many issues its mindboggeling. I really tried to see the good over the bad but its just not possible imho  Pros- Coop. you can play with friends or in publicgames, or with bots if theres noone around  LOOT! who doesnt like the loot from a job well done?  Great gameconcept. Youre the crook who robs n steal n kill cops while listening to progressive electronic music  Difficultylevel is increasing slowly with highest setting being hard enough to make public games a pain   Cons-  P2p connections. Can be really hard to even join a game if host have slow internet. If host leaves, game is shut down and all progress is lost.  Host have supreme power regarding kicking and lot of games ends up with all players but the host being kicked near escape-zone  Cheats. So many players use cheats/hax and it seems theres noone who try to control it. VACbans is nonexisting  DLC-fest. You have to pay 5-7 euro for a cpl of guns, a new character or a heist you can finish in very short time ie 1 heist have a 14sec completionachievement  You have to wait for ages to get a certain hesit available, or pay ingame cash to get it. You cant choose what you want from a list, they spawn randomly. And you need the cash to develop you character. Buying heists will delay the process a lot. Endgame tho doesnt have that issue  Graphics is just below the quality u see in Battlefield2  Community is in rage over the repeated failure of the devs to even act as humans  No Steam-workshop.   No Custommaps.   Superstupid/bugged AI, poor AI pathing.  Mobs have no arms/legs hitboxdetection. You can only shoot them in the torso and head! in a 2013 game..  Only a handful of good official heists.  Did i mention DLC-fest ?? 100 euro so far, or apx twice the basecost of vanillagame. No seasonpass available  Ingame mic doesnt work in most cases or is very low. Imagine that in coop!  Devs not correctin bugs very often. Dont provide whats promised regardin free dlc or Saferoom customization  Paid DLC doesnt offer anything a modder couldnt do.  As of January 2016 devs are still optimizing game for Windows XP and Vista, have downgraded textures  Micro-transaction in a RNG-based lootboxsystem, where the devs repeatedly have promised there would NEVER be any MTs- you now have the option to pay realcash for loot, once one of the pro´s  Devs are in numerous occasions downright lying, have a really bad attitude towrds the community(see link in comments for a sample of it)  250.000$ in pricemoney unlocked by fans during PAYDAYCON has vanished  All in all.. this sux. If you get butthurt over micro transaction, then don't buy this game.  Now, at the time of writing i have spent close to 470 hours and i wouldn't want it any other way. You will have to spent a lot of money if you want access to all, but you can still play everything, as you can still join a host that has the DLCs.  What i love about the game is the fact that it frustrates the absolute hell out of me, but never to the point where i would stop playing (outside of crashes). It just pushes me far enough to make it personal. This is the game, me and my friends always play. The one thing we can always agree on. It has gotten to the point, where most of our in-jokes are a result of this game.  If you are using to playing any other FPS, outside of PAYDAY: The Heist, and you try to act the same here, YOU WILL DIE. There are no two-ways about that fact. The horde of enemies simply do too much damage for you to withstand, even when you build yourself for taking damage. That said, you are getting shot at by dozens of enemies at a time, so no big surprise there.  I am no fan of electronic music, but the music is AWESOME. It fits the mood of the game, and prepares you for when the Police Assault hits (this is the part, where spawns ramp up and EVERYONE comes to wreck your fun.)  If you wanna steal stuff, feel like a badass or you just want to wreak ♥♥♥♥, i recommend.  The combination of the horde and the Special Police Units (similar to a game like Left 4 Dead) constantly tries to shake you lose and are a VERY good source of challenge. Just for a quick summary of the current ones:  Shield: These enemies use (big surprise) Riot shields, that you will need a Sniper, explosives or Incendiaries to bypass. These guys are all about dislodging you from your good position and we have had plenty of times, where they have actively stolen me (either dragging me while downed or picked me up), which has gotten us killed on several occasions.  Snipers: Self explanatory. Little health, higher accuracy and massive damage. Pro tip: if you see the red lazer, just run. It is granted to miss its first shot while you are on the move.  Cloaker: Oh, how many a heist has been foiled by this twit. With only a decent amount of health and poor damage, he doesn't seem to be much of a threat. Then melee happens. He spawns in inconvenient spots, likes to hide and will down you in one hit. It doesn't count towards instant costudy, but they are faster than you and hard to dodge.  Taser: So, let us take a basic cop, give him a gun that compares to higher end police forces, better armoring and then stick him with a taser. He isn't much of a threat OUTSIDE the fact, that he will tase you. It will lock you movement, randomly fire and prevent all actions, outside of looking and shooting. It does have limited range, and if it downs you (only the tasing, not the army of police that will BUTT♥♥♥♥ you during it) won't count towards instant costudy. He will stop a daring stand or escape.  Bulldozer: Comes in many variants, but same applies to most. He is a pain to take down do to high damage and a MASSIVE health pool. The damage is toned done significantly over range, but he will still hit you. Punch through his face plates and take advantage of his massive headshot multiplier. The Deathwish variant (Nicknamed 'Skulldozer') is a little different. He believes in one thing. F*CK your happiness. He doesn't have any more health than the Black Dozer, but doesn't suffer range penalties AND has even more damage. To balance this, he does have a long reload. Not that you will notice.  S.W.A.T. Sentry gun: Okay, i hate this thing. It has WAAAAY too much health, WAAAAY too much armoring to protect its weak spot, it will repair it self (though only 3 times and not replacing its armor plating.) and has WAAAAY too much damage. You can't pierce its armor either, so good luck trying to kill it. It does have a ridiculous headshot multiplier, it will rarely jam and doesnt move after its deployment (and has fixed spawn point like the sniper.), but he is still a ♥♥♥♥. I reviewed this game two years ago when it was still fairly new and lacking a lot of content. Now, two years later I can finally say I reccomend this game highly. PAYDAY 2 is a 4 player multiplayer co-op First Person Shooter which puts you in the shoes of a career criminal doing everything from robbing convieniance stores and banks to breaking your old crew member out of jail and killing his traitor and more!  This game is not the prettiest looking game out there, but it is rich with content and is very light on your system, especially with the 'Lower Shadow Map' mod made by fans of the game, with this I can run at 30 FPS on a low end laptop from wal mart with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Intel HD Graphics Chip. So most PCs should be able to play this. And once you do, you are in for a wild ride.  The base game sports TONS of hiests with a handful of Heists available as DLC. Each heist is unique in it's own way and they run the gambit from being short, quick runs to long treks through tons of bullets, cops and explosions.  This game is co-op but can be played single-player. Honestly, if you want the best experience, get 3 friends together and go heisting! But online is really the only way to get a solid experience in this game.  This game is not without it's flaws however, there are glitches and bugs that appear after every update, but in my experience it's never really broken (But this is something you have to see and deal with on a patch-by-patch basis)  Is PAYDAY 2 worht your money? Yes, yes it is. with the abundance of unique heists and great co-op experience mixed with varied gameplay makes this game more than worth playing especially if you have friends to play it with. I have nearly 500 hours in this game to show just how addictive this game can be.

Payday 2 is a good and simple, if somewhat overbuilt, action game.   A co-operative FPS, the heists you and the online players can run range from simple ones that last for only a little over a minute at best to giant, cinematic half-hour to hour-long epics. The gameplay isn't the most innovative or (especially) balanced, but it performs capably in doing what it's supposed to. What makes it good is the variety of difficulty levels and stages-so if you want a massive challenge or a simple, easy action, you can easily get both. That's the good part.  The bad part is that the game is indeed 'overbuilt' for lack of a better word. The developers have loaded tons of DLC packs, additional weapons, and (most recently-not to mention controversially) microtransactions into the game. None of this is directly needed to play the game, but it still exists with hordes of extra (often unbalanced) content stuffed on top of the simple gameplay base. Always research and see if you really want it before you buy any additional DLC.  However, being overbuilt does not change the basic quality of the game itself. Not the most advanced or balanced game, but still quite good.

I know there's a lot of negativity surrounding this game since Crimefest and the infamous microtransactions. I've only obtained the game recently at 75% discount (it was on my radar for some time already but wouldn't spend 20 bucks for the bare game) so I can't compare with pre-Crimefest days.  Anyway, I've spent about 15 hours now and am still happy with the purchase. Single Player is nice for tutorial purposes and learning the levels, but not to experience the real game. The fact that you can't give orders to the computer A.I. in your team and that they won't carry bags, make some levels (Slaughterhouse) rather unplayable in single player.  Online mode however fixes those issues. Maybe it's a way the devs want people to play online instead of offline. Sometimes you get kicked for no reason within 2 seconds after joining, but most of the times it has been a pleasant experience. First time playing and finishing the Slaughterhouse was very rewarding. Quite another level than the Jewelry store.   So would I advise to but this game? Sure, but I would wait for a discount (such as the current Steam Autumn Sale) as you can get the game + DLC's for €11,49 instead of €19,99 for the bare game.

Payday 2 is a fantastic game, and still receiving support and updates from its developers even two years down the line. In it, you play from an assortment of characters who on their own have no special capabilities, but by running heists, you earn experience and levels to assign points to various skill trees to flesh out your abilities. The recent updates have rebalanced the weapon sets so that many of them are much more viable than before, and the game continues to receive new heists and equipment as time goes by.  The game has recently come under fire from a vocal group who have mistaken pre-release rumor squashing from two plus years ago as ironclad resolutions (one from a man who no longer works for the company) to prevent a business model from being implemented in a game they enjoy.   What has happened is the game has received something similar to the Mannconomy Update from TF2, where safes can drop after the completion of a heist, and require the use of a key that costs $2.50 to open. The safes, like the crates in TF2, are entirely optional, and offer weapon skins that give minor statistical benefits at worst, and emulate common mod-loadouts while excluding the use of the same mods at best.   Do not let these reviews dissuade you from trying an actually enjoyable game! Just be aware that these are people who, should you join their lobby with one of these weapon skins equipped (as the game shows your character with their chosen mask and any weapon skins when you join), they will kick you to prevent you from playing with them.

Payday 2 is a co-op shooter game with a bit of a twist. Instead of facing off against zombies, or goin' up against one of the many, many faux terrorist organizations that the gaming world can cook up, you're playing the bad guys. Your objective are quite simple: Steal something and get out alive. You get a set of tools, skills, and weapons (even in vanilla, you get quite a bit) to do the dirty deeds, and get (in-game) rich.  The heists are rather varied, ranging from simple bank jobs to more elaborate 'break into museums and steal artifacts' and 'bust some heads while looting a casino'. One issue some may find with this, however, is quite a few of the bigger heists are locked behind DLC. It's rather cheap DLC, however, and when they go on sale, they're dirt cheap. It's worth a wait for most of them.  It's a game worth taking a swing at, really. It's a lot of fun, even when you're playing by yourself.

Payday 2 is an excellent game. While the basic premise is very simple (steal things, shoot cops, repeat), the mechanics of the leveling system as well as the levels themselves keep the game interesting and rewarding. The large number of heists ensures you'll never have to do the same one twice, and the shear variety and imagination of the settings keeps you on your toes.  This game combines an relatively simple leveling system with a complex and varied set of upgrades that allows for vast amounts of character personalization and customization. 4 different skill trees and 6(recently 7) perk decks give ample tools to create the perfect cat burglar, a run and gun John Dillinger of a heister, or a heavily armored enforcer.  Complimenting the leveling is the well designed gun customization system. While relatively simple to use and understand, the amount of different guns and modifications allows for even the pickiest player to create their own perfect firearm for heisting. All the customization is used as well, with different heists requiring careful management of loadout to execute efficently.  Possibly the best part about Payday 2 is the support it recieves from it's developers, Overkill software. This is a game you can expect to continue updating, advancing, and providing new content for the next 2 years, according Overkill's own statement. Bugs are constantly being fixed, features are being added, and new DLC is almost a monthly expectation. All in all, after 500 hours into the game, I can easily say I'm still learning new things within this game. If you enjoy a little mayhem, I can't think of a better game for you. Heist on.

A game perfect for playing with friends, PAYDAY2 offers endless fun, action, and replayability. One of the greatest Tactical FPS games in a long time. My only problems with the game dont derive from the gameplay thank goodness, Money is a ♥♥♥♥♥ to get in this game since the large sum of your money goes into an offshore account (respectively makes sense since I assume all this money is being wired, and if it was being wired to your person's personal account, the fuzz would pick up on all the HUNDREDS of MILLIONS of dollars in your account.) Second problem is the system for unlocking attachments for your guns, which are first unlocked randomly through a 'pick a random card' system at the end of every heist. This can get extreamly annoying (I have yet to experience this on PC though) when you just completed a 3 day job, and you pick a card, you see the gun attechment card pop up as the card you picked, you sit up in excitment waiting for your new attachment. Maybe it will be a new optic for your sniper rifle, or a better stock that increases the concealability of your assault rifle...or maybe it could be a tactical light...and you could already have 4 more of them because you never ever need them and they serve no purpose.  Im not entirely sure if this is a problem on PC, since it was very bad on 360, but you can still unlock attachments for guns you dont own. If you enjoyed Payday the Heist, then i recommend this game. For me, I loved Payday the Heist; it brought those Hollywood Heist movie elements from some of my favorite heist movies (Heat, Point Break, etc), however i thought that while the missions seemed very dynamic and posed their own challenges; the amount and replayability was rather limited. They were good and epic missions, but there wernt that many and missions hardly varied in circumstance. With Payday 2, i think they alleviated some of that monotonous rinse and repeat feel of the original game's missions with their wide variety of missions. and while some of these seem a bit shallow, they definately keep that fresh feel. However, the friendly AI seems to have been SEVERLY weakened since the first game; AI teammates hardly acknowledge Special units, seem almost near obsolete on difficulties higher than Hard with their mediocre choice of weapons and constantly reloading after firing only a few rounds. The problem with the AI seems mainly with their ability to fight specials, they will only fire maybe an average of 6 rounds before reloading and ignoring specials. They will literally run right past cloakers kicking a downed teammate to help them, only to get knocked down themselves by the SAME cloaker, rinse and repeat for any other assisting AI. Overall i think its a pretty good game, despite the problems,

Rating: 7/10  Payday 2 is a multi-player FPS developed by Overkill studios. The basic premise is to plan and pull off heists on banks, jewlery stores and other high value targets. There is no story, per-se, though some heists are 'multi-day' and so therefore have a story within them. There are little bits of background lore from the first game that are expanded on a little as well, but you can know nothing about Payday 1 and still have a clear idea of what is going on.  The game has a heavy focus on customisation, both on the players look and the guns they carry. The player has a mask, which can be customised through patterns, colours and markings, which acts as the main way in which you'll recognise them in the field and menus. The customisation is frankly ill-thought out, the achievement masks have defined ways of unlocking them, but the only other way to unlock masks is by luck through a random system at the end of each heist, which can give you a range of things, many of which are not related to customising the mask. This results in you feeling as though you COULD have a great representation of yourself in the game, but are restricted by the luck system within it. Gun parts are also unlocked in this fashion, but each has it's balancing elements, so it's better thought out and feels deeper than the mask system. Finding just the right combination of parts for your guns is rewarding and satisfying.  Once you're actually into a heist, you'll want to be with friends. The bots in single-player are either a) useless or b) bullet sponges and while the second can be really useful on bank heists, it means you have no way to do higher difficulties without going multi-player. This may not appeal to everyone, but good planning is required on Overkill and Death Wish difficulties. The game rewards good management, but can also punish small mistakes very harshly even on Normal difficulty. It has a steep learning curve, in short, which again may not appeal to everyone. Sometimes police turn psychic as well, which is infuriating. Stealth missions are either really fun (if you're a Ghost) or boring (if you're everyone else). Higher level cops also seem to take a ridiculous amount of firepower to kill, and while this fits with the difficulty of the game, it makes it very frustrating on occasion.  After completing a job using various tools of the trade (drills, emp's etc) you'll be able to assign experience to skills. This is where the game probably shines the brightest. The skill trees all compliment eachother very well, with powerful abilities in the top tier making the difference on higher difficulties, but combining lower tier abilities from each class also works for many heists. A stealthy Ghost can really benefit from the tough Enforcers ability to carry loot faster, for example, and these lower tier traits come into their own during early games, just as the higher tier ones will for later games. This is the mark of a good, well thought out skill system, and it's the games best feature.  The characters voices get really annoying after a while. Bain in particular will make you want to strangle him after a few missions of explaining that a 'big bank is a still a bank' in a crackled voice. Similarly later skills will have you shouting at eachother or civilians and will repeat the same line of dialogue, breaking the atmosphere of the game and hurting the experience. The guns sound a little 'meh' as well, with even the biggest loudest guns not really feeling particularly beefy or loud when you use them.  There is a massive amount of DLC for the game as well, mostly consisting of weapons and missions, and all of it adds something a little different. They're not too heavily priced, so it's worth getting a few and maybe adding more during sales, particularly the Courier Pack and the Armoured Transport pack.  Eventually though, even with this DLC, there's not much to keep you coming back apart from wanting to get the next gun or skill. There's no narrative or character depth, so it's entirely up to you to set the objective for the next few games. If you, like I have, find that there isn't really anything more you want from the skill tree or any more guns, then you'll stop playing, because you will, by that point, likely have played the same heists about 20 times over. There isn't a massive amount of variety, the DLC's help with this to some degree but not massively, and it is fun for a while, but only with friends and only before it starts feeling like it's frustrating to play again.  Overall, it's solid and well made and while it has it's faults I would certainly recommend it. It's not a Grade A shooter, but it's certainly a B and as long as your happy with repetition of the same mission you can get by.

The best way to describe this game is Left 4 Dead, but instead of a Zombie Apocalypse, it's a Heist. Also, it has a deep customisation system with four skill trees, hordes of weapons with customisations and of course, customisable (and very cool, imho) masks for your robber. Additionally, missions (heists) have multiple elements that are randomised each time you play, so it's 'never the same heist twice.'I will be playing this game for quite some time, as Overkill has already promised 12 months of content. The only downside is that the A.I. is kinda dumb sometimes and the graphics are not industry standard, but being as this game is the price of an indy game, it exceeds all expectations.  The TL;DR version is this game is great value if you want a solid co-op game and don't mind the idea of slaughter hoards of police when you set off the alarm.

Tons of fun with friends, but the community has been nothing but pleasent. People actually own up to mistakes, and then rather than getting yelled at, constructive advice or just a simple 'It's okay we've all been there' is offered.  The game itself is reasonably well designed, and a little less well developed. But neither of those things should stop you from the getting the game, because my reasons behind those statements are generally minor nitpicks. I would elaborate on why I think so, but it would make me sound like I don't actually like the game. In fact, it is the opposite. Payday 2 is easily top 5 in my list of favorite co op games, and absolutely #1 in terms of positive interactions with internet strangers.  In fact, the amount of positive reinforcement in the game is incredibly refreshing, be it from other players, or Bain encouraging you during heists. It seems like such a little thing, but the positive attitude is infectous, and makes failure much less painful, to the point where you don't even care that you and your team failed for the 10th time.  The game's mechanics are fun, and the randomness of each map setup means that playing scenarios over and over stays fun for a long time.   For those with 120+ hz monitors, the game supports them perfectly.   For at least one heist, I found that low graphics settings actually hindered my ability to beat a heist. I was supposed to read a computer screen and note what it said, but at low settings, the screen is just a blur. But other than that one instance, for that particular way of beating that heist, the game's graphics settings are flexible enough for my liking.

Okay, so you've managed to find Payday 2 on a sale page, and you're wondering... 'What is Payday 2?' Well, listen up, 'cause I'm about to tell you.  This game is mainly about robbing ♥♥♥♥, killing cops, thugs, mercenaries, Cloakers (these ♥♥♥♥ers are like Sam Fisher on speed, they will knock you down if you don't pay attention), and Bulldozers (this game's version of Juggernauts). Depending on your skills in FPS games, difficulty level, and build, these enemies will either be really easy to kill or will make your work harder.  There are several heists to play. Depending on your preferred style of play, you may either like the stealth missions more, or the assault missions more.  The Shadow Raid heist, for example, caters to stealth players, as detection results in a potential mission fail should you not secure enough loot. This heist has you sneaking into a warehouse to steal items such as cocaine, gold, artifacts, servers, money, art, and weapons.  The Hoxton Breakout mission, however, is for the heister who's not afraid to get their hands dirty or their boots wet. This mission is pure assault. It involves you blowing a wall into a tunnel to rescue a fellow heister. As a pickup truck escorts him, you escort the truck through the streets of DC, which is covered with cops, FBI, and SWAT. You then attack the FBI headquarters to erase all info of him from their database.  Builds will help you take on the cops as you amass your fortune. You can be a Mastermind, picking up revive skills and medic bags. You can be a Ghost, and pick up ECM and silent skills. You can be a Technician, picking up drill and C4 skills. You can be an Enforcer, picking up survival and damage skills. You can be a Fugitive, and pick up dodging skills. To get the best skills of each respective tree, you must stay mainly in that tree. Although this may seem bad, some skills in one tree work well with skills in other trees.  Did I mention customization yet? I should mention customization. While builds can be considered customization, you can customize each mask (if you can get one from the RNG card drop) and weapon (you're only   kind of   at the mercy of RNG, should you have the Gage Mod Courier DLC) you have.  While we're on the topic of DLC, there is a   lot   of DLC. Luckily, the people of OVERKILL were nice enough to give us a GOTY edition. This edition gives you every. single. DLC. There are soundtracks, weapons, new characters, and new heists. Although a GOTY edition normally means there will be no new DLC, there is more DLC in the works for us.  FInally, the fanbase and community is really amazing. It's not like Call of Duty, where it's mainly little children attempting to persuade you they had sex with your mother. It's a semi-mature community, who mainly want to have fun. Most of the people are really kind, and are willing to help if you are having trouble. You will however, run into a few trolls. From my experience (166.7 hrs at the time of writing this), I have only run into one troll. Others, however, only seem to find pubs full of trolls. To combat this, it's best to find some friends, or cool people from lobbies, to do private lobbies.  All in all, Payday 2 is a really good game, although it would be best to get it during a Steam Sale, as the game is 65% off for the regular edition, and 50% off for the GOTY edition.   Rating: 9/10 overall

Can't mark High Value Targets, like you can a Guard. PickPocketing should be a skill set in Ghost, or some form of like Security Card duplicator or hacking to open the security door with out a drill.  Dont get me wrong, for all the small things I am saying, there is a TON of good things. Update! I've included my original review below to show contrast, and how much the game has changed many people's opinions including my own.  Updated review:  Long story short, this game is ruined. Overkill and Starbreeze finally caved in and added what basically amounts to microtransactions. There is now a total of 36 DLCs(at the time of this review) that players have to pay for to unlock them. On top of that they've added this 'drill and safe' system, which has players pay real money for drills to unlock in game safes; heavily resembling the 'key and crate' system in Team Fortress 2., only now instead of hats and paint, you get masks and skins.  This game was fun for a while, I've spent many hours on it and put a lot of money into it as well, but as much as it pains me to see it go in this direction, I had to uninstall it. I would still recommend it for the vanilla experience, but with all these stat boosts and special weapons, it makes online play unfair. So unless you have a group of friends that are on the same page, don't bother.  It was fun while it lasted...  Original review:  PAYDAY 2 takes the formula from the first game and improves upon it immensely. While the first game is still fun on it's own, PAYDAY 2 has so much more to offer. You are able to customize guns, masks, and skills to your liking, with tons of varying options. Chose from a wide selection of heists, with more still on the way. They are constantly updating the game with new content, leaving more open options for different styles of play. The only thing I would recommend is to find a tight crew early, because sometimes you just find random strangers that either don't know what they're doing, or they simply like to grief other players. It's tons of fun and extremely satisfying. Buy it, play it, love it.

Barbie for Boys  this game comes with a great idea: bankrobbery. Become a team of four, make a plan, distribute the tasks, stealth into the lions den and start drowning in money and gold. What if anything goes wrong? If you get caught by a guard or seen by a pesant? Grab your guns and the game makes sure you have plenty of them. Defend inside the building. Pass the bags with loot on and make your way blazing to the escape van.  The difficulty of the game is very easy. Even though the maps are always a bit randomized, it soon gets boring picking out guards and binding hostages after some initial learning (hint: get a suppressor and stealth). The hardest thing are newbie co-players. But its still fun to play because you always win, in the long term. Just restart the heist over and over again and then somehow you get your loot. Lots of loot, tons of money. And the game offers lots of customisations: a hundred guns that all can be modified and upgraded, 5 skill trees, different speakers and customizable masks and appereance. Like a Barbie doll. So you can spend a lot of time turning the game into a reflection of your flavor and preferences. If you are looking for recreational fun, this game can be entertaining. If you seek out challenges, maybe the achievments are still tempting. I hope there will be a PAYDAY 3 with higher difficulty since the idea of a bank heist offers so much possibilites and the gameplay is already good. EDIT: This game is garbage now ;)  After 300+ hours of game play, I think I can finally write an accurate review of this game.  PayDay 2 is honestly best with a full group of friends. It's one of my favorite co-op games of all time. If you want to play Deathwish, it takes a strategy to get all of your skill trees to compliment each other for the best set up that can get you through any fire fight. If you just want to screw around and shoot up some banks or a mall, you can set it to Normal and just have a ball.  If you want a different kind of strategy you can stealth most of the missions. You can get in and out without anyone realizing. It is one of the most satisfying things ever when you finally complete a stealth mission that you've been planning (Or learning from trial and error) for hours.  Payday also has awesome mask and gun customization. By just using a few simple materials and patterns, you can make any mask your own. And even though you can't 'technically' customize your weapons, there are so many attachments and options to choose from that you can sculpt a gun that suits all of your wants and needs.  People always complain and crack jokes about it being a 'Bag throwing simulator' but there's much more to it. You have to fight through waves of cops or wait for the perfect moment to get all of your acquired loot to the van. Yes it can take a while if you get a lot of loot, but there's almost something satisfying about it when you realize that it's taking so long because you got all the loot that you could, and it's definantly going to end up as an epic payday.  Another subject I want to touch on is people complaining about the amount of DLC. Honestly, they could have released this game for $60 and I know that most people would still buy it. It's an awesome game even without the DLC. In my opinion, DLC is just there for people who want extra content and are willing to pay for it. It's not like you're at an extreme disadvantage if you don't buy it. I mean honestly the people who are buying it are one your side so there's not much room to complain. It's not like they are able to use said guns against you. So in short, if you want to pay for some extra content, go for it. If not, that's fine too.  I think i've made my point so i'm just going to end with this: I personally think that this is an amazing game. I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys shooting things and getting money for it.

PIcked this up because of the demo...and a sale. ;)  I enjoy this game. It's not a giantic hoopla of aggression like a UT title, nor is it an extravaganza of whackniess that can be found on Pandora in BL. But it does occupy some space in the good-gaming column. The missions are aplenty, so are the firearms, and so are the masks. Everything'll cost you a bundle but that's so you don't buy everything after one mission. That's odd but it keeps you playing; makes it worth the efforts.  There are a few more odd aspects that get me or prevent me from really sailing through the game. Having been spoiled by other FPS games that allow one to reload while sprinting I'm constantly struggling to find a good location for just that. I often begin reloading before I run to the next best spot. It's how I've played for ages; reload on the go. But as soon as you sprint reloading stops. This leaves me with only fisticuffs. If the cops are where I had intended on going, that's when I get boomshakacaca-ed. Reloads also take awhile too...or seem too.  Forever maps/missions also seem oddly...perpetual. A constant flow of cops & they never seem to run out of them (they must hire from neighboring counties) nor do they call in any 'RV's to spoil your efforts cooking endless batches of meth, etc. Probably just me though thinking about the realistic angle just as I did with the spontaneous genesis of hordes in LFD2. I guess I wanna see a chopper come in to end your campaign of illicity. It'd be like a mini-boss. Also be good to see the getaway car in the basement or really close by so you don't have to walk through hordes of dumb cops who can't figure out how to take your car out, or deprive you of it. Imagine the getaway, blowing out a garage door or screeching through dozers on the way to freedom.  Oh & you can't close any doors in the entire game. No one door. Not. A. Single. Door...can be shut in this game. I'm pretty sure another key ingredient would need to be coded to get this to work, (for those of us who enjoy shutting doors it would be appreciated), but think of the extra shtuff your classes could do: open doors faster, seal doors faster, carry blowtorch, carry extra blowtorch fuel, (There is no such thing as too much 'Aliens.') use hands to cleverly apply enough force to said door in the opposite direction in which it opened in order to facilitate it's shutting, all kinds of nifty stuff.  Hell, make it a new class: Door-shutter. I WOULD BE THAT GUY. I'd be the gd butler of the team, keeping the doors shut, the drafts out. He could carry kleenex, upgradable to hankerchiefs. By the end of his tech trees he's using Jedi powers to open and close 'em from a distance. He could induse fear in citizens makin' 'em think the place is haunted (See where this is going? All because doors don't shut.)  Ok...you can shut a car door. I never saw any friends driving around in a car with the door wide open, but had I seen that, I wouldn't have been surprised. But seriously, the notion of closing a door to prevent a member of secret caste of ninja security from sneaking up on your ♥♥♥, lord knows they don't make noise when they walk, (Samurai had it down. Make your buildings with rusty nails so they squeek. sheesh.), would be commonly sensical. Right?   It's simple - break in through door, cracking an alarm, whatever, enter, turn around, shut door. I don't care if the A.I. is too dumb to care, it makes sense. As much sense as the I-like-turtles kid. You hear him, he likes turltes, you know it. It makes sense. He likes turtles, simple. Doors open and shut, simple. You can agree with both. You like turtles right? Of course you do. You like doors right? You like it when they close after they open right? Sure as hell do.

Edit: With all of these recent changes, namely the elimination of the safes, I am more than happy to change my review back to positive for this game. I have always loved it, and am now happy to say that my faith has been restored. And, let's be honest, RON PEARLMAN! Even if it is a cheap gimmick to get me hyped, it worked. I admit it. I am an easy target. A good buddy of mine put it best: his voice could make me play a sausage in a game. Boy, is he right.     I have not put in as many hours as many of the other players here, but I still considered Payday 2 to be one of my favorite games. I would routinely look forward to playing it with my friends after work or on the weekends. The gameplay was exciting, the teamwork was awesome, and it never got boring.   Like everyone else, I was excited about this year's crimefest. I was looking forward to seeing what new content we would get. I wasn't expecting anything mindblowing; I recognize that the game has been out for a while now, and that the developers cannot be expected to keep putting out content for which they are not generating cash. However, what we have received thus far can only be considered a scam. We were promised free content. We all put in many hours grinding during the road to crimefest to ensure that we would earn our content. We as a community promoted Payday and the developers, helping them to continue to gain popularity in a game that is more than two years old! And what did we receive in return? Certainly not what I was expecting. Certainly not what any of us were expecting. Microtransactions?! I cannot believe that they are taking a PvE game and making it a P2W.   The community who has supported this game for a long time now has been completely betrayed, and Overkill has yet to say anything to us, the fans, about why they are doing this. Damion Poiter, aka Chains, has been the only one that I have seen thus far to say anything, and he is not even a dev!   My disappointment runs deep, and I cannot bring myself to play again until we get an apology from Overkill. I want to throw my money at you! I had been waiting for the DLCs that I do not have to go on sale! And now, I cannot make myself purchase them. I refuse to support an organization who does not support us. I want to change this review to positive. I want to play this game. I hate this crap. I hate not wanting to play my one of my favorite games.

If you are looking for a non-meme filled, honest, and sort of short review, you are in the right place.   This game really is worth the money, especially on sale, the game definitely improved after update 100 with new skill trees. Personally, I dont really understand why DLC is so important, im sure you have read plenty of other reviews and opinions stating 'DLC DOESNT MATTER' but really, its pretty important. You can survive with the vanilla guns perfectly fine in every difficulty, but having DLC weapons really makes a more fun experience and more opportunities for different skill sets and weapon builds to change the experience. Most of the DLC heists are also fun. This game is not one of those games where you get bored quickly, but its possible if you dont change up your play style from time to time. Personally, I enjoy Stealth the most, but I dont mind shooting a bunch of cops with my body armor on either. You can play stealth alone perfectly fine, but playing with friends is always more fun. Stealth can be pretty 'cancer' as some might want to call it because of desync, which is a massive problem in this game. If the host's internet sucks, you will lag a lot. Sometimes you wont notice it on loud heists, but stealth heists makes it truely cancer. Countless amount of times I have been spotted because of desync. Anyways, Mods are another thing that overkill doesn't have a problem with, and I really appreciate that decision. HUD mods are for sure the most popular, and they really are not that hard to install, if you have installed mods on any other game you should be fine. In my opinion, this game is a must have on PC, and there is literally no reason to not have this game on your PC, its not that hard to run either. If you really really hate it, I guess you can just refund or it or not buy it all. I have bought this game for multiple friends and they have all enjoyed it just as much as I have.

It's been a year since the last year debacle about black market update, where I've given the negarive review. I decided to give them time to see if they are going to listen to the community and change things.  As of this moment, Payday 2 has changed considerably since it's release, from more balanced game between stealth and loud heists, now it is heavily biased towards loud heist.   Good things: - variety of maps, choices, weapons, weapon attachments, skills, perk decks, mutators, and masks - since it's variety it's able to attract many types of gamers - certain heists are very well done and very atmospheric, accompanied by great soundtrack  Bad things: - poorly executed multiplayer, which when it works it's great, but it needs some long overdue changes - inability to fully enjoy the game without DLC's , and trust me, you need quite a few of them - bugs, that are being worked on, but still cripple the game to this day  So what is the conclusion? Even though most of the bad points haven't changed since my previous negative review, the game keeps changing, and in the previous year, improving. Improvements started since the completion of the contract with Starbreeze, the things started to improve, no new DLC releases, and significant changes to Black market, and a lot of free content.  Because of all this, I'm happy to give this game a cautious positive review.  This decision is mostly due to behavior of Overkill and them having the courage to admit that Black market update was a mistake, and apologize, and also listen to the community and change the things for the better of the players.

With regret,  I've played this title for over 1400 hrs. Most of them having a blast with solid, hard hitting, objective oriented, FPS action. But I stopped playing in March 2015 because I had a real problem with the Hype Train event and what it represented as to the mindset of the developer.   Essentially it was an event where you obtained 'fuel' to reach milestones and unlock free content. You obtained fuel by purchasing DLC. Yes, you bought DLC to earn 'free' content. The largest insult was the Completely Overkill DLC Pack released alongside this event. It was a pack of four masks and a 'unknown prize' that was $20 and available for only a limited time. That pack was worth the most fuel. So people were buying the mystery box, at the cost of almost an entire other game for the vague promise of a prize. As of this moment it is seven months later and that 'unknown prize' has still not been released. I could not support this connivance and so I thanked the developer for all my many fun hours and walked away from the game.  I never uninstalled the game though, I just didn't play anymore. I kept an eye on the forums, read the news and shook my head at the increasely bizarre and theme-jarring DLCs. Modern bank-robbers with medieval weapon DLC packs, ninja weapon DLC packs, WW2 weapon DLC packs, Old West weapon DLC packs. Love them or hate them, theme-jarring they remain.  Here and there though, there were nice gestures the developer made to the player base that I found refreshing. Then the Road to Crimefest event came along in October 2015 and I saw that all the challenges were in-game challenges. I thought, 'Hey that's nice of them and I've been dying to play a solid shooter lately. Why not return to Payday 2?' All these challenges unlocked free content in the upcoming Crimefest anniversary event.  So, I came out of 'retirement' and put in another 85 hours helping the community reach its goals and having some good fun. I had so much fun I was even considering buying all the DLC the next time a sale came around. One free item is released on each day of Crimefest so on Day 1, I see the first piece of what I worked for. What I ended 6 months of not playing for. I am once again disgusted at the mindset of the developer and I look at the 75% off sale and know I will not spend a dime.  A developer that had previously gone on record, not once, not twice but three times that they would never add micro-transactions to the game went and did just that. And they did a lot all at once. The rebalanced the weapons that day, damaging the viability of our most trusted tools and increasing the viability of the garbage no one uses anyway. Get it? They made the good stuff worse in order to make the bad stuff look better. Yup, balance.   At the same time they release new weapon skins. Weapon skins that strangely enough actually add stats to the weapons. So now you can get back the functionality of your pre-'balance' firearms with a skin. But how to obtain a skin? Why, when you play now some of your drops at the end of each heist can be a random safe (which makes it even harder to get weapon mods now). How do you open that safe? Oh, easy, buy a 'drill' off the steam market for 2.49. That simple!  I may still not uninstall and play again someday because I just really enjoy killing cops. But I repeat: I will never give this company another dime.  I can't even propose a way to make this right. The fact that the developer thought that this was a good idea at all, after all their other backlash inducing poor ideas tells me that this developer is beyond salvaging. I want no part in suggesting anything because it has becoming increasingly obvious this developer only listens to bad suggestions.  And I am further disgusted that this is around the fourth time that a contraversial decision was made by the developer that just happens to coincide with a large sale/free weekend. That tells me that the developer is more than aware of the contraversial nature of their decisions and so every misstep that disgusts the veteran player base is accompanied by an influx of new players who don't know any better.  I am appalled.  In a way I almost recommend the game still because the game itself is... well it's good.   I cannot support this developer any more though. Over the course of the game's life they have broken promises. They have made sweeping post-release changes numerous times that changed entire portions of the game's functionality - if the game said 'beta' on it that is something else entirely. They have divided their player base, have no PR, put little 'jokes' in the game like safe's that tell you to suck it and an enemy that tells you to go cry on the forums. The developer is unprofessional and have now shown themselves to be greedy on top of that.  Ramble ramble rabble rabble yadda yadda yadda ya

Payday 2 is way much better than the first one! If you never played Payday before, get Payday 2 instead of the first one. Leveling up on the first one was a bit confusing to me, but the heists were still fun to play through and to get a feel for the game. I love playing this game, that is if you don't mind killing cops and security guards to get rich. Rob banks, cook Meth, destroy Malls, run errands for the mob, etc. and listen to Bain. He will keep ya out of trouble. God forbid don't kill any innocents! There are tons of weapons that can be modded out and lots of customization for the character that you choose to play. You can get lots of different masks to wear, and can re-craft them how you want if you got the right materials.   Playing offline is ok, but the A.I. of your teammates suck. If you play online it is better and you will get rich fast if you play with people that know what they are doing. I have so many hours into this game than what it says because I played offline a lot. If you play on a harder level, prepare for a good challenge. Having a good team with different skillsets help. There is downloadable content that you can get for this game like extra weapons and extra heists. Did I mention this is a first-person shooter? If you are used to playing Counter-Strike with keyboard and mouse setup, you will be at home with the controls.  There has been a lot of dlc content for this game that has come out. You don't have to have the dlc to a heist to play with a person that is hosting that heist on multiplayer. You don't really need all the dlc content to have fun. But I do suggest getting some of the starter Gage mod packs, and mod courier pack if anything. After a while, the dlc content just adds extra fun heists to do, more guns and weapons that really don't give you an advantage most of the time, and different masks and patterns to collect. There are a few character packs to add flavor and many many achievements to do ( i love these). Right now it's neverending with more dlc to come! This is a very popular game, if you played it, you would see why.   Now go out and make some cash and get rich beyond your wildest dreams!

UPDATE: Overkill was bought by Starbreeze, who co-developed the original PayDay 2. 505 Games was the publisher. Starbreeze bought Overkill, making Overkill a subsidiary of Starbreeze. At update 100, PD2 had microtransaction drills added, used to open safes, similar to CS:GO's cases. Ulf Andersson, co-founder of Overkill and Wolf's likeness and voice, left Overkill a while after to start his own company. Starbreeze bought back the PD2 IP from 505 Games, owning complete control and splitting sales figures.  MOST RECENT UPDATE COMMENT: IMO, Overkill has fixed the microtransaction debacle quite well. Safes no longer need drills, you can still sell your stuff on the market, and there are stat boosts that drop as normal weapon mods.  Recent changes to skill tries make a lot more sense and allow for some really powerful builds. It also means that you can more easily specialize into things like Masterforcer, because you can just spec into the tree that gives your the ICTV and the tree that gives you inspire.  I think the recent buyback of the Payday 2 IP from 505 Games has been great for Overkill/Starbreeze.    ORIGINAL REVIEW: First off, I'm going to admit I'm biased. I loved the first game in the series, Payday: The Heist. It wasn't the most amazing game, but it was fun, challenging, and engaging enough to hold your attention for a while. Payday 2 ups the ante in every respect.  A 4-player co-op game, Payday 2 pits your crew in a large array of different missions. Missions are much more varied than in Payday 1, allowing you to do entire missions in stealth or go in guns blazing. Once you begin completing missions, such as robbing a stripmall, stealing paintings from a gallery to help blackmail a politician, stealing a fusion generator prototype for oil barons, and other various activities (including lots of drug smuggling and meth cooking), you will begin to gain XP to level up your character and gain items to begin customizing how you want to play and look.  Character customization includes a dizzying array of weapon mods for tons of guns, the all-important mask customization, 5 different skilltrees, and 5 Perk Decks that can be equipped to augment your build. Many of the skills augment specialties from other skilltrees and you will be able to reach top-tier skills in two trees, with several skill points left over, by the time you reach Level 100. After that, you can Infamy (similar to Prestige in CoD) to gain some perks and some masks, and then start looting all over again.  The various ways you can approach levels ensures that playthroughs will be about as varied as the masks of the heisters you play them with. Even the best-laid plans can go wrong with a guard coming at the wrong time or a camera that you forgot to take out. While there are set places for things, things are never in the same place every time. Camera positions, vault locations, loot locations, etc. are all randomized, and even some level designs are randomized. Missions rarely ever play out exactly the same.  Thinking back on how different this game is today than it was at launch is interesting. The game has expanded greatly and added a bunch of new features. Just as much free stuff has been added as has DLC, and the DLC missions only restrict you from creating a lobby for that mission, not joining one. So, even if you don't own the Armored Transport DLC, you can still join those missions when someone else hosts them. It's a great idea that doesn't split the community.  Also of note: On top of all of the looting and shooting is an excellent soundtrack from Simon Viklund, infamous for his work on Bionic Commando: Rearmed. Payday 2's soundtrack is great, especially if you're a fan of Viklund's work, and there's a wide variety of tunes to appreciate.  That aside, there are downsides. The game isn't exactly a graphical powerhouse, although it certainly doesn't look bad either. Just don't expect to be blow away. There are glitches and bugs. And the biggest letdown has to be the CrimeNET interface that you select your missions and lobbies from. CrimeNET is an interesting idea that simply does not quite work like it should. It winds up being more of a hassle than it should and due to some networking issues, you sometimes have dead lobbies stick around long after they've closed. Overkill has said they're looking into solutions, but there is no current word of what or when. It's basically been the only real hangup for what is an otherwise stellar title.

Be the bad guy in this 4-player co-op FPS crime simulation. Has some RPG elements in terms of leveling up your character's abilities, and customizing your weapons. But leveling up doesn't directly affect health or difficulty of your enemies, so a Level 100 player can play with a Level 1 player with no real penalty.  You play with up to a 4-person crew. To get the most out of the game, I highly recommend playing it co-op with friends. The experience is vastly different in co-op vs solo. While all of the missions are possible in solo, any mission where you have to transport a large number of loot bags is rendered tedious because the AI players will not carry loot for you.  Heists include bank robbery, art theft, jewelery store raids, weapon and drug hauls, and more. Almost all of the heists can be completed in stealth without police presence, or you can go in with guns blazing.  This game is head and shoulders above the original Payday: The Heist. It improves everything that was good, and fixes everything that was bad. Development is ongoing, with free updates adding new content and gameplay, and DLC offering new weapons and missions.  For the achievement junkies, this game has a ton of them. Very few are 'gimmies' (ie, 'you did what you were supposed to do, here's an achievement'), such as reaching Level 5/10/25/50/75/100. A lot of them are insanely difficult, such as killing the most heavily armored unit in the game with a knife, or completing each mission on the hardest difficulty level. In between you'll find some for completing certain missions a specific way, or racking up kills with a specific combination of mask and gun. There's something for everyone. If you're an achievement completionist, you're in for an ♥♥♥-whooping.

After the recent updates that kind of broke the game for me, especially the ones that really tore into stealthing a lot of the missions, I ended up quitting the game.  Now, I wasn't one of those people who abused the infinite body bags before these updates, like completely stealthing a bank heist on overkill by killing everyone in the map, but I did use it to my advantage in maps like Nightclub where all I needed to do was kill everyone in the back and go about my business.  After we were given limited body bags and overkill non-stealthing was made even more difficult thanks to Spooks, I ended up leaving the game for some time.  I had given the game a lot of thought after though, as it has been one of my favorite shooters to date. So, I finally picked it back up.  Now, I still fear getting to the higher levels in this game because the EXP scale is ridiculous later on, but I'm finding the little add-ons they put in, like stealth bonuses, certain jobs giving bonus exp and the option to find courier packs for small EXP bonuses, to be quite rewarding early on. What I don't like is the penalties put on maps that you've done before, I know they don't want this game to be all about grinding, but what if I want to play certain maps over and over because I'm really good at them? Should I be penalized for that? Personally I don't think so and I find it lessens the amount of time I put into the game. Sure my list of maps I can do is pretty long, but it still sucks to go through them all in one play through and then have to wait a few hours before I can get the full amount of EXP from them. I'd rather grind in a game, any game, than have to limit my time playing the game.  Other than that, the game is still fun for me even after the updates that previously killed it for me. The maps have little changes I noticed that I'm interested in seeing what they do, the NPCs are less bull**** when in certain situations, the gameplay is still entertaining that keeps me coming back. Payday 2 has certainly not lost its touch with the new updates, sure there's the EXP thing I mentioned, but other than that nothing really comes across as wrong to me about this game.   I still recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a good strategic shooter or just loves FPS games all-around. If you like the combination of RPG elements with your shooters, this game is right up your alley. Oh, you like customization too? Customize your masks and your guns. Tons of customization with just two items to do it on, they can be a little pricey, but hey, it's fun.

Payday 2 has its problems.   - Terrible AI making solo play an irritating way to go about playing unless you're playing all stealth.  - The repetitive feeling when playing some heists because of objectives being so similar to one another.   - Weapon\Mask\Attachments being extremely expensive compared to what you earn in-game,   - and finally lack of much weapon balance (Some weapons are great and everyone uses them while some aren't too much good in their own ways making them less popular).   That's pretty much the big problems with the game. Here's the thing, while you may think that playing only Co-Op and that there will not be much replay value in the game along with the other 3 problems always in effect, that that would cause you to not play this game, you would be wrong.  This game is awesome, graphics are majorly better than the predecessor and the gun play feels perfect for a shooter, better than any other AAA FPS out there especially when you hipfire at a law enforcers head, it may be better than Farcry 3's gun play system even without any lean or peeking system.  The sound for this game is amazing especially on home theatre systems and expensive headphones, but it is just as good with speakers/laptop speakers.   Customization is a lot better than even Battlefield 3 or 4 with the amount of options available, and some attachments, even with negative effects on your gun make it look absolutely awesome and worth the downsides.   A lot of heists come with the main game, while not as much as many people including me thought we would get from what the developers were saying (Misunderstandings by both parties and mistakes by the devs with what they were planning), it has smart, and very enjoyable freedom abouts in the heists included. Also, like the predecessor, the game does not split the players away from one another when it comes to DLC. If the host comes with the DLC maps then people who join who do not have them can play them, the same applies to the Grenades that were released with a weapon pack DLC.   Enemies are smart and ruthless, they come in different types and all have their own type of abilities, for example, the Bulldozer is pretty much like a man covered in super bomb proof armour making him very strong and the Tazer which I bet you can make from the title.   Smart skill customization makes everyone unique in their own ways, whether it be a fast but powerful soldier to a stealthy c4 wielding heavy damage dealer. Annual events are held for Christmas, Halloween and the like, that add content and achievements. And lastly, this game has major improvements planned all the time, whether it be DLC or patches.  If none of that convinces you, keep this in mind. In either 2 weeks - 1 month after the game launched, there were 10 bugfixing, content providing patches released (while it made it feel like a beta, it did a lot more than any beta I've played with constant updates in terms of content and fixes) and with more free content coming in the future.  Buy this game, even if it for some random reason goes up to $60 USD. This game is worth a hell load more than lots of AAA game that's at that kind of price, so buying it for half of that and getting a hell load more fun out of it is definitely worth it!

Payday 2 is easily the most fun online game I've played in years.Each match begins with you carefully selecting which heist or job you want to attempt, then meeting up with a crew of other crooks while you discuss strategies, loadouts and duties. Make it work and you feel the rush of collecting the rewards and getting your payday. Fail and watch as your crew turns on one another and when things get hot, may even leave each other to save themselves.   But before you think the missions are formulaic, the devs took a L4D approach by randomizing elements of gamplay, such as locations (or existence) of mission items, number and frequency of guards, cameras and civilians.  Unlike many other games where stealth is OP, the stealth in this game is so difficult that when you actually pull it off it feels amazing. Most often, however, You end up slealthing 'until you blow it' at which point hopefully you've completed enough objectives that your team can hold off the SWAT forces long enough to finish the job and GTFO.  Jobs are not repetitive, either. Everything from robbing stores, organizing bank jobs, rigging elections, shooting up shopping malls, pulling train heists, hitting art galleries, looting warehouses and even cooking in meth labs and tons more. This is NOT a typical co op shooter experience.
