Do NOT ignore all the negative reviews that only talk about technical issues. If a game does not work, then you cannot play, and a game that works is always better than one which does not work. Would you rather a pacman arcade or Crysis running at 5 FPS? And this game essentially requires multiplayer, with all its connection issues. The AI assisting you are dumb, the AI for the enemies are dumb, about the only seemingly not dumb AI are the ones who are supposed to press the panic buttons. But back to technicals. I have a generation one i7 with a GTX 580 and I can't run this on full HD. Maybe I have old drivers or I heated them too much you say, okay perhaps that explains the low FPS, but it certainly isn't causing the mouse lag. Look it up. It's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ problem I've never seen happen in any other game. If I lower resolution to 1600 900 its workable but anything higher and the mouse is not crisp. Thankfully the AI are dumb so it's like playing a zombie game when you're shooting but this carries over to the menus. Like, really? There's a host of other technical problems too, including the game crashing when you attempt to accept a friend invite to a game. Which you basically have to because the lobby system in this game is garbage.  And it has to be, because otherwise it'd be all too clear that this game has 0 content. Starting a mission requires you to look at what appears to be a map of a city, and then there are random dots that show up here and there. You aren't allowed to just pick a certain mission or a certain difficulty, you have to wait for it to pop up. It's not even in predictable locations; you'll find the exact same mission spawn on two entirely different points on the map. The maps have slightly different spawns totally to maybe five variations tops on each mission, but overall its the same stuff. This randomness is also in equipment: you can buy your base guns, but every single mod and every single mask component has to be obtained through random draw at the end of missions through this pick a card thing. Oh, and you still have to pay for them.  And every single mission briefing or ending there are people talking about the 'story' in the background.  And that's the game. What did I pay 30 bucks for again? This is an 'Action RPG'? Where's the action and where's the RPG? Maybe RPG stands for Random Player Game, because even the player's own equipment can only be obtained through lottery.  If you always have 3 friends playing with you then perhaps going full stealth every time inserts a little strategy and coordination into it, but just playing by yourself or with pubbies will always just turn it into Zombies: Stealing Cash With Clown Masks Edition.

Payday 2 is a brilliant sequel to the first game, Payday: The Heist. The game itself has a bunch of new maps and contracts. The stealth techniques have been completely revamped and the game has turned into a top selling game. The skills, inventory and masks options are a great feature new to the game which really makes customization a huge possibility. Should be called Stealing Things Simulator 2018, really really-stic, wonderful graphics, great grameplay.  THERE IS A TL;DR PART IF YA SCROLL DOWN, K? K.  The menu/start-a-game thing is really stupid, you have to sit and wait for the contract you want to play. If you don't want to sit and wait for the right contract, you can buy that contract using your off-shore shekels. That part pisses me off since you sometimes have to sit and wait for like 5 mins.  Another bad thing is the invisible walls, you feel like you could go anywhere you want to but then poof, you get stopped by an invisible wall.   There's one more thing that I might be alone in thinking, and that is the Perk system. So there are these perks right? And these perks play a HUGE role in this game, and the way you get these perks are by leveling up, nothing new there right? But if you're at a low level, you can't get all the things. For example there's a Saw perk, which lets you unlock the saw tool. This saw is needed if you don't want missions like the Bank Heist: Deposit to get reaaaally boring. For you who haven't played the game, in this mission you have to enter the bank vault and unlock these deposit boxes, not so hard right? WELL, without the saw you have to pick the locks by hand which takes like 20-30 seconds each, and there's five boxes per letter in the alphabet minus Y and Z, which makes a total of 120 boxes (i might be wrong on this, but search for the bank heist 'bank heist deposit' so that you get a clue on what i'm talking about). I did the whole mission stealthy-stealthy, and it took us 10 minutes to get all the boxes open. Imagine 10 minutes of just sitting there and looking into the wall. Really fun. (I do realize that the boxes are surposed to be a bit of a gamble but still, if you want to ace it, it takes far too long)  Otherwise it's a great game, missions are pretty much always different in some way, the cameras, the coke, the guards, the everything, switch places everytime you play the mission so you can't just speed run the whole thing and know the exact location of stuffings, you have to search the place for the dank bank monys. The game is really strategical, which makes it so different from other games in my opinion. You can actually stealth a bank, meaning that you can enter a bank silently and get out without having to deal with the coppers. This keeps you playing as you want to complete a heist as smoothly as possible.   I missed a lot of positives, but there are a lot of positives, and they outweigh the negatives by far.  TL;DR awesome game, has a few flaws but the positives outweigh the negatives. If you ever thought to yourself 'I wonder how it would feel like robbing a bank', then buy this game.  8/10

Graphically, not stunning. It's simply a step above Counter Strike and about as appealing as the lunch that you have today, but was packed yesterday. However, in the gameplay department, it really pushes Co-Op gameplay to what we all want it to be.   Now don't get me wrong, I'm actually more of a lone wolf when it comes to gaming. I don't communicate well, and I'm often off doing my own thing while everyone else is getting stomped. That being said, I didn't think that this was going to be such a fun game without the Co-Op. But when you really start playing it, you quickly find that you can solo missions with the right planning (and alot of patience) and you'll often approach each scenario differently than Co-Op. But when it gets down to it, I really believe that this game is strongest in the smash and grab approach of the heists. Battling waves of cops is surprisingly fun, and the feeling you get when you complete a heist on overkill or deathwish with some friends is really something else. Therefore, I highly recommend this game to all gaming personalities, and encourage you to get the associated DLC. The Big Bank is a beast that any real gamer needs to slay.

Graphics 7/10 The graphics i would put it about average with most online FPS games aside from the major $60 titles. Its not hard to look it but still noticibe that some things are poorly done. Aside from that, its still well made.  Gameplay 8/10 There's more than 1 way to complete a heist. You can go guns blazing, fighting off cops, drilling into safes, blowing up vaults, sawing through doors, etc. Or you can go quietly, capturing hostages, shooting out cameras, finding keycards etc. And every mission isn't exactly the same. The level is always changing from Security rooms or vaults being put in different locations, to the way the guards patrol, to camera locations.  Customization 8/10 There are so many things you can do with your guns. You can turn an assult rifle into a long range sniper with different attatchments. You can change guns to be more concealed and add silencers to help with stealth missions.  Overall 8/10 Playing this game has made me want to watch all the good heist movies like Oceans 11-13, Now You See Me, The Italian Job, etc. Its so well done that you keep coming back for more. It tickles your greed just enough for you to go back in and collect that last bag of cash. Very well done.

Personally, I love Payday 2. I think it's a great game which puts you into the shoes of experienced bankrobbers and allows you to completely ♥♥♥♥ up their reputation by getting wrecked by security guards on normal difficulty. However, there are a couple of glitches and difficulty spikes which can be extremely frustrating to deal with if you're not experienced at the game, or if you don't have a group of friends to work together with. Numerous times I've had security guards spawn inside me while stealthing a bank heist, ruining it. Many times units seem to go through the walls, but that may just be because of slight lag. Don't get me wrong, I thoroughly enjoy the game but it's rather glitchy and quite unbalanced in some aspects which may put off the more casual breed of players. To sum it up: Pros: -Great fun with friends -Many weapons to choose from -Very interesting and cool mechanics -There is nothing more satisfying that pulling off a stealth heist for the first time -Difficult for the right reasons -You can yell 'Get the ♥♥♥♥ up' and your teammates will magically ignore all injuries and continue to fight -Hillarious voice lines -Many heists which all require different skills to complete -DLC that doesn't cost much, and adds just that little bit more to the game, but you do not need to buy any for the full experience in the first place -Constant updates from Overkill  Cons: -Difficult for the wrong reasons (Yes I know I mentioned the opposite, but you will know what I mean) -RNG drop system for masks and attachments, seriously. It's a ♥♥♥♥ing pisstake. -Massive skill curve for the higher difficulties, difficult to ease into -Rather ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t moments -Enemies have the tendencies to spawn inside you (Or maybe that's just me and I'm just a very popular choice for guard spawns) -And I was going to mention cheaters, but thank ♥♥♥♥ they have been removed from ruining legit people's games.

I don't get the hype. Yes, it's shiny, full of loot and not to mention - you play as a badass. But it's incredibly tedious, with little-to-no typical first person shooter traits such as testing your reflexes, thrilling battles, surprising counter attacks. It's predictable and the intelligence of the AI doesn't surpass that of a toaster. In fact, the AI on Payday 2 hardly comes close to that of the first unreal tournement. On my first game I spent over an hour and a half in an open vault, fending off law enforcement not through a tight passage, but literally in the middle of the bank. About 1/10th of in-game time is spent looking down your iron sights, compared to the 27/10ths of your time fixing the drill.   It's a laugh to play with mates, but as far as dedicated gaming goes - it's poorly developed but well shined. Fit for a comedian who can get enough material for an 8 hour 'What's up with Payday 2' show.   That said, it is a nice game to have tried and owned - but I wouldn't reccomend paying anything over 5$ for it.

Ripe with Hackers, Trolls, and those just generally looking for something fun for fifteen minutes, Pay Day 2 is easily a staple in a FPS fans game list. Backed by an extensive achievements list, there are plenty of maps and experiences worth having in this game, but casual gamers might find some of it repetative after a while. The general expectation is to level to 100, then turn in all your chips and do it again in order to earn a special mask and some bonus stats to make the next ride a bit quicker, but really once a player gets there the first time, the necessity in going 'Infamous' is pretty lackluster if you don't care about the astehtic masks. The game allows a player to have four different skill-sets that being Infamous discounts in the hope of getting all the abilities in one skill-set build (which is really non-plus if you plan ahead).   If you plan on going Infamous, one key note: buy extra weapons with your surplus cash. Don't burn it! Sell back the weapons at a loss in order to get an easy couple of million to repurchase skills again afterwards (you'll level faster, and find yourself needing the money).  Two best skill sets: Technicians and Ghosts. Don't discount the value of a quiet drill or the ability to open a safe by hand!  Cons: 1.) Expansions/DLC are incredibly expensive for their return. For the most part, the DLC's are all just fluff. Very few of the weapons offer anything that you can't achieve with standard options. 2.) Novelty of the game can wear thin after the first trip to 100. 3.) Many of the non-infamous masks are ugly or generally just too far a step away from something I found 'fun' to wear. 4.) Offline mode is pretty much impossible without earning a decent amount of skills to offset the lack of intelligent players in the AI's. To often I watched the AI let someone die just to keep shooting a cop, or just stand around while things go to hell. They also wont pick up a bag to save their lives. 5.) There is an anti-taser skill that does not work. 6.) Cloakers.  Pros: 1.) A lot of maps, and consequently a lot of tactics patterns to learn. Stealth and Loud both have multiple approaches in all the maps. 2.) Most achievements can make the game a bit more fun. 3.) Even though mods award randomly, it's still pretty easy to modify weapons regularly. 3.) Headshots actually matter, being good at them matters even more. 4.) Dozers are fun to kill with silenced SMG's as a ghost with armor piercing while point-blank aimed at the face. You think the uniforms that show up with no body armor go down fast? Ha! 5.) Easy game to on-board, even easier to sleep-walk through for a good dream.  8/10, Would fill a van with 500 pieces of a rare, one of a kind Samurai armor again.

Tons of fun with friends, but the community has been nothing but pleasent. People actually own up to mistakes, and then rather than getting yelled at, constructive advice or just a simple 'It's okay we've all been there' is offered.  The game itself is reasonably well designed, and a little less well developed. But neither of those things should stop you from the getting the game, because my reasons behind those statements are generally minor nitpicks. I would elaborate on why I think so, but it would make me sound like I don't actually like the game. In fact, it is the opposite. Payday 2 is easily top 5 in my list of favorite co op games, and absolutely #1 in terms of positive interactions with internet strangers.  In fact, the amount of positive reinforcement in the game is incredibly refreshing, be it from other players, or Bain encouraging you during heists. It seems like such a little thing, but the positive attitude is infectous, and makes failure much less painful, to the point where you don't even care that you and your team failed for the 10th time.  The game's mechanics are fun, and the randomness of each map setup means that playing scenarios over and over stays fun for a long time.   For those with 120+ hz monitors, the game supports them perfectly.   For at least one heist, I found that low graphics settings actually hindered my ability to beat a heist. I was supposed to read a computer screen and note what it said, but at low settings, the screen is just a blur. But other than that one instance, for that particular way of beating that heist, the game's graphics settings are flexible enough for my liking.

This was a game that really didn't grab me until I actually played it. I definitely recommend playing the demo to get a feel for how the mechanics work outside of the usual fps pew pew pew. It's definitely a great co-op game where each person can pick perks that allow for specific roles in a job. The randomization of each area keeps the game fresh so replaying a job won't always go the same way each time.  EDIT:  I consider this review to be too out of date with what has been added to the game since then. Giving this game a thumbs down review until they remove the b.s. micro-transactions which they promised they wouldn't put in the game. Blatant lies like that should never be tolerated as acceptable behavior.                   Old review: Awesome game when playing with friends, endless fun. Generally not a bad game when playing with complete strangers either. But it's definitely not a great game when trying to play solo which is what this quick review will be based on.  Trying to complete a heist in stealth while playing solo is a complete nightmare for most of the heists since the AI doesn't do anything at all to help out. They just pick a spot to perch and stay there the entire time and you cannot issue orders to them or anything like that. And a lot of the heists require you to be in multiple areas at the same time in order to successfully get things done. For example, in Shadow Raid heist, it is literally impossible to get the armor set out of the vault without an additional friend playing with you since it requires 2 keycards (and you can only have 1 at a time) and they need to be inserted at either end of the vault door simultaneously. Although getting it done with complete strangers is also pretty much impossible too since there's no screening process for complete noobs and cheating noobs from joining your game and failing the heist each and every single time and still not learning a damn thing from their mistakes. And then of course, there's the fact that you're limited to 4 zip ties for w/e dumb reason and there's always a lot of ppl to tie up in order to incapacitate them... so you end up having to resort to killing the rest which deducts profit from you. And if that wasn't bad enough... by default, you're only allowed 1 body bag, and with skills 2 body bags with the addition of having a place-able body bag kit which contains I think 3 more?... instead of having ECMs.  Doing the mission loudly, well... that's also an issue since the AI helpers are just basic meat shields as they don't come with any decent gear and barely do any damage at all to the authorities. They do pick you back up 'sometimes' when you fall down... if you're very lucky, but that's literally the extent of their purpose. And if you play on Overkill or Deathwish or any heist that has a mounted turret van shooting at us... the AI meatshields are so stupid, they just sit there in the open and absorb all the bullets till they fall down and expect you to try to revive them so they can continue to stand there and absorb the bullets again.  Playing the game online allows me to play on Deathwish and Overkill difficulties, and even then they're sometimes a bit too easy (depending who I play with and which heists and which modes). Playing offline however... Normal and maybe Hard difficulty are my only option, and even then, it's a pain in the butt that requires constant restarts.  The only reason I'm giving this game a positive review is because I can enjoy the game a lot while playing with other ppl. But I seriously hope that the devs someday work on getting much better AI into the game. And it's not just the AI helpers that are for the most part, useless... there's an obvious reason as to why they try to drown you with fully armored military cops shooting at you... it's because the AI is that terrible. The AI have no strategy what-so-ever, they just charge at you and accept all the bullets you give them. They don't even understand the concept of intimidation at all. They also spawn in way too quickly after the alarms are set off, etc... stupid things like that.  Basically, the stealth is great in this game as it's acceptably very difficult, and if you like being buried under heavy fire all the time for loud missions, then you'll love this game for sure.

PAYDAY 2 is a game about robbing banks, destroying malls and assassinating guards. Well, it's much more than that too!  The game is very tactical and in-depth. It has plenty of content to keep you interested, plus DLC if you want a little extra to add to gameplay experience. Rather than writing a wall of text, I shall do some pros and cons.  PROS:    Great stealth gameplay, with different tactics you can deploy    Loud gameplay is interesting, taking hostages, getting police to arrest themselves, guarding targets and much more!     Loads of guns and customization of weapons, masks and much more!    A nice progression system, not too fast or slow to level up plus rewards for levelling.    In-Depth skill and perk trees that affect your playstyle.    Interesting and different maps.    To play a DLC map only the host requires the DLC.  CONS:    Lots of DLC can make you want to buy a lot. Game also shows off the DLC every time you enter the inventory.    AI is quite stupid.    Due to the AI's stupidity, the game is only fun with friends.    Menus are not the easiest to navigate.    Constant Updates that take forever to install, generally adding new paid DLC and Microtransactions...    Microtransactions. I will explain this below.     Microtransactions   The system PAYDAY 2 uses is similar to that of Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, but as far as I know the premium weapons have additional stats, making the game somewhat pay to win. If that isn't bad enough, earlier in development the devs promised to never add microtransactions, but they did...     Score

Post Update 100 Review-  In light of the recent Update 100, I can safely say Overkill has thoroughly impressed me. They have finally retracted their microtransactions which not only tore apart the game but the community as well. While I can personally say I am not a fan of the monstrous amount of paid DLC as I believe it promotes a bad business model, I can find a sort of new-found respect for Overkill on doing such a monumental thing that is rarely ever done in the gaming community. They did listen to their fans after all. They abolished the horrendous microtransactions which plague the gaming world and continue to suck money from honest players. This is something which I can admire. I'm still disappointed due to the seemingly bad business model of DLC, and for the fact they allowed such an event take control in the first place. However, due to the removal of microtransactions, I can safely say Payday 2 is a good purchase once more. Happy heisting.   [Original Review] I stopped supporting this game around when they began releasing DLC on a weekly basis. With DLCs at price that totals around $100 with a base game price of $30, and now the 'cherry-on-top' micro-transactions, that they sworn would never make an appearance in-game, I can safely say that you should avoid this game like the plague. I encourage you to read the other highly rated negative reviews in order to get an in-depth analysis on the situation, but with a 100% certainty, avoid this game and any other game created by Overkill. They treat their fans with little respect as can be observed on their almost non-existant response to the negative outlash with the recent Crimefest and its horrid updates it has brought as well as the absolute horde of DLC that have been released. This is not the company they projected themselves to be years ago and, have yet to make any sort of amends for their actions. Avoid this game- in fact any Overkill product or merchandise at all costs.

Original Review: What a fantastic game. At the time of this review I have put 200 hours into it and I have enjoyed every minute of it.  The closest thing to PAYDAY 2 that I can think of is Left 4 Dead. The three major differences is that PAYDAY 2 typically doesn't involve Point A to Point B levels, almost every level can be stealthed, and your enemies are cops instead of zombies. When you are detected or thrown into a loud scenario the game will begin throwing waves of cops at you.  There is some variety among the cops. You have your normal beat cops that deal high damage but are easily killed with 1 or 2 shots. You have your armored SWAT cops that deal moderate damage but take more punishment. Then you have your 4 special cops. The Tazer is a cop... with a tazer. If you get tazed, you will be stunned and you will automatically pull the trigger on your gun. The Shield is a cop with a riot shield. Most weapons cannot penetrate the shield so teamwork or agility is required to take down a Shield. The Cloaker is a ninja cop. You do not want to let any Cloaker get close to you. Cloakers can jump on you and beat you down instantly in melee. The Bulldozer is a cop dressed in bomb disposal type body armor. Bulldozers deal insane amounts of damage and can only be effecively taken out by shooting their visor. Explosives help as well.

This game is all about pulling off epic hiests, including robbing banks, rigging elections, causing general mayhem and much more.  When you first start this game, most hiests often turn into a giant shoot-out. Once you figure the game out a bit more or get people/friends who know whats up, it gets more complex and interesting. The game offers plenty of challange levels to suit any players comfortable difficulty, though the rewards for the higher difficulties are much greater and require greater skill or knowledge of mechanics. It also has a class/perk system and a ton of different weapon options/mods to suit many different playstyles. Until recently, I have been a supporter of this game, and of Overkill. However, over the last, I want to say 3-4 months Overkill have made some incredibly bad business decisions.  I may well be in the severe minority here when I say that I'm not against the microtransactions as a whole, I'm just against them affecting the stats of guns. Honestly, if there wasn't any incentive to pay more money to get better stats on a gun, then there wouldn't be as much community uproar. My simple message to OVK regarding this: Remove the stat boosts on them, and I'll be happy.  DLC is where we get to my main issue with this game. 10 characters, half of which, you have to pay extra money to either Overkill, or the developers of another game, to access. And not only that, but they are ludicrously overpriced for what you're getting with the packs. Yes, I understand that the voice acting for new characters isn't cheap, but if you're going to charge that much for the character packs, at least give us something better than the character, 1 gun and a melee weapon. it's not enough that you're already bleeding the community dry with your other Weapon Packs that you have to do the same with new characters. While I'm still on the subject of characters, why the hell are there 10 available characters, but we can still only have 4-player co-op? If you're going to keep adding characters, please for the love of god, let us have more people in a lobby, otherwise it just seems pointless. Yes, we get more chance of playing as the character we want to, but honestly, I'd rather play with more of my friends at the same time. Additionally, the B-Sides soundtrack hasn't been updated since it was released (although it has been confirmed there is an update in the works) but the Official Soundtrack DLC hasn't been updated since the Hoxton Revenge heist, which was months ago, I understand that updating things may be a little time consuming when you're busy creating weapon skins, but there has to be a point where you realise that you need to start taking care of your players by updating the content they already have. A final word on Payday 2's DLCs. Stop with the constant charges for DLC, 75% of your game, and 100% of the things that make the game worth playing, are locked behind your absurd paywall at this point. And your community have had enough of it. Something needs to change Overkill.  Finally, we get onto actual gameplay. This hasn't changed since I first started playing the game 2 years ago. The mechanics still feel identical, and the only thing that's really changed dramatically is the addition of driveable vehicles. Some of the more recent heists are riddled with bugs and issues, the AI is still as horrible to both fight against and alongside as the day I first played, and the 'Weapon Balance' patch as part of Crimefest 2015 completely destroyed all weapon balance, completely removing any point to using a shotgun, and punishing anyone that didn't have either a Deagle or a Bronco as their secondary. If there's one thing people hate in a game like Payday 2 where there is such a wide array of weaponry to choose from, it's being forced to select certain weapon types. Additionally, there are some incredibly annoying issues with Desync in this game, 90% of the entire game is based on HOST CLIENT DETECTION. Meaning that if you aren't host, then bodies and NPCs aren't where you see them. Thus rendering half of the entire game (anything stealth related) ineffective, as you spend half your time sitting around doing nothing while the host solo stealths the mission, or restarting heists because someone shot a guard that wasn't where they thought he was. The desync in this game is on par with GTA V's online lobbies in some cases.  If I'm completely honest, GTA V is a better game right now, simply because the 5 heists that GTA:O has are more interesting than all of Payday 2's combined, and the DLC for GTA is completely free.  Long story short, I cannot in good faith recommend this game to anyone until Overkill impliment some serious changes and actually start listening to their community. I've given this company enough of my money, but not so much that I'm adverse to cutting my losses and uninstalling.  Overkill, if you happen to read this, myself, and other members of this community you have are willing to give you another chance, but you have to start fixing your mistakes, instead of offering half-hearted apologies for the sake of apologising.

Even if 'Payday 2' is a sequel, it feels very familiar. You still do heists, you still blow stuff up and you still kill bankguards and SWAT teams. It's in the UI and menus that you notice a great difference. They are slicker and more userfriendly. But, at least in my opinion, 'Payday 2' feels a lot like a refinement rather than a sequel. That's not to say it doesn't inovate.   The upgrade in graphical quality is very nice, but even if you play the game on the highest setting possible you will still notice some graphical bugs and sometimes the framrate drops. But it is a fun and thrilling action co-op game that relies heavily on team work. One uses the drill to crack the safe while the others protect him or her from enemy fire and takes out cameras. You can either go in stealthy or guns blazing. In any case, a heist usually ends in a gunfight. That isn't bad, rather the contrary but it might get boring after a while. As it stands, 'Payday 2' is fun and thriling in short bursts, but as your game session closes in on the 2 hour mark, you, or at least I, feel kind of bored and spends more time customizing my character than actually playing heist.  Final rating: 8/10

In lieu of my former most recent immature pissy review, this is my attempt on a more fair review for a game that deserves it. I will discuss the pros of the game that I praise, the cons of some things that should be improved, the grade I would rate Payday 2, and my final overall opinion.  My first pro is the varying style of gameplay with several different missions. A handful of missions can only be stealthed, several can only be played loud, and a few of them can be done either tactic. This definitely is something that I didn't expect in a shooter, I expected guns blazing 100% of the time but there is definitely a learning curve to the alternate tactics of approaching different jobs.  Secondly on the thought of variety; enemies. There are a plethora of enemies that are fought depending on difficulty level, each with their own gimmicks and health values that may force you to change your approach on them, i.e. keeping your distance from cloakers, laying waste on bulldozer visors, flanking shields, etc.. Additionally, the ability to call out and mark special enemies makes it much easier for teams to strategize during the game.  Lastly with pros; skill trees. They killed it here with the most recent update. It feels like I'm playing an RPG shooter and I can spec my character however I want. In the five trees you can mix and match whatever points you want to make your heister as badass as you want. In addition to the skill trees are the perk decks. These I'm a little more mixed on, some are amazing, some are semi-viable/situational, and some are pure garbage in all circumstances. I will give credit though they all CAN have their uses depending on your playstyle and the difficulty.  Now with the cons.. recent updates have potentially caused me some ire but I have been able to play the game without too much keyboard destruction lately.  Firstly, and I know a lot of people have complaints and will say 'eh just keep your distance'...; Cloakers. For sure I understand why overkill added Cloakers to gameplay, it's literally a curveball to your normal playing style (I enjoy high risk/high reward so it may be my own problem) and for a melee oriented/shotgun built character cloakers can be a bit of a hassle for someone who plays like me. Regardless, my big issue is their kick hitbox. It is broken, I have been hit from across the map from a cloaker who was 'chasing me' for about 10-15 seconds then I randomly end up being downed. In spur of the moment it makes me furious but I've gotten to the point where I accept cloakers are broken and I can live with it but I like complaining about it :P  Secondly, stealth mechanics. I originally loved these jobs. They were quite the change of pace from loud jobs. My friends and I would play Framing Frame all day to learn stealth and get the added benefit of a experience stealth bonus. I miss being able to play FF multiplayer like I did several months ago. The addition of the most recent update seriously messed up connection. Desync, while originally prevelant only occasionally, happens quite possibly 80% of the time playing stealth missions, which has recently discouraged me from playing the stealth jobs I used to love playing with my friends.  Thirdly and my biggest issue with the game is the DLC content. I know people will complain about microtransactions, and I'm guilty of it myself while I use some skins in-game, but DLC's are really where the game bothers me. A game like Skyrim has three DLC's that add entirely new content, storylines, characters, quests and even more. Each for a reasonable price for what they offer. For Payday however, some of the perk decks available really give a player the edge or a deficit depending on which one you use, and a ton of them are only available as DLC's. Granted, I will give credit to steam for having sales often throughout the year lowering the price by as much as 75%, but the sheer number of DLC's available start to become a little pricy for someone with modest means of income.  I will give this game a B grade.  While very fun and addicting, Payday 2 has its problems like any game. But with a good group of friends to play with, a generally considerate and friendly community, and a multitude of missions to play either alone or with a group, overall this is a game I would recommend playing.

While this isn't beautiful, original, or unique gameplay, I remember having a lot of fun with this game, and almost excessively playing it with a couple of friends during Thanksgiving break. I thought the amount of heists and their fun, the amount of weapons, armor, masks, characters, and cool skill trees all gave a lot of content, so this game could easily have hundreds of hours, even though I personally don't recommend doing that (I'll explain why in a second). This game has a lot of experimentation, and the actual gunplay itself is pretty interesting while doing all that, and seeing how all this stuff affects the playstyles. As stated before, there are a lot of heists, and each one is really fun and replayable, which is pretty much the big point of this game, to replay all the heists and get better with them, and it does well at that.  Now, the big problem with this game (and why a lot of old fans of the series don't recommend it) is that Overkill has promised support for this game up until like 2016, and what they've done since after the first couple of updates is just put weapon packs or character packs and be done with it. I really don't like these either, but they're not *that* intrusive (not ignoring this, it's dumb to do) until you start noticing that they're not adding other content because of it, and the original content gets old after the first couple of times playing them (which is not even remotely comparable to Payday 1's replayability in the heists, where you couple probably play each over 10 times and still not get bored). After a while, people pretty much finish all of the really interesting content and start to notice that the game's boringly repetitive, and stop liking the game and be done with it. That's really fine, but this game almost always has you play up until a point where you just stop entirely with the game.  Overall, this game's a blast to play over a break or during the school year or whenever, but after you start getting into about a hundred hours, the game's fun starts to deteriorate and the game seems worse. All of Overkill's content additions have been almost exclusively weapon packs, which really takes away from the good heists, which they don't seem to add. This game has a really finite amount of fun content, and it's nice to hit it and be done with the game, but you shouldn't play after that.  EDIT: After Crimefest 2015, I honestly can't recommend this game anymore. They promised not to ♥♥♥♥♥ DLC like all other AAA companies, but they did it anyway. All of the rewards were worthless, and they almost literally copied CS:GO's announcement of skins. Don't get this game, if for no other reason, to not give these greedy devs any money.  EDIT EDIT: the issues have been fixed, the things they added are no longer direct pay to win garbage, and they've been working to make actual good content like before.

Missions got boring for me and there aren't a lot of maps. Then again I have played 400+ hours now so that comes as no surpise. But our good friend Overkill releases plenty of maps in dlc packs. Clowns who kick you right before the end or if you don't please them or they don't like you for whatever reason you better start packing your stuff. The game is entertaining, a shame about the company degenerating over the years. Paid advertisements, microtransactions and poor coding. Impressive to consider that the former director and former EA employee was the one preventing this degeneration until he left.  I feel I should further elaborate. Over the years, strange decisions slowly came to light. Crimefest, public event which hosts a string of free updates, was culminated by the addition of John Wick; a nonsensical assassin from an unrelated film added as a poorly made character. He is not voiced by Keanu Reeves of course, but some strange imitation. Also provided alongside him had been the dual wielding feature, which was unfortunately poorly programmed, like a shoddily made weapon from a GMOD modder. As a final aspect to that particular note in the game, if the community had not achieved the community goal during said crimefest, John Wick would have been a paid DLC, despite being funded as an advertisement by the company that produced the film to begin with.  Following this, other traits of development began to become more prevalent. DLC was always a sticking point for many, but in some cases it was justified in the level of content it provided. That level of content slowly lowered over time however, whilst in some cases the cost of the DLC rose. With the release of the Diamond Heist, its associated character 'Clover' was sold separately, splitting the DLC in twain into two packs.  Programming does not seem to be Overkill's forte. The game was produced on the Diesel engine, used for former games such as Flatout and Bionic commando. Despite being their own engine however, the company cannot produce driving physics to even the vaguest degree of pleasantness, let alone gameplay. Any driving in the game is frequently avoided in the few heists that allow it. There are no leg and arm hit boxes, although one modder created them within the space of one afternoon. Multiple sights, underbarrel attachments... they seem to stalwartly ignore potential improvements. Flashbangs merely spawn into existence and are not thrown by any particular enemy, for example.   I will not go into detail regarding the weapon skins, as many others have. I merely wanted to explain that my negative review is a culmination of poor decisions and effort in Overkill in their development over the past two years. They realised how much money certain features could make, and ruined any possible theme the game may have once had. It has made its money however, and will continue to do so. I am merely curious to know whether the skins will be a part of that, or will prove detrimental overall.   Somehow, I doubt that.  Edit:  Lately it seems the company is making effort to improve the game in a surprising number of ways. It's a sign of effort at least, and far more than I anticipated from them. My original complaints have lost some traction in recent months with these changes, so I suppose I can change this to a hesitant yes for now, if they stay on this path.

6/2/16 Overkill have announced that they signed a deal with Starbreeze that transfers all of the PAYDAY franchise back to their ownership and have removed the 'pay-for' feature of all future safes, previously requiring the purchase of a $2.49 drill. In addition, the control of the game's updates are back in the hands of the players and Overkill. I will be changing my review from negative back to positive, and wish to congradulate Overkill on a job well done. Below are brief statements about the game I made awhile back about the whole micro-transaction fiasco, if you still care to read about it.      10/26/15 Overkill have addressed the issues stated below, but, in my opinion, gave lackluster answers to the community's questions. My review still stands as negative, and will stay so until they give us a long-term solution and/or compromise. I am overall disappointed with Overkill.  10/16/15 Below is my original review of Payday 2. Back then I loved it. I don't anymore. With the recent additions of MICROTRANSACTIONS, which were promised to never be present in the game, they have officially gone back on their word and deceived the community once again. I am unfortunately changing my review to a negative one, and it will stay like that until they have formally addressed the issues the community has with their actions.  -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  Payday 2 is the definitive co-op shooter. The game relies heavily on cooperation which I like. You choose from multiple ways to attempt a heist. Go in guns blazing? Maybe try the backdoor? Kill the guards and disable the cameras? The option is yours, the player, to choose.   Payday 2 also has a unique weapon system. You can make any weapon you want, wether that be a long range sniping rifle, or a close quarters shotgun. There are hundreds of combination options to make your gun unique. In addition to weapon personalization, there is mask customization as well. You can't just feel and sound like the true heister. You have to look the part!  The game also features a skill tree. You can spend points under the Mastermind, Enforcer, Technician, and Ghost trees. If you have a team balanced in all four trees, you will be unstoppable. Each tree has specific skills that compliment the others well.  On top of all this, Overkill is supplying the players with a constant stream of content, both free and pay-for. They listen to the community well, and often deliver items and features the community desires.  Payday 2 has got to be my favorite shooter, by far. I reccomend this game to anyone new to the genre, AND to the veterans of the shooter. Please support this company and purchase this videogame. You won't regret it. See you on the streets of D.C.

I could see my friend run to me throwing me a bag from very far in my sight ,and the bag fell under my feet. This is because his position I see is actually the postion several seconds before. He's actually close to my postion right now. This is not a once or twice issue, this is a issue throughout the whole multiplayer gameplay, which means you have no idea where everyone is actually at. The player position you see are delay displayed.  In go louds, you have no idea where your teammates are going to do. Like in a escape. You see a guy in the back, you run back to him to help him. Also, I think it might be a connected issue in multiplayer steath, client gamers are always so easy to be detected by guards. PAYDAY 2 is one of my favourite games of all time and by far one of the best co-op games ever made. Consistent updates from the developers over the past 3 years (as of writing), and being a game I have never been bored of (Had this game since release day on Xbox 360 then switched to PC) , I can strongly reccomend it.  PROS: -Insanely fun, solo or co-op -RNG Heist generation, playing the same heist twice will have changes to item positions like cameras, keycards, small safes etc. -Challenging objective based, cop killing gameplay -Unique concept -Fantastic level design -Amazing soundtrack -Fantastic community and developers (I forgive overkill for crimefest) -Community group content, basically a very big free DLC pack complete with characters, heists, weapons, masks and weapon mods just for joining the community group  CONS: -Far too much DLC, new players who didn't buy GOTY start out with very barebones content, only boosted slightly from the community group content -Difficult for players who don't have all the DLC to know which DLC they should get -Can be very confusing for new players -Powercreep, for example, 2 of the 3 sniper rifles in the Gage Sniper Pack DLC are outclassed by the free Platypus sniper rifle    Overall, some random guy on the internet thinks payday 2 is a fantastic game and well worth your money and time. It's expensive and time consuming to have all the DLC and be able to use all the weapons but is in my opinion worth it. 9/10

Payday 2 is the sequel to Payday: The Heist, which I admittedly do not own nor do I intend on owning it. I got this as a gift a while back and was kinda unsure about it. I didn't intend on buying this myself because it seemed relatively basic, but I was delighted to get in the game and find that I was wrong (in some aspects.) Payday 2 has it's ups and it's downs. We'll start on the upside first. On the ups, the game can keep itself fresh for a remarkable amount of time, even though there are only a small number of heists, the difficulty hikes are truly massive steps to take. Just making the step from Normal to Hard can be pretty tough, and don't even get me started on Very Hard. Just a little note. This game is EXTREMELY multiplayer oriented. If you try to solo it, it's incredibly difficult. Your only hope really is to turn on bots, of which you can only have 2 at a time, so it requires a buddy to join to make it a full crew. This is both good and bad for the game. For Multiplayer gamers, it adds a sense of necessity to cooperation, for single players, it just makes it feel kind of odd. At the end of every match, you have a chance of getting a mask customization item, gun mod, or a mask itself. I don't particularly like this system all that much. It may allow customization for your guns, but if there's a gun you want to be customizing to fit your build, but can't find any mods for it on the drops, looks like you're just stuck with a default gun until the x amount of time it takes to find a mod for it passes.  I'm really not all that sure of what keeps me interested in this game, it could be the definite role that each of your team members play, thanks to the game's flexible skill tree system (You could stack all on one tree or put a little into all of them,) the feeling of progress when you level up and look at how awesome your guy is now, or is it the fact that no matter how awesome your guy is, a Watchdogs heist on Very Hard is still going to wreck you.  I recommend this game, »ZCC« Zombie Chicken

For a $5 game, it sure does pack a punch with an arsenal of weapons and content. Since this game is old, the developers periodically release dlc content for a reduced price. Payday 2 does a great job adding new weapons that add a new twist without making it pay to win. I could argue that this is my favorite game right now, but it is so different from other genres. This game is grandiose, including a variety of enemy types, weapons and gamemodes. If I could make one final verdict, I would state that this title is perfect, except its cheat detection. PAYDAY 2 is an action-packed, four-player co-op shooter that once again lets gamers don the masks of the original PAYDAY crew - Dallas, Hoxton, Wolf and Chains - as they descend on Washington DC for an epic crime spree.   The new CRIMENET network offers a huge range of dynamic contracts, and players are free to choose anything from small-time convenience store hits or kidnappings, to big league cyber-crime or emptying out major bank vaults for that epic PAYDAY. While in DC, why not participate in the local community, and run a few political errands?   Up to four friends co-operate on the hits, and as the crew progresses the jobs become bigger, better and more rewarding. Along with earning more money and becoming a legendary criminal comes a new character customization and crafting system that lets crews build and customize their own guns and gear. Key Features Rob Banks, Get Paid – Players must choose their crew carefully, because when the job goes down they will need the right mix of skills on their side.  CRIMENET – The dynamic contract database lets gamers pick and choose from available jobs by connecting with local contacts such as Vlad the Ukrainian, shady politician 'The Elephant', and South American drug trafficker Hector, all with their own agenda and best interests in mind.  PAYDAY Gun Play and Mechanics on a New Level – Firing weapons and zip tying civilians never felt so good.  Dynamic Scenarios – No heist ever plays out the same way twice. Every single scenario has random geometry or even rare events.  Choose Your Skills – As players progress they can invest in any of five special Skill Trees: Mastermind, Enforcer, Ghost, Technician and Fugitive. Each features a deep customization tree of associated skills and equipment to master, and they can be mixed and matched to create the ultimate heister.  More Masks than Ever – PAYDAY 2 features a completely new mask system, giving players the ability to craft their own unique mask together with a pattern and a color combination, resulting in millions of different combinations.  Weapons and Modifications – A brand new arsenal for the serious heister, covering everything from sniper and assault rifles to compact PDWs and SMGs. Once you've settled for a favorite, you can modify it with optics, suppressors, fore grips, reticles, barrels, frames, stocks and more, all of which will affect the performance of your weapon. There are also purely aesthetic enhancements - why not go for the drug lord look with polished walnut grips for your nine?  Play It Your Way – Each job allows for multiple approaches, such as slow and stealthy ambushes, to running in guns blazing. Hit the target any way you want, and watch as the heist unfolds accordingly.  New Game Content All the Time – More than 70 updates since release and still going strong with new heists, characters, weapons and other gameplay features like driving cars and forklifts. Every month offers new free content and paid DLC as PAYDAY 2 continues to be developed by the OVERKILL crew until at least 2017.

Payday 2, a game about robbing banks and the likes. That's the main setting, you steal, you fight against cops, you aim to be rich.  Now, I'm not the type to write long reviews so I'll say this.  Payday 2 is a  Co-op  game, it revolves around teamwork and such, playing this game in solo is not recommended, as it may feel boring and tiresome after a few hours. Playing it with friends or pubs can be fun, even i still have fun with friends, messing around and throwing bags at each other and working together in the new difficulty, One Down.  You have skills, variety of weapons, melees, throwables, armors, deployables and perk deck, oh did i also mention, you can get a lot of masks and customize them to your fitting!  The game has a lot to offer to last around a few weeks of gameplay, quite a lot of heists and a lot of them are fun. It may get boring after some time but don't worry, either mess around, challenge yourself or play with friends to make it enjoyable again, or wait for the devs to update the game and add new heists.  Regarding the DLCs, there may be a lot but only quite a few are needed, or even yet none of them are needed at all. Its just there to add content.  And for the performance, i can't say its the best, but its not the worst either, some map lags, some doesn't. Can't be helped.  With that said, i think I'll give this game a 8/10, Oh did i also mention the OST? Now that's the best part about this game, the soundtracks, believe me you will love it. So whatcha waiting for? Story Story revolves around a Crew that you get to pick character to play an important role in running heists. The live action stories that go along with the game aren’t half bad and gives you an inside look on how the characters act and some back ground on them. Also with mission briefings you get some insights on how the crew interacts with the people who hire you and their roles on crime net and in the payday universe. This game is not the most story driven game but dose add a nice touch to the games lore if you are looking to learn more about this world and characters in it.  Gameplay The game play has changed much over the years from skills, levels, characters additions, perk decks, micro transactions added then removed but the core game is still there. This game is a great coop fps-skill leveling projection system this adds a lot of replay if being max level is your thing. The heist some are fantastic others are a little underwhelming but over all very satisfying when you complete a heist on higher difficulties. I do recommending playing with others online rather than solo your ai team just shoot enemies and will not help with objectives (think L4D). But overall the controls are good and feels like most other games of this type (killing Floor,L4D) sometimes hit boxes feel off but once you get use to them they are horrible. The skill system and perk decks are great to make any build for anyone’s play style and really make it so your character feels like your own. I do feel some skills need nerfs and buffs some are op in dw and others are under whelming and rarely get used any more.   Visuals and Sound The visuals are good but sometimes the optimization is horrible connections lost in the mid of the heists. Random lag spikes for no reasons and random game freezes this issues use to be a lot worse but have gotten better over the while. The soundtrack is great some of the music is some the best I have heard in a game for years but others are fall short. Most of the voice actors that did characters really put in time and effort to make the part there own there are a few that are generic and feels like they put very little in the part. Payday 2 is my first Payday game, though I have played a bit of Payday: The Heist after putting in a couple of hours into Payday 2.   Good : 👍 Great, fast-paced and fun gameplay  👍 Replayability: There are a lot of missions and multiple difficulties to choose from, some are stealth-able and others are straight up loud. 👍 Variety of characters: As of now, there are sixteen characters to choose from and most of them are pretty unique and have amusing voicelines like Jiro, Jacket, Jimmy. 👍 Various playstyles: There are a lot of skills to choose from, depending on your preferred playstyle. From being a dodgy character who relies on luck and uses dual-wielding pistols to a tanky character with heavy armour, slow movement speed and hard-hitting with a shotgun. There are also missions for people who prefer going loud and also those who prefer playing stealth. 👍 Modding capabilities: The modding community is pretty active and there are a lot of mods that change the game in their own way, whether purely looks or cosmetics like masks, sounds, weapon skins, HUD, or custom maps or mods that can change the entire gameplay like that one stealth mod.   Bad : 👎 Huge update sizes: Payday 2's updates can be huge even for small changes or additions to the game, this can be an issue for people with slow Internet or people on a data cap. 👎 Desync issues: At times there would be desyncronisation occuring, this is very noticable when you see a teammate's animations moving really fast. 👎 Amount of DLCs: The amount of DLCs the game has can be quite overbearing to most, especially new players. Though for players who have put in a lot of hours into the game and enjoy it often don't mind paying for the DLCs, I'm guilty of this.. sometimes. 👎 The drill: After spending a lot of time earning cash, continental coins, safehouse upgrades, weapons, loot, you still can't purchase a drill that doesn't break itself multiple times. Thanks Bain. 👎 Bullet sponginess: As of Hoxton's Housewarming Party, difficulty levels now change the HP multipliers of the cops, the higher the difficulty, the more HP a unit would have. This makes a lot of weapons useless, it could take up a lot of ammo to kill a normal unit.  Also, how does a bow do more damage than a .50 cal sniper rifle?  They have somewhat addressed Mayhem by giving the enemy units' Overkill HP and Death Wish damage and tweaking a bit of the numbers (?).   Notes : 👌 Achievements: There are a lot of achievements for the game, if one is an achievement hunter then they might see this as a good thing, for others, perhaps not. Some achievements also unlock in-game items such as masks, weapons or weapon mods. Achievements are being added as more content is being put into the game.   Suggestions : 💡 Better difficulties: Rather than introducing HP multipliers for the cops, I'd rather they kept it the way it was before but make the cops on higher difficulties deal more damage and introduce more difficulty-unique units.  I try to edit my review as I play the game more and as the game gets more updates.  EDIT 1:  So this is how it feels to be on the receiving end of a robbery. Just as I was about to get back into PAYDAY 2 because of friends and Crimefest, we get transactions and  rebalanced  weapons. Great. Just great.   EDIT 2: Game is less pay-to-win now, thanks update 100.

I review the core game.  In the category of an FPS, Payday 2 possibly isnt a very good game. From a technological standpoint it is outdated. Geometry, visual effects and textures are poor. the optimization is bad. AI behavior is depending on the hosts CPU speed. Bugs regularly get fixed and replaced with different ones. Difficulty scale has big gaps. From an aesthetic standpoint the animations are poor. physics feel like from the last century and through added DLCs an updates, the game has gradually shifted towards a different target audience. from a 90'es signature styled heist game based in Washington DC, PD2 turned more and more into an arbitrary CS:GO-pink M4 Carbine-something-with-goats for the lulz. Yes, I am still laughing. not.  Why do I still recommend Payday 2? Its a great shooter which rewards you for paying attention to your team members. The higher the difficulty, the more the game will weld you and your 3 friends together into a perfect clockwork. Hero/Macho/Chicken players get penalized for ignoring the needs of the team and the objectives. As I have gained more experience in the game, it felt very rewarding to beat a heist on a high difficulty level - especially in stealth.  The game soundtrack supports those adrenaline pushes, but it becomes annoying over time.

Let me get this straight - Payday 2 is an excellent game. Good mechanics, fun gameplay, many customisational masks, weapons, skills, and many characters to play. Graphics are very good, dialogue is funny and witty, and it's a challenge to play right. So there was quite a controversy over the past year however in this game because of Overkill's 'Crimefest Day One' update. The developers of this game had nerfed every weapon and introduced cosmetic skins, a la CSGO, but some weapon skins also had their own stat buffs, essentially including P2W microtransactions. The only way to really augment your build to the best it could be was to buy a drill to unlock a safe, which would drop a skin of a random quality, which works the exact same was as the aforementioned CSGO's skin crates work. For a time this made me put the game down as I was quite frustrated with the way the devs done things.  Thankfully, after the outcry of many players, the developers listened to the community and removed the microtransactions. Now all the skins can be unlocked for free and the safes and drills can both drop ingame at the end of a heist, where you choose one of three random rewards.   But the game is still great and has a lot of content, yes, but there is a LOT of DLC which is annoying. You don't really need any of it but it will lock you out quite a bit of the game. And the DLC is pretty frequent too. I would recommend the game but the sales are your best bet if you wish to get it and the DLC as it costs far too much for everything otherwise.
